data.reading_mnemonic: As <kanji>humility</kanji> washes over you, you feel a shaking in your <reading>shin</reading>s (<ja>しん</ja>). Humility lives in your shins, so now they're shaking and trying to bring you down to the ground.
data.reading_hint: Imagine humility literally moving through your shins. Can you still stand or do you need to fall to your shins, in humility?

data.meaning_mnemonic: Show your <radical>fingers</radical> to a <radical>giant</radical> to show you <kanji>refuse</kanji> him. Giants are very big. So big that when you talk they can't really hear what you're saying. Hold up all your fingers so that he can see what you mean.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine holding up your fingers to show a giant you're refusing to let him do something. Yeesh, you're brave!
data.reading_mnemonic: What do you <kanji>refuse</kanji>? You refuse to let him stomp all over Little <reading>Kyo</reading>to (<ja>きょ</ja>). Little Kyoto is your home! And if the giant comes any closer he's going to destroy all the little buildings and shrines and soba noodle shops.
data.reading_hint: Imagine standing in front of a giant, refusing to let him crush Little Kyoto. I hope he doesn't stomp on you instead.

data.meaning_mnemonic: In a <radical>tree</radical> on <radical>nine</radical> branches are some <radical>cross</radical> <kanji>frame</kanji>s. Each cross frame is hung on the branches of the tree. You don’t know who decided to hang the frames there, but you think it might be some new wave art or something. Actually you need a frame, and there are already nine up there, so you decide to take one.
data.meaning_hint: Feel the tree bark under your palms as you climb up the tree to take a frame. You get a splinter from grabbing the frame. It really smarts.
data.reading_mnemonic: The cross shaped <kanji>frame</kanji> you took has a picture of the American rapper <reading>Waka</reading> (<ja>わく</ja>) Flocka in it. If you don’t know who Waka is, take the time to YouTube a song of his to get the Waka beat flowin’ through your body.
data.reading_hint: Look at the picture of Waka Flocka as you imagine the sound of his groovy tunes. It almost makes you forget how painful that frame splinter you got is. Almost.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>turtle shell</radical> radical and the <kanji>turtle shell</kanji> kanji are exactly the same!
data.meaning_hint: Cowabunga!
data.reading_mnemonic: With a <kanji>turtle shell</kanji> on his back, imagine <ja><reading>こう</reading>いち</ja>.
data.reading_hint: Because this is WaniKani, <ja>こういち</ja> has probably set the turtle shell on fire, too. "Burn those turtle shells, burn those kanji!" he yells.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Criminal</radical> <radical>writing</radical> is always <kanji>patterned</kanji>. That is to say, there is a pattern to it, lots of ARGS and GONNA STAB YAs, but it's also patterned beautifully, with a collage of cut out letters.
data.meaning_hint: Can you see the patterns in the writing this criminal did? It looks like a quilt or some plaid. It's almost beautiful, the way those death threats are arranged!
data.reading_mnemonic: As you look closer at the <kanji>patterned</kanji> writing you realize that it forms the shape of an <reading>eagle</reading> (<ja>い</ja>). The most American bird of them all! Maybe this guy isn't a criminal after all!
data.reading_hint: Picture an eagle patterned out of cut out letters. What the words say isn't important (though it is asking for a ransom on your grandma), but the underlying image is gorgeous.

data.meaning_mnemonic: When a <radical>spirit</radical> <radical>stop</radical>s protecting you, you'll have to go on <kanji>welfare</kanji>. If you can't rely on your family spirit, you'll have to have the help and protection come from somewhere else.
data.meaning_hint: The next time you see someone on welfare, be nice. Their spirit stopped protecting them, so they need a little more help right now.
data.reading_mnemonic: While on <kanji>welfare</kanji>, you have to do the only job available to you: herding <reading>shee</reading>p (<ja>し</ja>). Sheep can help you out when you're having a rough time. Sheep provide warmth, wool for clothes, and even food, if you wanna get dark about it.
data.reading_hint: If you've ever been on welfare you probably already know about the sheep.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>grain</radical> stuck in your <radical>cleat</radical> had a <radical>former</radical> life. In that life it was a <kanji>rice plant</kanji>. It was a happy little rice plant, minding its own business, when it was yanked up and cleaned up and put in a bag for people to buy and cook and eat. That was so long ago. Now it's just a sad grain in the bottom of your shoe.
data.meaning_hint: When you look at a grain of rice, you should think of it's former life as a rice plant, not where it ended up.
data.reading_mnemonic: The grain of rice, as it thinks about its <kanji>rice plant</kanji> life too, mutters, "<ja><reading>いな、いね</reading></ja>." Yes little grain, it was a really nice life. I'm sorry.
data.reading_hint: You decide to bring the grain back to where all of the other rice plants are, and they all chant <ja>いな、いね</ja> as you return it to its home. You did a good thing today.

data.meaning_mnemonic: When you <radical>say</radical> "<radical>Nurse</radical>!" you're ready to <kanji>defer</kanji> to them.
data.meaning_hint: If you say "nurse" you're asking something of a nurse. For this story, pretend like you don't know what to do, so you're going to defer to their skill and let them take over.
data.reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>defer</kanji> to the nurse because you're trying to save the local farmhand, <reading>Jou</reading>rm (<ja>じょう</ja>), and you can't do it. He's bleeding a lot, and you don't know what to do.
data.reading_hint: It makes sense to defer to the knowledge of a medical professional. When going through this story, imagine yourself trying to revive Jourm, but nothing you do works. That's why you defer to the nurse. "Save Jourm," you say. "He's just a simple, kinda weird, ten foot tall farmhand with nine toes."

data.meaning_mnemonic: They <radical>say</radical> <radical>Mona Lisa</radical> had more <kanji>modesty</kanji> than any other woman at the time.
data.meaning_hint: Leonardo da Vinci picked her for her modesty. She's so modest she shows no emotion.
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>modesty</kanji> of Mona Lisa inspired <reading>Ken</reading> (<ja>けん</ja>) the samurai to become more modest.
data.reading_hint: Have you met Ken the samurai in person? He never smiles, and will never show you his emotions. He's too modest for that.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You use your <radical>foot</radical> to kick <radical>Wolverine</radical> in the face so a <radical>turkey</radical> can <kanji>leap</kanji> to freedom. This turkey is trying to escape from Wolverine by leaping over a fence. Wolverine doesn’t want the turkey to escape, but you kick him with your foot and the turkey is then free to leap to safety.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine kicking Wolverine in the head with your foot as the turkey makes turkey sounds in the background. He’s taller than you so you must leap as you kick.
data.reading_mnemonic: After you kick Wolverine and the turkey is safe, you <kanji>leap</kanji> onto a <reading>yak</reading> (<ja>やく</ja>) to make your getaway. This yak is really fast so you’ll have no problem outrunning Wolverine while riding it.
data.reading_hint: Leap! Leap onto the yak. Feel the yak fur beneath you as you ride away to safety, wind in your hair.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You need to <radical>allocate</radical> enough <radical>gold</radical> to buy a <kanji>gun</kanji>. Guns are weapons of the old world, so you can't just buy them with paper money. Guns have to be bought with gold coins and slabs and bricks.
data.meaning_hint: Picture yourself handing over an armful of gold bars to buy a single gun.
data.reading_mnemonic: You need this <kanji>gun</kanji> so you can steal some <reading>jew</reading>els (<ja>じゅう</ja>)! Why didn't you just use your gold to buy the jewels, you ask? Because! That's not how we did things in olden days. When you want jewels you buy a gun with gold and rob a jewelry store!
data.reading_hint: Picture an old fashioned hold up. You're holding a gun and shoveling jewels into a burlap sack. The heist of the century!

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Construction</radical> for <radical>geoduck</radical>s doesn't require as much paperwork as construction for humans, but you still need to write at least a <kanji>paragraph</kanji> to explain what you're doing.
data.meaning_hint: Actually imagine yourself writing one paragraph of explanation to the city so you can get the permits to construct housing for your geoducks. On the form, it specifies you should only write a paragraph.
data.reading_mnemonic: You turn in your <kanji>paragraph</kanji>, and it is given to Emperor <ja><reading>こう</reading>いち</ja>, who insists on being involved in all construction projects. Surprisingly, he approves your construction project, thanks to that paragraph you wrote in the application.
data.reading_hint:
In that paragraph, you praised <ja>こういち</ja> for being a great emperor, and you said that this construction project would help you to have more time to do your WaniKani reviews. Clearly you were pandering to Emperor <ja>こういち</ja> when you wrote it. But hey, it worked!

Hint: When you see <ja>工</ja> in a kanji it will often take the <ja>こう</ja> reading.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You come across a <radical>gold</radical> <radical>hill</radical>. You think you hit it big! You start digging, only to find out that it is merely a paper-thin layer of gold covering a hill of <kanji>steel</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Dig out many other spots. Every time, it's just steel under there.
data.reading_mnemonic: You report your findings about the <kanji>steel</kanji> you found to Emperor <ja><reading>こう</reading>いち</ja>. He is displeased that it is a hill of steel.
data.reading_hint: "I suppose I can use this steel, even if it is not a hill of gold," he says. "We will make steel weapons, which we will use to subjugate other nations. The whole world will learn kanji using the WaniKani system!"

data.meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>employ</radical> a <radical>geoduck</radical> to <kanji>review</kanji> all your work.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine hiring a geoduck, then ask them to review your work. Please review my writing, geoduck. Please review my record-keeping, geoduck. Please review my taxes, geoduck. This geoduck you employed can review anything for you.
data.reading_mnemonic: As the geoduck <kanji>review</kanji>s your paperwork, it notices something surprising. You have a <ja><reading>子</reading></ja> (<ja>こ</ja>)!
data.reading_hint: The geoduck tells you that while it was reviewing your records, it found information about a child you have. Even you didn't know this, so you're surprised that this review geoduck found something like this.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>horse</radical> is your <radical>master</radical> and you are merely a <kanji>resident</kanji> in his house. How did this horse become your master? Those aren’t questions a resident should ask! Know your place, resident!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine having a horse as your master. Hear him neigh out orders to you and the other residents of the horse master’s house.
data.reading_mnemonic: To prove yourself a worthy <kanji>resident</kanji> of the horse master’s house, you must capture <reading>Chew</reading>bacca (<ja>ちゅう</ja>). Your horse master collects rare creatures, and Chewbacca is his latest desire. If you wish to remain a resident of the house, you must capture Chewbacca.
data.reading_hint: Imagine Chewbacca in a cage in the horse master’s house. You’ve proved yourself a worthy resident. Hear Chewbacca making his Wookie sounds as he bashes against the bars of his new cage.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>horse</radical> goes to his favorite <radical>district</radical> to <kanji>gallop</kanji> around. This district has lots of cool buildings and lights to look at, so this horse loves to gallop around there.
data.meaning_hint: Hear the horse clip clopping around the district as it continues to gallop. Clip clop, clop clip clop!
data.reading_mnemonic: Then the horse <kanji>gallop</kanji>s into the road and gets hit by a <reading>ca</reading>r (<ja>か</ja>). Oh man, there’s blood everywhere. This horse is never going to gallop again. That car totally destroyed it.
data.reading_hint: The tires screech, the horse neighs, BAM! Total destruction everywhere. Bystanders scream in horror. That horse will never gallop again. It’s a sad day for all horsekind.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>tree</radical> is the <radical>master</radical> of a <kanji>pillar</kanji>. The pillar is subservient to its tree master because the tree is so great and awesome and big and cool and stuff. The pillar has great respect for its tree master.
data.meaning_hint: See the pillar next to the tree master. See the pillar bow over and over in veneration of its tree master.
data.reading_mnemonic: While bowing, the <kanji>pillar</kanji> accidently smashes <reading>Chew</reading>bacca (<ja>ちゅう</ja>). The pillar is horrified for having murdered Chewbacca, his tree master’s closest friend. The pillar is going to be punished.
data.reading_hint: Hear the crack and snap of branches as the tree beats the crap out of the pillar for having murdered Chewbacca. Unforgivable.

data.meaning_mnemonic: It's time to do the <radical>mouth</radical> <radical>sun</radical> <radical>sun</radical> <kanji>chant</kanji>. That's when you use your mouth to chant sun sun, sun sun, sun sun, over and over until the sun appears.
data.meaning_hint: Open your mouth and practice the chant right now! Sun sun, sun sun, sun sun!
data.reading_mnemonic: You're doing this <kanji>chant</kanji> because the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (<ja>しょう</ja>) ordered you to. The sun hasn't been shining on him as much lately, and he's displeased. So now you have to chant for him.
data.reading_hint: The Shougun is glaring intently at you as you chant. Open your mouth as wide as you can, get all those "sun suns" out, and pray that the sun will appear.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Teacher</radical>s are all around us. Those who came before us are our teachers, so it's important to respect them. This is the basic idea of <kanji>filial piety</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Respect your elders, for they have much to teach us.
data.reading_mnemonic: With <kanji>filial piety</kanji> in mind, you decide to go visit your father, who is <ja><reading>こう</reading>いち</ja>.
data.reading_hint: I am so ignorant and have much to learn. I must show filial piety to my father, <ja>こういち</ja>, so that he may teach me.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> of all the <radical>spider</radical>s is a <kanji>genius</kanji>! Spiders are already pretty smart. They can weave complex homes and traps in one web. They even know where not to step so they don't get caught. But the leader knows everything. It made itself a little webbed computer and everything!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine seeing the leader of the spiders weaving it's own little spider computer. Doing spider math, and spider chemistry. It's a genius!
data.reading_mnemonic: As you watch the spider <kanji>genius</kanji> you realize that <reading>soon</reading> (<ja>しゅん</ja>) spiders will take over the humans. They're just way smarter than us. Soon we'll be the bugs.
data.reading_hint: Soon we'll be slaves to the genius spiders. Soon we'll be the flies.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>Mona Lisa</radical> is in front of you. "You must all paint the Mona Lisa <kanji>concurrently</kanji>," says your art class teacher.
data.meaning_hint: Pay close attention to the students around you. Don't go too fast or too slow, or you won't finish concurrently.
data.reading_mnemonic: Your entire class finishes <kanji>concurrently</kanji>. You look at your finished result. Wait, that's not the Mona Lisa. You painted <reading>Ken</reading> (<ja>けん</ja>) the samurai.
data.reading_hint: It's a nice painting, the frown is just right, and you finished concurrently with everyone else, but you're probably going to fail this class.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Simultaneous</radical>ly, you throw your <radical>knife</radical> at another person who's throwing a knife at you and you both get a <kanji>dose</kanji> of your own medicine. Literally, there's poison on these knives and now you've both been stabbed.
data.meaning_hint: Watch as the dose of poison sinks into your body through the knife that's in your chest, as it simultaneously happens to the other guy too.
data.reading_mnemonic: "I need a <kanji>dose</kanji> of the antidote!" you yell, and the other guy looks you dead in the eyes. They slowly pull a tiny <reading>xy</reading>lophone (<ja>ざい</ja>) out of their pocket, play a few notes, and then eat it. "Ah, you'd like a dose of the xylophone cure, wouldn't you?"
data.reading_hint: Now you're begging them for a dose of the xylophone drug. Just a taste, you want to live!

data.meaning_mnemonic: You attempt to expel wind out of your <radical>mouth</radical> but <radical>lack</radical> the breath to <kanji>blow</kanji> out any. You’re using your mouth and trying to blow out some air, but you are failing to do so.
data.meaning_hint: Blow some air out of your mouth. It’s easy, right? Imagine what could cause you to fail at this activity.
data.reading_mnemonic: You silly <reading>foo</reading>l (<ja>ふ</ja>), the reason you couldn’t <kanji>blow</kanji> any air out of your mouth is because your hand was over it. You can’t blow air out that way. You silly fool, you.
data.reading_hint: Attempt to blow air out of your mouth while covering it with your hand. It’s hard to do, right? Only a fool would try to blow air out of their mouth this way.

data.meaning_mnemonic: When you're driving, you may notice the <radical>flag</radical>s in the <radical>dirt</radical> near the <radical>exit</radical>s. These flags mark the <kanji>ditch</kanji> running along the side of the road. You won't want to try to exit the road here or you'll end up stuck in one.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the flags in the dirt. Picture the ditch just over the edge of them. Now look for another way to exit this road, cause that way is just not a good idea.
data.reading_mnemonic: If you do end up veering into a <kanji>ditch</kanji> you'll find yourself yelling, "<reading>Holy</reading> (<ja>ほり</ja>) crap!" Then you'll go hurtling into the ditch.
data.reading_hint: It's a pun, get it? Holy. Hole-y. The ditch is a long hole. See? It's funny.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You're using your <radical>scooter</radical> to navigate the <radical>flood</radical> because you're on <kanji>patrol</kanji>. You're one of the few people with a floating scooter, so it's your job to patrol the flood waters and look for people and animals that need help.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine patrolling the flood waters on your scooter, which is bubbling and scooting along on the surface of the water. You have to be extremely vigilant in your patrol, you don't want any lives to be lost on your watch.
data.reading_mnemonic: You have to <kanji>patrol</kanji> all of the floods in <reading>June</reading> (<ja>じゅん</ja>). Unfortunately, that's the month when most of the floods in Japan happen, so you end up on patrol a lot.
data.reading_hint: You're in a group with a bunch of other scooter people, and you're all assigned to one month of flood patrol duty. But you got June. The floodiest month. Womp womp.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>drunkard</radical> issued <radical>twenty</radical> <kanji>commandment</kanji>s to his people.
data.meaning_hint: He basically just made up a bunch of commandments to order all the other drunkards around and decided having twenty (twice the amount of that other religion he heard about) would be a good number.
data.reading_mnemonic: The drunkard is yelling out his twenty <kanji>commandment</kanji>s to the others at the bar, but they're all about <reading>ka</reading>yaks (<ja>かい</ja>).
data.reading_hint:
Commandment 1: Thou shalt not touch my kayak
Commandment 2: Thou shalt not look at my kayak
Commandment 3: Thou shalt give me beer to put in my kayak

It goes on like that for a while...

data.meaning_mnemonic: Raise your <radical>fingers</radical> to a <radical>criminal</radical> to <kanji>reject</kanji> their request to have your things. If someone is trying to steal something from you, just reject them.
data.meaning_hint: "Talk to the hand, I mean, fingers!" you say, <kanji>refus</kanji>ing the criminal.
data.reading_mnemonic:
After you <kanji>refuse</kanji> him, he recites this <reading>hai</reading>ku (<ja>はい</ja>) at you: 

You are very mean / What's a criminal to do / But haiku at you.
data.reading_hint: You refuse to listen to any other haikus and you push your fingers into the criminal's face and walk away.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Use your <radical>fingers</radical> to shoo a <radical>turkey</radical> down the <radical>stairs</radical> and into a <kanji>portable</kanji> carrier. You've been trying to get this turkey into the carrier so you can transport it for like, the past hour. You finally got it done with the help of gravity. And, you know, smacking it a bit in the butt with your fingers.
data.meaning_hint: Turkeys aren't portable on their own. I mean you could pick one up I guess, but it will bite and poop on you. So get it in a portable carrier first.
data.reading_mnemonic: You needed the turkey to be more <kanji>portable</kanji> because you're going to be bringing it to a <reading>ca</reading>ke (<ja>けい</ja>) shop to turn it into a cake. You aren't cooking it! Geez, what's wrong with you? No, you're making a cake OF it, for its birthday. The baker needs to see it for reference.
data.reading_hint: Imagine getting a portable turkey cake made of your pet turkey. It's made of turkey friendly cake mix.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Every</radical> <radical>winter</radical> you are <kanji>alert</kanji> for danger. Everyone knows that the worst monsters come out in the winter so you need to be alert if you want to survive.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine yourself out in the winter wilderness. You hear twigs snapping, growling, leaves rustling. You’re incredibly alert and aware of everything going on around you.
data.reading_mnemonic: Being the <kanji>alert</kanji> fellow you are, you hear a sasquatch approaching and dive into a trash <reading>bin</reading> (<ja>びん</ja>) to hide. The bin smells really bad and you are keenly alert to all the various stenches and smells currently penetrating your nostrils, but at least you are safe.
data.reading_hint: Listen to the sasquatch rumble on by as you continue to smell the smelly smells of this putrid bin you’re in.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you have <radical>gold</radical> you also need a <radical>guard</radical> with a very <kanji>sharp</kanji> sword to protect it.
data.meaning_hint: You should probably also get some sharp spikes, sharp traps, and sharp spears to keep that gold safe too. Just a bunch of sharp stuff.
data.reading_mnemonic: You're setting up all these sharp traps around your gold when you step on a <kanji>sharp</kanji> <reading>a</reading>corn (<ja>えい</ja>) that's just laying on the floor. Ouch! But wait, then you get a great idea!
data.reading_hint: Imagine covering the floor around your gold in sharp acorns. This is basically a Home Alone situation, and anyone who tries to steal your stuff is gonna get stuck full of sharp things and probably stabbed by your guard.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Taking a <radical>cross</radical>, you walk through the <radical>rice paddy</radical> in the <radical>direction</radical> of <radical>winter</radical> and <kanji>spread</kanji> your arms wide. You spread your arms to halt the approach of winter because your rice paddy is not done growing yet. You take the cross with you for some extra religious power of persuasion.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine facing the direction of the approaching winter while facing away from the rice paddy. Feel the weight of the cross in your hands as you spread your arms and implore the winter to hold off on its arrival.
data.reading_mnemonic:
You’re actually a <reading>Sheikh</reading> (<ja>しき</ja>) (an Arab leader) which makes the fact that you’re holding a cross while you <kanji>spread</kanji> your arms even more of a big deal. You spread your arms wider than any Sheikh ever has before.

Side note: The official kun'yomi reading is just <ja>し</ja> but since no vocab words ever use <ja>し</ja>, we're teaching you <ja>しき</ja>, which includes what used to be okurigana but is never used outside of the kanji anymore.
data.reading_hint: Feel the strain on your Sheikh arms as you continue to spread them. Since you’re a Sheikh, you have to set a good example for your people, so don’t let them (or your arms) down.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Under the same <radical>flag</radical>, all the people get <radical>together</radical> to present a new <radical>weapon</radical> to your <kanji>lord</kanji>. You all bow and say, "<kanji>Milord</kanji>, this gift is for you." Because that's the proper way to address your lord.
data.meaning_hint: When you address your lord you better say "milord," otherwise you might get beheaded with the weapon you're all giving him.
data.reading_mnemonic: As you give the <kanji>lord</kanji> his weapon together, you see his face turn into a frown, "What's wrong, <kanji>Milord</kanji>?" you ask. "THERE'S A <reading>DEN</reading>T (<ja>でん</ja>)!" he bellows.
data.reading_hint: Oh no, oh no, oh no! Now the lord is running around with his dented weapon trying to put dents in all of you. You don't want a dent in your head! Run!

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>cow</radical> of <radical>righteousness</radical> is always there for us. He is the cow that must <kanji>sacrifice</kanji> himself for us to survive.
data.meaning_hint: The reason he is sacrificing himself is so we can all eat! Yum! Thanks to your sacrifice, righteous cow, we all have hamburgers. You should think about all the cows you ask to die for you every day. Maybe say thanks next time.
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>sacrifice</kanji> must be done via <reading>gui</reading>llotine (<ja>ぎ</ja>). I know, I know, that sounds really brutal, but it's the best way. It's fast, it's effective, and hopefully the sacrifice—I mean, cow—doesn't feel a thing.
data.reading_hint: Of course, the reading is also shared with kanji like <ja>義</ja>. The righteousness radicals seems to have that effect on kanji.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You see an <radical>animal</radical> with some <radical>flowers</radical> and a <radical>turkey</radical> on a <radical>stool</radical> trying to <kanji>seize</kanji> them. The animal with the flowers is really tall so the turkey needs to stand on the stool in its attempt to seize the flowers.
data.meaning_hint: Look at this turkey straining itself on the stool trying to seize the flowers, grunting with effort. You think he’ll ever get them?
data.reading_mnemonic: The animal the turkey is trying to <kanji>seize</kanji> the flowers from is a <reading>cock</reading> (<ja>かく</ja>). The cock is a lot bigger than the turkey, so that’s why the turkey needs to stand on the stool in its attempt to seize those flowers.
data.reading_hint: Imagine this scene again only with a big cock holding the flowers as the turkey attempts to seize them. Hear the cock shouting cock-a-doodle-doo as it defends its flowers.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You take <radical>flowers</radical> down a <radical>slide</radical> to a <radical>drunkard</radical> that you picked from your <kanji>luxuriant</kanji> garden. You picked the flowers from the luxuriant garden, not the drunkard, mind you. Also the drunkard has a cane, but not flowers. That’s why you picked some from your luxuriant garden and slid down your cool slide. Now the drunkard has a cane and some flowers.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine picking these flowers from your luxuriant garden then shooting down the slide. There are so many flowers that you are simply overwhelmed by their aroma. Now hand your flowers to the drunkard and watch his face light up as he excitedly thanks you for the gift.
data.reading_mnemonic: The drunkard is so happy to receive flowers from your <kanji>luxuriant</kanji> garden that he begins to <reading>mo</reading>an (<ja>も</ja>) with pleasure. The moans are getting louder and more erotic. You’re kind of creeped out. You really want him to stop moaning.
data.reading_hint: Hear the drunkard moan as he rubs the flowers all over his body. You’re really weirded out. This is the last time you give him flowers from your luxuriant garden, that’s for sure.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Every</radical> <radical>winter</radical> the <radical>thread</radical> fields become <kanji>overgrown</kanji>. Yes, thread grows in fields these days. And the thread grows the most in the winter because reasons. The thread gets so overgrown that you can’t even walk through it without cutting the thread down with a machete.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine trying to wade through this overgrown field of thread. It’s really difficult, and also it’s really cold because it’s winter. You shiver. Imagine chopping the thread down with your machete. Chop chop chop!
data.reading_mnemonic: The reason this field of thread got so <kanji>overgrown</kanji> is because you’re <reading>Han</reading> (<ja>はん</ja>) Solo and you’re not used to simple things like farming thread. Han Solo is used to blasting baddies and kissing princesses. Overgrown thread is not his specialty. Use your blaster to clear a way through this thread instead of using that machete.
data.reading_hint: Imagine yourself as Han Solo, bravely blasting your way through the overgrown thread with your blaster. Pew pew pew!

data.meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>walk</radical> by a <radical>geoduck</radical> a <kanji>frequent</kanji> amount. This geoduck really intrigues you, so you can’t help but frequent the area the geoduck is in and walk around.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine walking around near this geoduck. This is the best area to frequent when you want to look at the geoduck. Just keep looking at it as you walk.
data.reading_mnemonic: Apparently Hindu people also love geoducks because <reading>Hin</reading>du (<ja>ひん</ja>) people <kanji>frequent</kanji> this area quite often as well. You always see the geoduck here, but also a lot of Hindu people.
data.reading_hint: Look at all the Hindu people as you walk around and observe the geoduck. Hear them all speaking Hindi as you continue to walk around.

data.meaning_mnemonic: When you go to the <radical>yakuza</radical> to <radical>fix</radical> your problems they'll just <kanji>multiply</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: You thought you had problems before? Yikes, now you've done it. The yakuza are just going to make all of your problems multiply!
data.reading_mnemonic: Just like I said, your problems <kanji>multiply</kanji> before your eyes and give you quite a <reading>shock</reading> (<ja>しょく</ja>). You really shouldn't be shocked though, because I warned you this would happen.
data.reading_hint: Feel shock envelop your entire body as late payments multiply into more debt, and the number of people mad at you multiply too. You can't even think from the shock of it all.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>flowers</radical> are being worked upon by a <radical>tsunami</radical> with a <radical>specialty</radical> for knowing how to <kanji>dilute</kanji> things. The tsunami can dilute the flowers by pouring itself onto it. A tsunami can dilute things because it is made of water. You could say that it’s its specialty.
data.meaning_hint: Look at the flowers as they begin to dilute. Their color and fragrance and dimensions become weaker and more spread out. It’s really trippy to witness.
data.reading_mnemonic: As you watch the flower <kanji>dilute</kanji>, you determine that this is obviously a nature <reading>hack</reading> (<ja>はく</ja>). You’ve never seen anything like this before, so you think the tsunami found out how to hack nature and that’s how it got so good at diluting things. By hacking nature.
data.reading_hint: As you continue to watch the flower dilute due to the water being poured onto it by the tsunami, imagine what techniques this tsunami is using to hack nature. Is the tsunami a super cyborg from the future? Maybe.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you try to <radical>go</radical> somewhere but you're too <radical>heavy</radical> you'll <kanji>collide</kanji> with everything. Cars, people, houses. You're too heavy to dodge them, so you collide with it all.
data.meaning_hint: Imaging being too heavy to go anywhere without colliding with things.
data.reading_mnemonic: You're going around the town, you <kanji>collide</kanji> with a bunch of things, when all of a sudden you collide with the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (<ja>しょう</ja>)! Oh no! The shogun looks really mad.
data.reading_hint: The Shougun is glaring at you from the ground. "You've been colliding with my entire city and now you collide into ME?!" Smoke blows out his nostrils.

data.meaning_mnemonic: There’s <radical>grass</radical> on the <radical>ground</radical> and the <radical>fins</radical> there <radical>say</radical> you have no <kanji>honor</kanji>. The fins are left over from the fish you dismembered and they do not believe it was an act of honor. Now they are just sitting on the ground on the grass, calling you out for having no honor.
data.meaning_hint: Listen to what the fins have to say as they flop around on the ground in the grass. Hear them swish about as they flop, brushing up against the blades of grass.
data.reading_mnemonic: Being one of little <kanji>honor</kanji>, you decide to squash these vocal fins with your <reading>yo</reading>-yo (<ja>よ</ja>). You take out your yo-yo and start bashing each fin with it until they stop talking about what little honor you have.
data.reading_hint: Imagine taking your yo-yo out to do this. Feel the string tighten around your finger as you unleash the yo-yo and silence all the fins.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Lift the <radical>lid</radical> off your <radical>preserve</radical>s, <radical>kick</radical> it, and <kanji>praise</kanji> the lord! Your food is preserved, you don't need the lid anymore, praise be!
data.meaning_hint: You also praise the lid. And praise the plants and animals that gave you the food.
data.reading_mnemonic: You do this <kanji>prais</kanji>ing in your <reading>ho</reading>me (<ja>ほう</ja>), though, not a church. I don't think anyone outside your home would understand why you're praising inanimate objects.
data.reading_hint: If you're going to praise the ingenuity of the invention of the "lid" for its preservation methods, you should definitely do it from home. Or at least from the internet from home. Find your people where you can, you know?

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>scooter</radical> you made out of <radical>grain</radical>s and are about to ride down the <radical>stairs</radical> is completely <kanji>transparent</kanji>. You mashed the grains down so fine that you can see through them! And then you made them into a scooter.
data.meaning_hint: Picture this transparent scooter. Well, it's actually a bit hard to see, because it's see-through. I guess imagine the outline and the feel, as you perch at the top of your stairs.
data.reading_mnemonic: You slip, the <kanji>transparent</kanji> scooter scoots down the stairs without you and into the streets of <ja><reading>とう</reading>きょう</ja>. Nooo! Transpa-scootie come back!
data.reading_hint: Almost immediately you lose track of the scooter because it's transparent. All you see is <ja>とうきょう</ja> in front of you. And no scooter. Maybe this is why people don't make transparent vehicles.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Inside that <radical>building</radical> someone is doing a <radical>rice</radical> <radical>dance</radical>. That someone is your <kanji>neighbor</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine your neighbor doing a rice dance, whatever that may be, in the building next to yours. That's your neighbor, for ya.
data.reading_mnemonic: Your <kanji>neighbor</kanji> has an incredible <reading>rin</reading>g (<ja>りん</ja>) that they use for their rice dance.
data.reading_hint: Imagine the ring your neighbor has as overly extravagant. You have to make it wild enough for you to remember. Maybe it is integral to their rice dance. Perhaps you covet your neighbor's rice dance ring.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>fang</radical> on a <radical>turkey</radical> is <kanji>elegant</kanji>. Most turkeys do not have fangs, so this turkey with a fang is quite elegant and dignified. This turkey is special.
data.meaning_hint: Look at this turkey with a fang. It’s elegant, but also frightening. See the fanged turkey staring at you menacingly.
data.reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>elegant</kanji> fang makes the turkey look more like a <reading>ga</reading>rgoyle (<ja>が</ja>) than a turkey. In fact, you haven't seen it move at all. Maybe it is just an elegant gargoyle!
data.reading_hint: Picture this elegant gargoyle sitting in front of you. Reach out your hand and feels its hard, elegant stone gargoyle body.

data.meaning_mnemonic: On this <radical>scooter</radical> is a <radical>child</radical> who's trying to show that his <radical>lineage</radical> is <kanji>humble</kanji>. All of the other children are going around in fancy cars or helicopters, but this one child wants to be a humble child of the people, so he scoots on a plebeian scooter.
data.meaning_hint: Picture this child scooting to his fancy, expensive university in a little suit. Compared to the other kids, his wheels are quite humble!
data.reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>humble</kanji> child is your <reading>son</reading> (<ja>そん</ja>). You don't want any child of yours flaunting his wealth and good standing in the faces of other people. You've taught them to be humble.
data.reading_hint: You even bought your son this humble scooter and you really hope they don't grow up to be a selfish, spoiled kid this way.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>leader</radical> is also a <radical>director</radical> so you need to <kanji>pay respects</kanji> to him before you can start filming. He’s a huge big-shot and you don’t want to offend him by not paying the proper respects, so you make sure to bow every time you go on stage.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine bowing really really low as you walk on set. Don’t look him in the eye! He might get upset. Just do as you’re told!
data.reading_mnemonic: The name of the director is <reading>Ook Aga</reading> (<ja>うかが</ja>). Ook Aga is a caveman which is why everyone has to be really careful and make sure they <kanji>pay respects</kanji> to him. Ook Aga doesn’t know how to live in a civilized society so your phones and clothes scare him. You have to bow really low and respect what he says, moving slowly, so that he continues to direct you and won’t run away or hurt anyone.
data.reading_hint: Imagine Ook Aga looking down on you and you bow, slowly walking onto the stage. Oh no, your cell phone is ringing. He’s grunting Ook Aga Ook Aga and looking around angrily. Quick, put it away and pay your respects harder!! Bow, BOW!

data.meaning_mnemonic: You decide to <radical>loiter</radical> next to the <radical>trash</radical> under the <radical>moon</radical> in <radical>winter</radical> so the moon's light will <kanji>penetrate</kanji> you. The sky is <kanji>clear</kanji>est in winter, and this spot next to the trash happens to get the most of it.
data.meaning_hint: Picture a single beam of moonlight penetrating through the winter sky, right onto the trash.
data.reading_mnemonic: You want the light to <kanji>penetrate</kanji> you, so you put your face in the way of the beam and it shoots <kanji>clear</kanji> through you. Your mouth fills with the taste of <ja><reading>鉄</reading></ja> (<ja>てつ</ja>).
data.reading_hint: The clear, penetrating beam tastes exactly like iron, which is something you really weren't expecting. But now it's filling your entire mouth and you don't want it to stop.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> hits a <radical>bundle</radical> of <radical>geoduck</radical>s, swirling around their weird shapes, and creating <kanji>rapids</kanji>! The rapids are so violent, some of the geoducks break out of the bundle and get washed into the <kanji>shallows</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the bundle of geoducks getting smashed by the tsunami, breaking apart, and getting tossed around in the rapids.
data.reading_mnemonic: After being washed through the <kanji>rapids</kanji> and into the <kanji>shallows</kanji>, the living geoducks are screaming “<reading>Save</reading> (<ja>せ</ja>) me! Save me!” They need to be saved from the water, and you are the only one who can save them. You gotta run over and help them out.
data.reading_hint: Imagine reaching into the shallows and saving the geoducks as they scream, “Save me! Save me!” into your ear.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You use your <radical>fingers</radical> to dig through the <radical>trash</radical> in the light of the <radical>moon</radical> in <radical>winter</radical> because you're going through <kanji>withdrawal</kanji>. You need your fix and you need it now, so you're willing to freeze your fingers off digging through moonlit trash to get it.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine withdrawal this bad, that you're in the trash like this. Close your eyes and feel the cold, smell the stink.
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>withdrawal</kanji> makes you withdraw a <ja><reading>鉄</reading></ja> (<ja>てつ</ja>) and try to eat it. The taste of the <ja>鉄</ja> fills your entire mouth.
data.reading_hint: These withdrawals are turning you into an <ja>鉄</ja> eater. Ahhh!

data.meaning_mnemonic: You find some <radical>fingers</radical> from <radical>long ago</radical>. They must have been <kanji>set aside</kanji> by their previous owners. They definitely weren't cut off or anything, someone just decided they didn't want them anymore and set them aside.
data.meaning_hint: What would have to happen for you to set aside your own fingers? Try to imagine it right now.
data.reading_mnemonic: I know why they <kanji>set aside</kanji> their fingers long ago, it's because there was no <reading>so</reading>ap (<ja>そ</ja>). If you didn't have soap to clean your fingers you wouldn't want to keep them for very long...
data.reading_hint: Think of all the things you do with your fingers. Now picture how they would look if you had never ever cleaned them with soap. Uhg, disgusting. You should just set them aside here, and find some new ones.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Wipe your <radical>fingers</radical> on this <radical>table</radical> in <radical>winter</radical> to see what it was <kanji>based on</kanji>. The cold winter weathers cover the table in frost, and when you wipe it away, you can see traces of what the table was originally based on. All tables have to be based on something, even if it's just other tables that came before them.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine tracing your fingers over the table, the cold winter frost stinging them, as you reveal the secrets of this table and what it was based on.
data.reading_mnemonic: This particular table was <kanji>based on</kanji> the design on Little <reading>Kyo</reading>to (<ja>きょ</ja>). You feel the little, cold designs that were inspired by Little Kyoto. There are tiny little temples and shrines carved into the table that you could only find this time of year.
data.reading_hint: The table was based on Little Kyoto, but it probably wasn't made there. What a shame.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> of <radical>righteousness</radical> is the only one who can run this <kanji>ceremony</kanji>. Why? Because it's a very pure ceremony, and only those with an extremely righteous mind can run it.
data.meaning_hint: Have him run your ceremony for you. Think about why he is so righteous, then think about an extremely righteous ceremony.
data.reading_mnemonic: Sadly, the reason only the righteous can run this <kanji>ceremony</kanji> is because it's a punishment ceremony, where he pulls the cord to cut someone's head off via a <reading>gui</reading>llotine (<ja>ぎ</ja>).
data.reading_hint: *CHOP*

data.meaning_mnemonic: Each <radical>tree</radical> needs its <radical>drum</radical> <radical>measurement</radical> done before you can say it's really made of <kanji>wood</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: There are a lot of hoodlums out there that try to dress as trees and confuse people. So make sure you measure their drum before you cut one down or tell someone your secrets under it.
data.reading_mnemonic: If you're still not sure if the tree is really made of <kanji>wood</kanji>, just take out a small <reading>ju</reading>ice (<ja>じゅ</ja>) box and start drinking it. A wooden tree will show no interest in the juice box at all.
data.reading_hint: However! A non-wood tree will be really thirsty from pretending to be a wood tree. It will start making sounds and moving and probably say, "Can I have a juice box, please?"

data.meaning_mnemonic: In the <radical>trash</radical> is a weird looking <radical>fruit</radical>. Someone decided to <kanji>abandon</kanji> it here.
data.meaning_hint: Most people abandon fruit when it's misshapen. It's probably fine though...
data.reading_mnemonic: You reach into the trash, take out the <kanji>abandon</kanji>ed fruit, and bite into it. OUCH! There's a <reading>key</reading> (<ja>き</ja>) inside, and you just bit into it.
data.reading_hint: You abandon the fruit and stare intently at this key. It must be why the fruit was weird looking and abandoned in the trash... but what does it go to?! You dig through the trash and try the key on everything that's been abandoned in there.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tiger</radical> has <radical>legs</radical> that belong to a <kanji>tiger</kanji>. You know, a tiger has the legs of a tiger. This is common knowledge. Nothing new here.
data.meaning_hint: Look at the tiger running with his tiger legs. So majestic. So fierce.
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>tiger</kanji> is using his legs to run away from the <reading>Torah</reading> (<ja>とら</ja>). This tiger is deathly afraid of religion, so a holy book like the Torah causes the tiger to run away.
data.reading_hint: Imagine watching the tiger as it notices the Torah and then runs away. The tiger sounds as if it is screaming in terror as it flees from the proximity of the Torah.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>Viking</radical> <radical>insect</radical> is a <kanji>firefly</kanji>. In the insect kingdom, the insect most resembling a Viking is undoubtedly the firefly.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine this little firefly blinking his firefly light as he flies around shouting a Viking warcry and brandishing an axe. Yaaaargh!
data.reading_mnemonic: The Viking <kanji>firefly</kanji> is attacking <reading>Hotaru</reading> (<ja>ほたる</ja>) Tomoe (alter ego of Sailor Saturn) because the Viking firefly hates the show Sailor Moon and everyone on it. Hotaru screams in terror as she is deathly afraid of fireflies, especially Viking ones.
data.reading_hint: Hear Hotaru’s shrill scream as she runs away from the Viking firefly. If you don’t know what Hotaru Tomoe looks like, Google a picture of her to get a better visualization.

data.meaning_mnemonic: On the <radical>insect</radical> <radical>signpost</radical> there is a single sign that says <kanji>bee</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: This particular insect signpost points you to where the bee is.
data.reading_mnemonic: Thanks to the insect signpost you find the <kanji>bee</kanji>. You make it just in time to see the bee <reading>hatch</reading> (<ja>はち</ja>) from its egg.
data.reading_hint: You got to see a single bee hatch! What a beautiful sight. Weird that a signpost points to it.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>alcohol</radical> you take a <radical>measurement</radical> most carefully of is <kanji>sake</kanji>. Sake is very important to the alcohol culture in Japan, so you must make sure to measure it out to the precise amount.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine this sake as you measure it out. Hear it pouring out of the bottle as you catch the whiff of sweet alcohol in the air.
data.reading_mnemonic: You know who enjoyed <kanji>sake</kanji> a lot? <reading>Chew</reading>bacca (<ja>ちゅう</ja>). He was always drinking, which is concerning when you think about all the driving he did.
data.reading_hint: Imagine Chewbacca drinking sake all the time while Han Solo told him he needed to stop and get help, but Chewbacca just did his yell thing and drank more sake.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>roof</radical> (hive) on a <radical>certain</radical> <radical>insect</radical> (a bee) is what protects all of the <kanji>honey</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Bees are a certain insect that build a roof around their honey.
data.reading_mnemonic: To get the <kanji>honey</kanji> out, you need to put on special <reading>mitts</reading> (<ja>みつ</ja>) so your hands don't get stung.
data.reading_hint: Your thick mitts make it so the bees can't even sting your hands. Unfortunately, you are naked and only wearing mitts, what were you thinking?

data.meaning_mnemonic: You're digging in the <radical>dirt</radical> when you find a <radical>tiger</radical> and a <radical>cactus</radical>. You keep digging until you realize that these are a part of some big <kanji>ruins</kanji>. They're the ruins of tiger and cactus statues. It looks like whoever used to live here worshiped tigers and cacti. Or maybe they ate them. But now their whole civilization is just ruins.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine looking through these ruins. Picture the broken tiger and cactus statues. Try to imagine the people who used to live here before it turned to ruins.
data.reading_mnemonic: Well, as it turns out, these are the <kanji>ruins</kanji> of Little <reading>Kyo</reading>to (<ja>きょ</ja>), the city that existed before the modern day one. And it looks like the citizens of Little Kyoto faced their end a long time ago.
data.reading_hint: Picture the ruins of Little Kyoto. Try to imagine what it was like before the whole place fell apart. Maybe they would have lived on if they hadn't been doing things with sharp cacti and bitey tigers.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>boat</radical> that <radical>oversee</radical>s other boats, land, and people is usually a <kanji>warship</kanji>. They're the big boats that oversee everything around them. And if anyone steps out of line, a warship can take care of it.
data.meaning_hint: Picture a huge warship overseeing everything around it. It's big and kinda scary.
data.reading_mnemonic: This huge <kanji>warship</kanji> is run by Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (<ja>かん</ja>), the famous warlord. Really, what did you expect? Who else is strong enough to captain a warship but him?
data.reading_hint: Picture Genghis Khan aboard a monstrous warship. He's carefully watching the sea and land that he's conquered.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> carries a <radical>husband</radical> and his <radical>husband</radical> up into the <radical>sun</radical> where they <kanji>conceal</kanji> their centaur. The two husbands run a centaur farm, but the local government isn’t too pleased by this so they have to conceal their centaurs in the sun unless they want them to be confiscated by the government.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine the tsunami carrying the husbands and the centaur up into the sun. Hear the water gushing as they conceal the centaur up there. That tsunami is gigantic.
data.reading_mnemonic: What is it the husbands are going to <kanji>conceal</kanji>? Oh that’s right, a <reading>cen</reading>taur (<ja>せん</ja>). They are concealing a centaur in the sun. How forgetful of you.
data.reading_hint: Just make sure to remember there is a centaur up on that tsunami with the husbands. They need to conceal the centaur to keep it safe.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>gladiator</radical> turns his <radical>hand</radical> into a <kanji>fist</kanji>. A fist for punching other gladiators.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the gladiator squeezing his hand into a tight fist, raising it up and yelling.
data.reading_mnemonic: The gladiator's <kanji>fist</kanji> is now aimed at <reading>Ken</reading> (<ja>けん</ja>) the samurai. Little does the gladiator know, Ken knows the ways of the samurai and the gladiator. He slowly raises his own hands and turns them into fists.
data.reading_hint: Ken and the gladiator clash! Fists fly! You've never seen hand-to-hand combat like this! You can hardly keep up!!

data.meaning_mnemonic: You climb up a <radical>mountain</radical> and a <radical>cliff</radical> in search of <radical>fire</radical>, but all you find is <kanji>charcoal</kanji>. You can make fire with the charcoal, but you were hoping to find fire itself. All that climbing for nothing.
data.meaning_hint: You’re angry that you could only find charcoal so you take the charcoal in your hands and you crush it atop the cliff on the mountain. Feel the charcoal breaking in your hands as the wind carries the charcoal dust off from the top of the cliff on the mountain.
data.reading_mnemonic: After crushing the <kanji>charcoal</kanji>, you decide to take advantage of your current location and lay out in the sun for a while to get a <reading>tan</reading> (<ja>たん</ja>). Instead of getting a tan though, you catch on fire. Oops.
data.reading_hint: Imagine lying out in the sun next to the crushed charcoal, thinking you’re going to get tan. You’re very surprised when you actually catch on fire. Hot hot hot!

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>fire</radical> in the <radical>rice paddy</radical> burns down the <kanji>field</kanji>. The rice paddy fire spreads out from the paddy and consumes the field next to it. This rice paddy fire has ravaged your entire farm!
data.meaning_hint: Look at this fire burning the rice paddy and the surrounding field. Smell burnt rice in the air as you see the flames dance before your eyes.
data.reading_mnemonic: Your rice paddy farm and <kanji>field</kanji> are on a cay. A cay is a small, sandy island, and since your farm is on fire, this cay has turned into a hot cay. Or as Mario would say, that’s one-a <reading>hot-a cay</reading>! (<ja>はたけ</ja>) Mama mia!
data.reading_hint:
Imagine running around this hot cay as you try to put out the fire in your field. The fire is ravaging the entire hot cay, so it takes you a while to put it out. Man those flames are hot.

Also, this kanji can have the reading <ja>はた</ja> for the kun'yomi as well. If you learn the longer version (<ja>はたけ</ja>) it will be easier to just shave off a kana to remember the shorter version.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>wrap</radical> radical and the <kanji>wrap</kanji> kanji are the same!
data.meaning_hint: Know your radicals, yo!
data.reading_mnemonic: Think about being <kanji>wrap</kanji>ped up, nice and warm and safe in your home (<ja>ほう</ja>). Home is where you wrap yourself in a blanket, in the warmth of the fireplace, in the arms of those you love.
data.reading_hint: Home is where the wrapped heart is.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>clothes</radical> radical and the <kanji>clothes</kanji> kanji are exactly the same! Surprising!
data.reading_mnemonic: An <reading>ea</reading>gle (<ja>い</ja>) sees a pile of your <kanji>clothes</kanji> and lays an <reading>e</reading>gg (<ja>え</ja>) in them. The eagle’s egg needs a soft warm place to incubate, and your pile of clothes is the perfect place.
data.reading_hint: Look at the eagle and her egg sitting atop your clothes. Every time you get close the eagle starts to screech at you fiercely. Screee! Screee!

data.meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>leader</radical> has <radical>two</radical> things that remind him of his <kanji>humanity</kanji>: his shoes, and his hat. These two things remind the leader of his humanity because humans are the only ones who wear shoes and hats.
data.meaning_hint: Reflect upon your own humanity. What does it mean to be human? Is it wearing shoes and hats? Probably.
data.reading_mnemonic: Another thing that reminds you and the leader about your <kanji>humanity</kanji> is wearing <reading>jean</reading>s (<ja>じん</ja>). Jeans are the go-to legwear for many people, and no one but humans wear them. Jeans are another great symbol of humanity.
data.reading_hint: Are you wearing jeans right now? If so, rub them with your hands and say aloud “Oh, the humanity!” Or just imagine wearing jeans if you aren’t actually wearing them.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Aside from <radical>gold</radical> there are a <radical>wide</radical> variety of other <kanji>mineral</kanji>s as well.
data.meaning_hint: Think of the wide range of minerals there are that aren't gold. There are a lot.
data.reading_mnemonic: One person is trying to control all the <kanji>minerals</kanji> of the world. That person is Emperor <ja><reading>こう</reading>いち</ja>.
data.reading_hint: Emperor <ja>こういち</ja> is getting all the minerals, and the <ja>鋼</ja>, so he can take over all neighboring nations and force them into a subjugation of efficient kanji learning.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Dig up a <radical>mole</radical> and you <kanji>attain</kanji> a mole status. You're always trying to attain a new level for yourself and now you get to be on the mole level!
data.meaning_hint: It's actually pretty easy to attain mole status. Just stand in a field. Wait for the ground to move under you and shove your hand in the earth. Blam! An achievement pops up above your head and you're there.
data.reading_mnemonic: Mole isn't enough, you want to <kanji>attain</kanji> <reading>shee</reading>p (<ja>し</ja>) status next. Everyone knows it goes human > mole> sheep. Now you need to stand in the field with the mole and get a sheep to come over.
data.reading_hint: If you can attain two animal levels in one day you'll be a legend on the leaderboards.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Something you <radical>say</radical> to someone you <radical>become</radical> attached to should be said with <kanji>sincerity</kanji>. You need to speak with sincerity when you say things to someone who will eventually become your significant other, for example.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine saying something with sincerity to someone you want to become important to you. Say something like, “I love you” out loud. Say it with the utmost sincerity.
data.reading_mnemonic: When you say something with complete, unabashed <kanji>sincerity</kanji> your special <reading>sa</reading>ber (<ja>せい</ja>) starts to pulse with the beating of your heart. It shows the person you want to become close to that you truly are sincere!
data.reading_hint: Say, "I love you," again and watch your saber beating in time with your heart. If you weren't sincere it would fade and grow dull.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Everyone has a <radical>poop</radical> <radical>guy</radical> from their <kanji>hometown</kanji>. You know. That poop guy. And every single time you try to visit your hometown, poop guy is there making everyone uncomfortable and reminding you why you left in the first place.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the poop guy from your hometown. Picture him really vividly. The awkward, rude things he does. The way he smells. The way he makes you never want to come back.
data.reading_mnemonic: Your <kanji>hometown</kanji> is in <ja><reading>きょう</reading>とう</ja> which, unfortunately, means your poop guy is in <ja>きょうとう</ja> too. Now every time you go back home he's there stinking everything up.
data.reading_hint: Imagine all the wonderful things that exist in your hometown of <ja>きょうとう</ja>. All the things you love to do and see. And now picture poop guy. Ruining it all with his poop hands.

data.meaning_mnemonic: There is a tiny <radical>leader</radical> on <radical>Wolverine</radical>’s <radical>forehead</radical> sitting on a <radical>stool</radical> and commanding his troops to <kanji>invade</kanji> Wolverine’s brain. These tiny soldiers are going to invade Wolverine’s body in an attempt to destroy him. The leader himself isn’t going to invade Wolverine’s brain, he’s just going to sit on the stool and supervise.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine the little leader sitting on Wolverine’s forehead as he shouts “Invade! Invade invade! Invade his brain and destroy the Wolverine!”
data.reading_mnemonic: Soon they realize that they cannot <kanji>invade</kanji> Wolverine through his head so they travel down to his leg and try to enter through his <reading>shin</reading> (<ja>しん</ja>). The little soldiers take a big knife and slice open Wolverine’s shin in order to invade his body.
data.reading_hint: See the little soldiers slicing open Wolverine’s shin as Wolverine grunts in pain. Getting your leg cut open is not a comfortable thing, even for someone as manly as Wolverine.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> gets a nice uniform for the <radical>sake</radical> of not wanting to look like a <kanji>fake</kanji>. The leader is a fake, he just doesn’t want to look like one. He’s not really a leader, but he thinks he should get an official-looking uniform for the sake of not looking like a fake.
data.meaning_hint: Look at this fake leader. See him scramble into a uniform. Does he look like a real leader? Or can you tell that he is a fake?
data.reading_mnemonic: Well, everyone found out he was a <kanji>fake</kanji> anyway, and now you're all going to use a <reading>gui</reading>llotine (<ja>ぎ</ja>) to cut off his fake head.
data.reading_hint: Watch as the guillotine comes down. You close your eyes for a second, and when you open them you see that the leader's body was a fake! Wait, where did he go?!

data.meaning_mnemonic: Even though you’ve <radical>old</radical> <radical>legs</radical>, you <kanji>overcome</kanji> your disability. These old legs of yours don’t work very well, but you overcome the odds and you run a marathon!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine running a marathon with your old legs to prove you can overcome anything. Feel your old legs cramping up as you try to overcome the marathon and finish the race.
data.reading_mnemonic: When you pass the finish line and finally <kanji>overcome</kanji> the limits of your old legs, someone hands you an ice cold <reading>Coke</reading> (<ja>こく</ja>) as a reward. Mmm, such a refreshing Coke.
data.reading_hint: Filled with the jubilation of achievement from overcoming all odds, imagine the flavor of this cold Coke in your mouth. Fizzy and Coke flavored, it runs down your throat and into your tummy. Yum.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>mole</radical> has a <radical>knife</radical> ready for your <kanji>arrival</kanji>. You get out of your airplane, you step on the ground and... ouch! You stepped right on the knife, and there's the mole, sticking it out of the ground. "I checked the schedule for your arrival!" it squeaks happily, and disappears.
data.meaning_hint: Welp, your arrival didn't go smoothly. You have a knife in your foot. I'm not sure what you did to make that mole hate you, but you'll have to be more careful next time.
data.reading_mnemonic: Your <kanji>arrival</kanji> to <ja><reading>とう</reading>きょう</ja> is now ruined. And your next stop is now going to be an arrival at a <ja>とうきょう</ja> hospital to get this mole knife out.
data.reading_hint: This certainly wasn't the type of arrival you were expecting when you bought your tickets to <ja>とうきょう</ja>.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you have one <radical>stool</radical> and another <radical>stool</radical>, you have a <kanji>pair</kanji> of stools. Look at this pair of stools. Look at it.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine being in front of this pair of stools. Picture yourself sitting on one stool, getting up, then sitting on the other. Repeat this process.
data.reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>pair</kanji> of stools shares a <reading>sou</reading>l (<ja>そう</ja>). Even if you tried to separate them, they'd eventually find their way back together.
data.reading_hint: It's the same with pairs of socks and pairs of people. Sometimes what looks like two things is really a perfect pair, with one soul. Meant to be together forever.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Put an <radical>axe</radical> in your <radical>mouth</radical> with your <radical>fingers</radical> to express your <kanji>philosophy</kanji>. Your philosophy of putting weapons in your mouth. Everyone else seems to think it's a stupid philosophy, so you're showing them that it's not with actions!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine expressing your philosophy, your deepest thoughts and beliefs, by putting it in your mouth.
data.reading_mnemonic: Your <kanji>philosophy</kanji> on weapons in mouths means you're always tasting <ja><reading>鉄</reading></ja> (<ja>てつ</ja>). They say blood tastes like copper, well weapons taste like iron.
data.reading_hint: Your philosophy and your way of life means everything tastes like <ja>鉄</ja> now, and you think everyone should be that way.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Under the <radical>cross</radical> is a <radical>mouth</radical> and another <radical>mouth</radical> wearing special <radical>clothes</radical> because they're in <kanji>mourning</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the cross looming overhead, people's mouths open so they can sob loudly, and everyone wearing the same color clothes (just picture whatever color works for your particular culture/religion combo).
data.reading_mnemonic: As the <kanji>mourning</kanji> continues, the <reading>sou</reading>l (<ja>そう</ja>) of the dead person rises out of the cross. The soul looks around at all of the mourners and nods. Yes, your mourning has pleased it.
data.reading_hint: If you aren't mourning enough, when the soul comes out of the person's body, it will get really mad. "What, I'm not worth a few tears? Really?" And then the soul will haunt you. So you better mourn like you mean it.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>servant</radical> secures a <radical>stool</radical> in the <radical>dirt</radical> so that it is a <kanji>solid</kanji> sitting device. If you just throw a stool on the ground it will flop over easily. But if you have a servant to dig it into the dirt a bit, it becomes nice and solid and safe for sitting!
data.meaning_hint: Picture two stools in your mind. One is solid, you want to sit on it. The other looks like the wind will knock it over. Don't sit on that!
data.reading_mnemonic: You need this stool to be extra <kanji>solid</kanji> because you're using it to test your new <reading>cata</reading>pult (<ja>かた</ja>). If it isn't solid, when you launch it and yourself in the catapult, the stool might fall over, killing you both. And you don't want that, now do you?
data.reading_hint: You better hope that catapult is solid too. If it isn't the whole thing will come apart when you try to launch yourself into the air.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Under the <radical>canopy</radical>, you use a <radical>tree</radical> for your <kanji>floor</kanji>. It also becomes your <kanji>bed</kanji>, because hey, what is a floor but the original bed?
data.meaning_hint: You lay it down, cut it into slats, and voila! A floor! And a bed!
data.reading_mnemonic: News of your amazing <kanji>floor</kanji> / <kanji>bed</kanji> spreads and reaches the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (<ja>しょう</ja>), who wants to come see it. He's impressed, and asks you to build floor beds out of trees laying under this canopy in all of his buildings.
data.reading_hint: This new floor + bed invention, along with your other accomplishments, have you being watched really closely by the Shougun now. He seems to be keeping an eye on you so he can swoop down and check out everything you do.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Someone's <radical>fingers</radical> touch your <radical>tongue</radical> and <kanji>fasten</kanji> it together. You can't talk. All you can do is make sad tongue-less sounds as you try to figure out who would fasten your tongue like this.
data.meaning_hint: Try to fasten your own tongue with your fingers right now. You probably can't do it, right? That's because your fingers are too big and your tongue is too slippery.
data.reading_mnemonic: Only one creature could use its fingers to <kanji>fasten</kanji> your tongue like this: <reading>cats</reading> (<ja>かつ</ja>). Cats are notorious for fastening tongues so that people can't speak. Haven't you ever heard the phrase, "Cat got your tongue?"
data.reading_hint: In this case, many cats fastened your tongue. You should probably be nicer to cats from now on so this doesn't happen again.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Shoot a <radical>melon</radical> out of a <radical>bow</radical> and it will fly in a steep <kanji>arc</kanji>. Melons are too heavy to fly straight, after all.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine shooting a really heavy melon out of a bow. Watch it make an arc through the air. Trace the arc with your finger.
data.reading_mnemonic: Shooting melons in an <kanji>arc</kanji> is something little <ja><reading>子</reading></ja>'s (<ja>こ</ja>) love to do. It also helps that when they come down from the arc they smash all over the place.
data.reading_hint: Imagine being a <ja>子</ja> and watching melons fly in arcs all over. Imagine a little <ja>子</ja> version of yourself giggling and clapping your hands with absolute glee.

data.meaning_mnemonic: When your <radical>finger</radical>s move like that, you know it's an <radical>omen</radical> of a <kanji>challenge</kanji> that will face you soon in the future.
data.meaning_hint: What kind of challenge is it? If you look closely at your fingers sometimes you can figure out the challenge that is to come based on their movements.
data.reading_mnemonic: In your finger, you see a <kanji>challenge</kanji>. And... if you look closely, you can see the fast movements of your fingers forming the outline of Mrs. <reading>Chou</reading>'s (<ja>ちょう</ja>) face. Oh no, the challenge is going to be Mrs. Chou!
data.reading_hint: Whenever you see an omen (radical), there's a good chance that Mrs. Chou will be a part of it. This is not a good sign.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You see a <radical>flag</radical> near the <radical>exit</radical>, so you use your <radical>fingers</radical> to <kanji>dig</kanji> there. Most flags mark something, and this exit is pretty obvious, so there must be something under here. At least that's what you think to yourself as you dig.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine digging under the flag by the exit of your building with your bare fingers. The dirt is getting under your fingernails as you dig. It's getting on your knees. It's everywhere.
data.reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>dig</kanji> until you finally hit something. It's a bunch of buried old <reading>coots</reading> (<ja>くつ</ja>). They're in an underground room for old coots. One yells up at you, "Whatcha doing to our roof, ya whipper snapper?! Stop digging in our lawn!"
data.reading_hint: You carefully un-dig the old coots and leave them to their old grumpy coot hole... basement... secret clubhouse? Whatever.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you have <radical>fingers</radical> it's <radical>easy</radical> to <kanji>hoist</kanji> things above your head. If you don't have fingers, well, it's not so easy.
data.meaning_hint: Hoist the sails! Hoist the anchor! Hoist a baby! All of these situations are easier if you have a ton of working fingers. (The more the better.)
data.reading_mnemonic: Today, though, you have to <kanji>hoist</kanji> a bunch of <reading>yo</reading>gurt (<ja>よう</ja>). It's for your job. And lucky for you, you have fingers so it's easy! But yogurt is still slippery and heavy. Oh, did I mention this yogurt isn't contained in anything? Good luck!
data.reading_hint: Imagine hoisting loose yogurt onto a ship. Feel it between your fingers and dripping onto your head as you hoist it above you. I hope you aren't lactose intolerant, cause it's getting all over you.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You use your <radical>fingers</radical> in a <radical>shop</radical> to <kanji>grip</kanji> what you want to buy.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine picking up a few different things in a shop. If something fits nicely in your grip: buy it. If it's too small or too big, put it back.
data.reading_mnemonic: You have a really strong <kanji>grip</kanji> thanks to <reading>acu</reading>puncture (<ja>あく</ja>)! All your fingers are primed for buying things. You can grip anything at a shop—pineapples, tires, even live turtles. All thanks to some well-placed needles.
data.reading_hint: Acupuncture is great for strengthening your grip strength. If you do intense shopping (like I do) you should definitely consider it!

data.meaning_mnemonic: You grab a <radical>satellite</radical> with your <radical>fingers</radical> and <kanji>shake</kanji> it! You're an astronaut and it's your job. Don't worry, the satellite won't break or anything, it's strong for space travel. Just do as you're told and shake the sucker.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine being in space and shaking a satellite with your fingers.
data.reading_mnemonic: You need to <kanji>shake</kanji> it because this satellite is full of <reading>yo</reading>gurt (<ja>よう</ja>). And you only like yogurt that's been well shook. And who can resist space yogurt? Huh? Anyone?
data.reading_hint: Imagine shaking yogurt in space. Now imagine eating yogurt as it continues to shake (in space still)!

data.meaning_mnemonic: Use <radical>simultaneous</radical> <radical>jackhammer</radical>s to perform the <kanji>purification</kanji> ritual. Two jackhammers running perfectly in sync will purify your body, mind, and soul! (And the ground around you that's being jackhammered.)
data.meaning_hint: Close your eyes and feel the purification begin. Try not to let the loud jackhammering sound bother you, just focus on the simultaneous vibrations cleansing you inside and out.
data.reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>purification</kanji> ritual is supposed to help you forget your <reading>cy</reading>borg (<ja>さい</ja>). It's been a while, but you can't seem to get it our of your head.
data.reading_hint: Hopefully this purification (or just the two jackhammers shaking your brain up like pudding) will get the memories of your cyborg to go away. You can't keep picturing it all the time like this.

data.meaning_mnemonic: To your <radical>car</radical> you take an <radical>axe</radical>. The <radical>sun</radical> has broken your car for good this time (you think). You're so angry at your car. You think this is permanent. Turns out, though, that it's not permanent. It's just like that <kanji>temporarily</kanji>. You did make it permanent by taking an axe to your car, though.
data.meaning_hint: Feel sad that you were the one to destroy your car for good, even though the sun messed it up temporarily.
data.reading_mnemonic: You were driving around in <reading>Zan</reading>zibar (<ja>ざん</ja>) when this happened, too, so now you're stuck in Zanzibar, a foreign place, and you have no idea what to do next.
data.reading_hint: You should probably be worried about this situation.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You hit a <radical>tree</radical> with an <radical>axe</radical> so you can do some <kanji>analysis</kanji> on it. To do the analysis on the tree, a cross section needs to be obtained, so you must chop it in half with your axe.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine taking this axe in your hands and chopping away at this tree to do your analysis. Hear the chop chop chop as wood chips fly into your face.
data.reading_mnemonic: The person who is doing this <kanji>analysis</kanji> is very <reading>sexy</reading> (<ja>せき</ja>). Who is this sexy person? Why it’s you of course, you sexy beast. I love watching you do analysis on trees. It’s so sexy.
data.reading_hint: Imagine yourself being sexy and doing tree analysis. What sort of sexy analysis moves can you think of? Oh yeah, so sexy.

data.meaning_mnemonic: In the <radical>tree</radical> <radical>district</radical> of town you can buy a lot of tree products, including doors. With those doors, though, you always need <kanji>hinge</kanji>s.
data.meaning_hint: Don't forget to buy a hinge. Your door purchase will <kanji>hinge</kanji> on your hinges.
data.reading_mnemonic: You buy an awesome <kanji>hinge</kanji> and try it out. Instead of working properly, it just falls apart and the door falls on you, crushing your lower body. You yell out (and you have to yell) "I'm GOING TO <reading>SUUUUEEE</reading> (<ja>すう</ja>) YOU!"
data.reading_hint: Really lengthen out that "sue" because it's a long "suu" for the reading and that will help.

data.meaning_mnemonic: For a <radical>car</radical>, the <radical>reason</radical> why it works is because it has an <kanji>axis</kanji> that it is built on. If it doesn't have that, it won't work at all.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine a car without an <kanji>axis</kanji> on it. Not a car that will work too well.
data.reading_mnemonic: You see a car without an <kanji>axis</kanji> and it's your friend's car. He's all like "isn't this a cool car?" You reply: "<reading>Gee, coo</reading>l" (<ja>じく</ja>) very sarcastically.
data.reading_hint: You're super sarcastic about this, so feel the sarcasm inside of you when you imagine this.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You walk up to a <radical>tree</radical> and put <radical>dynamite</radical> on it. Then you set it off. BOOM. It explodes, but doesn't do what you'd expect. Instead of blowing the tree up, it blasts a very beautiful <kanji>pattern</kanji> into the side of it as well as the ground around it.
data.meaning_hint: Think about what pattern it might be. Is it a checkered pattern? Something more complicated and beautiful? Whatever it is, think of something that really impresses you.
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>pattern</kanji> is so beautiful that you want to put it on your <reading>gara</reading>ge (<ja>がら</ja>). So, you do.
data.reading_hint: Imagine painting your garage with the pattern you imagined earlier.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>tsunami</radical> that is <radical>white</radical> is the most scary tsunami of all. It doesn't come in and destroy everything. No, it comes in, goes inside your door, then stays at your place <kanji>overnight</kanji>, without even asking!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine the white tsunami knocking on your door, walking into your house, and then just laying down on your bed. You try to tell it to leave, but it's a tsunami, and it says it will be staying overnight thank you very much.
data.reading_mnemonic: Your cat walks up to the white tsunami that's staying <kanji>overnight</kanji> and decides it doesn't like it, so it <reading>hack</reading>s (<ja>はく</ja>) up a hairball on it. Even that doesn't get the tsunami to leave.
data.reading_hint: See the hairball slowly sinking into the tsunami. The cat hacks up another one.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> breaks your <radical>bone</radical>s, not from hitting you, but from making the ground <kanji>slippery</kanji>. The water from the tsunami made all the sidewalks and stairs too slippery to walk on, but you tried anyway, slipped, and broke a couple bones.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine trying to get back up on the slippery ground. You've already broken a few bones, but you slip again, breaking a few more.
data.reading_mnemonic: As you struggle on the <kanji>slippery</kanji> ground you hear a loud yowling sound. You turn and see a bunch of stray <reading>cats</reading> (<ja>かつ</ja>) slipping and sliding too. They're coming right for you, uh oh!
data.reading_hint: Picture the cats trying to walk on the slippery ground.
