Their legs keep spreading, so they try to jump, but that makes the slipping worse, and they go sliding forward and topple over their fluffy buns and onto your broken body. Now the cats are all perching on top of you and your broken bones as they try to avoid the slippery ground. It would be nice if they didn't have their claws out.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> crashes into the <radical>sun</radical> (breaking it in half) and creating a different <radical>wing</radical> of the tsunami all together. This wing crashes down and creates a <kanji>lagoon</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: The lagoon is beautiful! The water is hot (from hitting the sun) but it isn't so bright that you'll get a sunburn.
data.reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>lagoon</kanji> was created on purpose by a really angry dude and his <reading>cata</reading>pult (<ja>かた</ja>). He wanted a nice place to lounge that's tropical, but not too bright. So he came up with a plan: use a giant catapult to send a tsunami into the sun!
data.reading_hint: Now picture it all in slow motion. The catapult tosses the tsunami into the air, it smashes the sun, breaks off into a wing of nice, hot water, and finally splashes back to the earth into a beautiful, secluded lagoon.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You take a <radical>turkey</radical> and try to <radical>boil</radical> it but you <kanji>char</kanji> it instead. That's what happens when you throw meat into a pot on high with no water in there.
data.meaning_hint: You should know better than to try to boil something without water! Now what are you going to do with this raw, but charred turkey?!
data.reading_mnemonic: You're staring sadly at the <kanji>char</kanji>red turkey when you suddenly sense the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (<ja>しょう</ja>) looming behind you. You were supposed to be cooking this turkey for him and now he looks really, really mad.
data.reading_hint: The Shougun reaches down and bites a charred hunk off the turkey. He yells and spits it out. Why did he do that?! You have no idea but it looked nasty.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>bamboo</radical> can be whittled into an <kanji>example</kanji> of anything. See, here's a <radical>car</radical>. Here's a <radical>snake</radical>. I can make so many examples just with bamboo.
data.meaning_hint: It's amazing how fast this guy can whittle!
data.reading_mnemonic: One last <kanji>example</kanji> for you. Now I'm going to take this bamboo and whittle it into an example of <reading>Han</reading> (<ja>はん</ja>) Solo!
data.reading_hint: Han Solo's bamboo example comes to life and runs off.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Take this <radical>thread</radical> and look at this <radical>part</radical>. Now look at this part! Now look at this part. You don't know where to look! Haha, I have <kanji>distract</kanji>ed you!
data.meaning_hint: You don't know what part of the thread to look at. What a distraction.
data.reading_mnemonic: Despite how distracted you are, that was indeed a lot of <reading>fun</reading> (<ja>ふん</ja>).
data.reading_hint: Imagine yourself really enjoying looking at parts of the thread. You don't know why it's so fun, but being derpy is exciting, I guess.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Thread</radical> and <radical>vines</radical> alone are too weak to hold anything up. You need to <kanji>twist</kanji> them together to make them strong.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine twisting some threads and vines together. Feel them and twist the two tighter together.
data.reading_mnemonic: As you <kanji>twist</kanji> the thread and vines together, suddenly you feel a lump. You look down and see a <reading>cu</reading>cumber (<ja>きゅう</ja>) twisted into it.
data.reading_hint: It turns out those vines you were twisting were cucumber vines! Yum!

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you take a <radical>thread</radical> and wrap up a bunch of it, so much it becomes a <radical>hill</radical> of thread, you're going to have a lot of thread. You can wrap some of that thread around other thread to create a much thicker thread. This thread is a <kanji>cable</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine yourself twisting this hill of thread up to make thicker cables. They're strong!
data.reading_mnemonic: You use this <kanji>cable</kanji> to swing down from a building but you need to do i<reading>t soon</reading> (<ja>つな</ja>)! You're being chased by some bad guys and they've almost caught you, so if you're gonna swing to safety with this cable, you need to do it soon.
data.reading_hint: Gotta do it soon. Imagine swinging from this cable and feeling the wind in your hair.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You have a <radical>thread</radical> <radical>hill</radical>, but the hill is a bit weird looking (take a look at the hill radical in this kanji). It's not any normal hill, it's a weird lumpy hill that isn't quite right. That's because it is a thread hill of <kanji>netting</kanji>, and parts of the nets have caught things, like fish and cats, so there's weird abnormal lumps in them.
data.meaning_hint: You'll need to differentiate this from <ja>綱</ja>, which uses the same radicals (though <ja>綱</ja> has a real hill radical). Just remember that the weird "hill" has stuff caught in it because it is <kanji>netting</kanji>.
data.reading_mnemonic: There's so much <kanji>netting</kanji> that it's out of control. You decide to take your lawn mower to <reading>mow</reading> (<ja>もう</ja>) it all down.
data.reading_hint: When you do this, it destroys your lawn mower, because who thought it was a good idea to use a lawn mower on netting? Your dumb idea. C'mon!

data.meaning_mnemonic: If the <radical>moon</radical> is <radical>dry</radical>, it's good for your <kanji>liver</kanji>! Haha, get it? Because there's no moonshine to ruin your liver. Don't drink, kids.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine holding an empty bottle up to the moon and seeing it's completely dry. You pat your belly above where your liver is and say, "I guess you're safe tonight, liver."
data.reading_mnemonic: As you pat your <kanji>liver</kanji> suddenly a strange feeling bubbles up and the ghost of Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (<ja>かん</ja>) comes out! Right out of your liver.
data.reading_hint: Genghis Khan glares down at you, "You inherited my liver, and that means no moonshine for you. Protect your liver and don't drink, like me, Genghis Khan."

data.meaning_mnemonic: There are <radical>flowers</radical> and <radical>hills</radical> in your front <kanji>lawn</kanji>. Your lawn is pretty big and it is covered with both flowers and hills. It’s very pretty.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine walking through your lawn and smelling all the flowers as you travel over the rolling hills. What a delightful lawn this is.
data.reading_mnemonic: You are the proud owner of a <reading>Shiba</reading> (<ja>しば</ja>) Inu, y’know, the Japanese dog? Well, this Shiba Inu of yours loves to run around in your <kanji>lawn</kanji> and through the flowers and over the hills. This is the perfect lawn for your Shiba.
data.reading_hint: Look at your little Shiba running through the lawn all happy and elated. Hear him barking as he zooms up and down each hill.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Flowers</radical> find their <radical>death</radical> in a <radical>river</radical> out in the <kanji>wild</kanji>. Flowers live on water, but this river drowns the flowers to death. The wild is a dangerous place.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine yourself out in the wild wilderness as you hear the flowers screaming until death takes them. The river is raging, there’s nothing you can do to help the flowers. The wild has claimed them.
data.reading_mnemonic: <reading>Ah</reading> (<ja>あ</ja>), the flowers in the <kanji>wild</kanji> have been claimed <reading>à la</reading> (<ja>あら</ja>) the great flood. Ah, you don’t think so? Well I do.
data.reading_hint: Imagine this scene again, only imagine it like the wild flowers are experiencing their own great flood. Ah, those flowers are drowning to death à la everything that died in the Biblical flood.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You keep your <radical>substitute</radical> <radical>clothes</radical> in a <kanji>sack</kanji>. The clothes in the sack are just substitute clothes, so they only come out in emergencies.
data.meaning_hint: Look at this sack of substitute clothes. Imagine it filled with all the clothes you hardly ever wear. What kind of clothes would be inside this sack?
data.reading_mnemonic: You need your substitute clothes so you take out your substitute clothes <kanji>sack</kanji>. You open it up to grab your substitute clothes, only to find out that there is a ton of salmon roe inside your sack. Oh man, you forgot all about putting that in there. You yell: <reading>F**K ROE</reading> (<ja>ふくろ</ja>) because that roe destroyed all your clothes and made it nasty.
data.reading_hint: Imagine how nasty it is in there. Also imagine how smelly it is. Feel angry about putting roe in your sack. Why would you even do that? Why would the roe do this to you, as well.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Who will <radical>say</radical> <radical>turkey</radical>? Who? <kanji>WHO</kanji>???
data.meaning_hint: Say "who" over and over again, demanding someone says "turkey," for some reason.
data.reading_mnemonic: Then, someone says turkey. "<kanji>Who</kanji> said turkey? You? How <reading>dare</reading> (<ja>だれ</ja>) you."
data.reading_hint: You're so mad at that person even though you demanded someone say turkey.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>king</radical>'s <radical>hat</radical>, not to mention the <radical>hair</radical> stuck to said hat, is incredibly <kanji>rare</kanji>. If you have your hands on either of these things, you'll be a rich duck.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine yourself holding a king's hat covered in his hair. Who will you sell it to? This is such a rare item!
data.reading_mnemonic: Then you look closer at the hat. It's about to get even <kanji>rare</kanji>r. Attached to the hair is the king's <reading>chin</reading> (<ja>ちん</ja>).
data.reading_hint: Not sure how it got there, but you'll make a pretty penny from this. The king only had one chin, so that's about as <kanji>rare</kanji> as they come.

data.meaning_mnemonic: When a <radical>yakuza</radical> takes a <radical>knife</radical> to <radical>clothes</radical>, it will of course cause a <kanji>split</kanji> or <kanji>tear</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: It doesn't matter if it's a yakuza member or not. Any knife will cause a split or tear in clothes.
data.reading_mnemonic: "I want to <kanji>split</kanji> and <kanji>tear</kanji> that." You agree, so you say <reading>Let's</reading> (<ja>れつ</ja>) do it.
data.reading_hint: Think of a thing you want to tear with your yakuza buddy. You're into it, so you agree and say "Ret's do it!"

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Imperial</radical> <radical>clothes</radical> allow you to perform an ancient <kanji>attack</kanji> that cannot be repelled.
data.meaning_hint: IMPERIAL ATTACK, GO! Imagine what this imperial attack might look like and imagine yourself in some swanky imperial clothes while you perform it.
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>attack</kanji>'s power is concentrated in the <reading>shoe</reading>s (<ja>しゅう</ja>) in this imperial outfit. You attack with your feet, kicking the enemy with your old, fancy shoes.
data.reading_hint: Picture the shoes as you attack, they glow—full of attack power! These +4 attack shoes are really special.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>construction</radical> project made from <radical>shellfish</radical> will act as a <kanji>tribute</kanji> to the Crabigator.
data.meaning_hint: The Crabigator is a sea creature (maybe?), so making a tribute from shellfish makes some sense.
data.reading_mnemonic: This great <kanji>tribute</kanji> is being commissioned by Emperor <ja><reading>こう</reading>いち</ja>.
data.reading_hint:
In his power, <ja>こういち</ja> has made a new religion around the Crabigator, to put the fear of kanji learning into his subjects.

Hint: When you see <ja>工</ja> in a kanji it will often take the <ja>こう</ja> reading.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You have to <radical>run</radical>, put your <radical>ear</radical> on the <radical>stool</radical>, then run back. That's the <kanji>gist</kanji> of this game.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine yourself asking how this game works, then getting the above response.
data.reading_mnemonic: You got the <kanji>gist</kanji>, but now there's the matter of this big <reading>chu</reading>te (<ja>しゅ</ja>). No one told you how to use it, and you've got the gist of how chutes work, but what does it have to do with this running, ear-touching, stool game?!
data.reading_hint: As you watch, you get more of a gist of what's going on, but not all the way. Some people are throwing the stool down the chute, some people are sliding down it on their ears... I mean, you'll get the gist eventually. Probably.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>foot</radical> on a <radical>giant</radical> is a pretty long <kanji>distance</kanji> for a normal person to walk. Giants have big feet and can travel large <kanji>distance</kanji>s very quickly.
data.meaning_hint: Compare the distance you can travel with one step compared to a giant. It's a considerable difference in distance.
data.reading_mnemonic: Going to Little <reading>Kyo</reading>to (<ja>きょ</ja>) is a short <kanji>distance</kanji> for a giant but a long <kanji>distance</kanji> for you.
data.reading_hint: Imagine walking the distance between where you are and the (possibly made up) Little Kyoto. Think about the distance.

data.meaning_mnemonic: People had to ride their <radical>bamboo</radical> <radical>plow</radical>s <radical>long ago</radical> to <kanji>enroll</kanji> in things. There were no cars yet, so they would hitch a cow to their bamboo plow, and dig their way to the government office or school to enroll.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the little hut that passed for school long ago. All of the bamboo plows are parked around it, as the people enroll themselves and their kids up for classes.
data.reading_mnemonic: If you <kanji>enroll</kanji> in something new people will find you very <reading>sexy</reading> (<ja>せき</ja>). This was true long ago too. There's nothing sexier than trying to improve yourself.
data.reading_hint: Picture a line of people enrolling for new classes, sports, citizenship, etc. The moment they've enrolled they poof into the perfect, sexy person (in your eyes).

data.meaning_mnemonic: If the <radical>rain</radical> touches your <radical>foot</radical> and gives it a little rain <radical>kiss</radical>, you know that part of your foot is <kanji>expose</kanji>d to the elements. You can also see some <kanji>dew</kanji> forming on your exposed foot. So that's what rain kisses are!
data.meaning_hint: Ugh, you shouldn't have bought these open toed shoes, at least not during rainy season!
data.reading_mnemonic: You run along the <reading>ro</reading>ad (<ja>ろ</ja>), trying to get out of the rain, but the road keeps going and going, with walls on both sides.
data.reading_hint: You wonder how long this road will go. With exposed toes, your feet are going to get all wet with dew if you can't get off this blasted road.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>cow</radical> in the <radical>winter</radical> doesn't like to leave the barn to go to the <kanji>pasture</kanji>. It has to, though, because a cow's gotta eat.
data.meaning_hint: It's cold outside (it's winter after all). Imagine you having to herd all the cows out to pasture even though they don't want to leave the warm barn.
data.reading_mnemonic: <ja>ぼく</ja> is one of the common ways to say "I" in Japanese (which you should remember!). In this case, you're a boy... a cowboy, and you say, "<ja><reading>ぼく</reading></ja> will take these cows out to pasture!"
data.reading_hint: Actually say that phrase out loud while thinking about bringing your cows to pasture.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You take out a <radical>flag</radical>, lay a <radical>towel</radical> below it, and use your <radical>knife</radical> to carve the pattern through them both. Voila! This is exactly how old <kanji>printing</kanji> presses used to work.
data.meaning_hint: The old way of printing involved taking the pattern you want (the flag) pressing it against the place you want to print it (the towel) and then just slicing that sucker on there (with the knife).
data.reading_mnemonic: As you're working on <kanji>printing</kanji> your own flag onto this towel you look over and see someone else just <reading>sat</reading> (<ja>さつ</ja>) down on theirs. "Excuse me, where is your knife?" you ask. "Oh, this way is slower, but it's less work. I'm just pressing them together with my bum."
data.reading_hint: I guess if you wanted to be slow you could do your printing if you sat down on it too...

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>good</radical> <radical>moon</radical> is a <kanji>bright</kanji> moon. Not just in terms of light, but in mood as well. Like, gee wiz, what a bright, happy moon.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the good, good bright moon. Shining and shimmering and smiling down at us on Earth.
data.reading_mnemonic: It's so <kanji>bright</kanji> that you can see all the <reading>roe</reading> (<ja>ろう</ja>) in the sea glowing and reflecting the light like stars. And the tiny baby fishies inside the roe are smiling brightly back up at the moon!
data.reading_hint: Picture this scene like it's a Disney cartoon. The good moon is smiling brightly down at the roe which are smiling right back. They might even start singing a song!

data.meaning_mnemonic: A small <radical>tsunami</radical> comes in the <radical>morning</radical> with the <radical>moon</radical>. That just means the ocean gets bigger when the moon's out, and that my friends is simply the <kanji>tide</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: The moon does affect the tides a bit, so you can imagine the tsunami as the water getting bigger whenever the moon is out. That's just the tide.
data.reading_mnemonic: You go check out the <kanji>tide</kanji>. The water is coming in a little stronger, and something washes up on the shore. It's a body! You roll the body over and it is Mrs. <kanji>Chou</kanji> (<ja>ちょう</ja>)!
data.reading_hint: She wakes up and says, "If only you came at low tide then I would never have been saved!" She jumps up and runs off, yelling something about destroying the world.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>root</radical> of a <radical>stamp</radical> is to get an <kanji>instant</kanji> picture down. Back in the olden days, people had to make seals and draw out things by hand, so stamps came about so you can—BAM—just stamp it and have what you want in an instant.
data.meaning_hint: Lots of things have roots from wanting to have something in an instant. Just think about instant ramen. The root of that was to get ramen real, real fast. Similar to stamps, ya know?
data.reading_mnemonic: Think about the thing you want to make <kanji>instant</kanji>. I'd want instant <reading>sock</reading>s (<ja>そく</ja>)! Don't waste time searching for a matching pair or pulling them on. Just take out a pair of instant socks, add water, and the socks are already on your feet. In an instant!
data.reading_hint: Imagine using instant socks. How do they feel? Soggy, but hey, it was fast!

data.meaning_mnemonic:
Look at the <radical>dirt</radical> on the <radical>ground</radical> at <radical>dawn</radical> and you'll be able to see all the <kanji>hedge</kanji>s growing in the area really well. At any other time of day, hedges tend to blend into their surroundings. But at dawn, the shadows the sun makes really helps them stand out.

This hedge also works as a <kanji>fence</kanji>. It borders an area and you can't walk through it. A natural fence!
data.meaning_hint: Picture yourself leaning over a balcony at dawn, looking at all the hedges appear and their shadows stretch over the ground.
data.reading_mnemonic: You're looking intently at one particular <kanji>hedge</kanji> because yesterday you dropped your <reading>ca</reading>r <reading>key</reading>s (<ja>かき</ja>) behind it. Now that you know where the hedge is you're going to need to search it to find your car keys.
data.reading_hint: Imagine rooting around under some hedges, desperately trying to find your car keys. Hedges are prickly and there's spiders in here! If only you didn't need a car in the first place!

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>drunkard</radical> goes down a <radical>slide</radical>, hits the <radical>ground</radical> and bumps into a <radical>woman</radical>. Who is that woman? It's none other than her <kanji>majesty</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: The problem is that you don't want to run into her majesty. That's a grave offense. Feel the fear that you're going to get your head lopped off from running into her.
data.reading_mnemonic: After you run into her <kanji>majesty</kanji>, her guardian <reading>ea</reading>gle (<ja>い</ja>) swoops on you and pulls you off of her.
data.reading_hint: Then it starts pecking at your eyes. Imagine fighting off an eagle trying to get at you.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You need to make a <radical>measurement</radical> of an area so you take two clumps of <radical>dirt</radical> to <kanji>seal in</kanji> each side of your measuring tape, so it stays on the ground. This is the way people used to seal things back in the day, back when we didn't have fancy things like tape and glue.
data.meaning_hint: Picture sealing other things with dirt. Like the bricks in your wall. Or the hole in your floor. Dirt can seal in anything.
data.reading_mnemonic:
You can also <kanji>seal</kanji> <reading>foo</reading>d (<ja>ふう</ja>) in dirt to make it last longer. That's how jerky came about, you know. Seal some meat underground and in a few months you'll have some tasty dried meats to chew.

By the way, this has another reading you should probably know. It’s <ja>ほう</ja>. Most sealing is done in the <reading>ho</reading>me (<ja>ほう</ja>), you know? So just think about eating food in your own home!
data.reading_hint: Dig up your sealed food and eat it in the comfort of your own home. Mm, delicious!

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>bamboo</radical> stalk looks the <radical>same</radical> as a big ol' <kanji>cylinder</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Compare the two things in your mind and make them the same.
data.reading_mnemonic: Picture a <kanji>cylinder</kanji> shaped <ja><reading>とう</reading>きょう</ja>. All the buildings are cylinders. The city itself is cylinder shaped too. Even... gasp! The people of <ja>とうきょう</ja>!
data.reading_hint: <ja>とうきょう</ja> is a really weird city now that they passed the cylinder law. Imagine it so deeply that it weirds you out.

data.meaning_mnemonic: An <radical>axe</radical> is sticking in the <radical>ground</radical> on top of a <radical>mountain</radical>. It's sticking into the very <kanji>peak</kanji>. Because why would you bother to stick your axe anywhere else on the mountain to prove you climbed it?
data.meaning_hint: Picture that axe, jammed into the mountain's <kanji>peak</kanji>. The person who did that must have been really cool to get all the way up there.
data.reading_mnemonic: You can't help but <reading>gawk</reading> (<ja>がく</ja>) at the <kanji>peak</kanji>. Somehow it looks even higher now.
data.reading_hint: Go ahead, imagine this peak with an axe in it and actually gawk a bit at how far you have to go to get that high.

data.meaning_mnemonic: We put a <radical>flag</radical> to remember where we tried to use a <radical>jackhammer</radical> to <radical>measure</radical> your friend's <radical>heart</radical>. Granted, it was a terrible idea, but hopefully that flag of remembrance is some kind of <kanji>consolation</kanji>?
data.meaning_hint: Obviously it's not good enough consolation. Be furious about this.
data.reading_mnemonic: Even though you weren't happy with the flag, you were even more frustrated to watch an <reading>ea</reading>gle swoop down and grab the flag and fly away with it.
data.reading_hint: Now you have absolutely nothing. Not even a <kanji>consolation</kanji> flag.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>badger</radical>, at the <radical>root</radical> of its <radical>heart</radical>, is a <kanji>courteous</kanji> creature.
data.meaning_hint: They may seem gruff and rude at first, but they'll still let you in their home in the middle of winter unannounced and offer you tea, a warm fire, and a place to sleep.
data.reading_mnemonic: Badgers are especially <kanji>courteous</kanji> to <reading>con</reading>dors (<ja>こん</ja>). Condors live in the trees while badgers live in burrows under those trees. When humans tear down the condor's homes, the badgers who live below them always let them stay over until they get back on their feet.
data.reading_hint: Picture a courteous badger taking care of an injured, and now homeless, condor. It's fluffing the condor's pillows, bringing it soup, and patting it on the shoulder saying, "There, there."

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>loiter</radical>ing <radical>mountain</radical> <radical>king</radical> who hangs around during <radical>winter</radical> to provide an indication (this kanji uses the "indication" kanji as its top 2/3rds) of things to come now looks into your <radical>heart</radical>, and only sees bad things. So, he <kanji>chastise</kanji>s you about it.
data.meaning_hint: "What's in your heart is no good," he chastises you.
data.reading_mnemonic: Why is he chastising you, really, though? He foretold Mrs. Chou coming back in a previous mnemonic, but you saved Mrs. Chou on the beach (once again, in a previous mnemonic), so you could have prevented her second coming. He is <kanji>chastis</kanji>ing you for saving Mrs. <reading>Chou</reading> (<ja>ちょう</ja>).
data.reading_hint: In the <ja>潮</ja> kanji you saved Mrs. Chou from dying, so he is chastising you for it.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Below the <radical>canopy</radical> of <radical>tree</radical>s is a <radical>hand</radical>. The hand is just there to <kanji>chafe</kanji> against the trees.
data.meaning_hint: There's a hand just chafing against some trees. That's... interesting.
data.reading_mnemonic: As the hand <kanji>chafe</kanji>s on the trees, it says <reading>ma</reading>ma (<ja>ま</ja>), mama.
data.reading_hint: This is the hand of a child looking for its mama. And, it chafes against trees to try and find the warm, soft touch of its mama. Instead, it only finds rough bark, so it continues its chafing.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You hold the <radical>roof</radical> of the <radical>festival</radical> up with your <radical>fingers</radical> but it <kanji>grate</kanji>s on them. The roof is heavy, and you have to walk to keep up, so the roof is grating on them really, really badly.
data.meaning_hint: Have you ever been to a Japanese festival? There's always one of those portable shrines that are basically just roofs people hold up. That's what you're trying to hold with your fingers as the whole thing grates on them.
data.reading_mnemonic: Just when you thought the <kanji>grat</kanji>ing couldn't get worse, someone <reading>sat</reading> (<ja>さつ</ja>) down on the roof! AHG! It hurts!
data.reading_hint: Picture a very large person that decided to sat down right on top of the roof you've been carrying through the festival. The weight makes the grating so much worse, you can feel the skin coming off of your fingers.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Put your <radical>fingers</radical> in somebody's <radical>business</radical> by <kanji>slap</kanji>ping them! This method also works if someone is getting too involved in your business. Slaps are basically your way of doing business with your fingers.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine giving someone a good, hard slap in the face. You're all up in their business now.
data.reading_mnemonic: <ja>ぼく</ja> is one way to say "I" in Japanese, usually used by dudes. But you're going to use it now when you <kanji>slap</kanji> this guy. Who's in everybody's business, slapping them? <radical><ja>ぼく</ja></radical>.
data.reading_hint: Say that out loud, using <ja>ぼく</ja>. You're the boss, the boss of slap business.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>simultaneous</radical> radical and the <kanji>simultaneous</kanji> kanji are the same!
data.meaning_hint: Know your radicals, yo!
data.reading_mnemonic: What <kanji>simultaneously</kanji> protects and kills? Your holy blue <reading>sa</reading>ber (<ja>せい</ja>).
data.reading_hint: It's also simultaneously here and there at the same time. It moves really fast. And simultaneously glowing blue and white. Your saber is a lot of things all at once!

data.meaning_mnemonic: Take your <radical>spoon</radical> to the <radical>sun</radical> to be able to take a bite. It's <kanji>delicious</kanji>, you hear. That's the <kanji>point</kanji> of the spoon.
data.meaning_hint: Taste that delicious sun. It doesn't even burn!
data.reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>delicious</kanji> taste is... familiar somehow. You take a few more bites and then scream. It tastes like <reading>shee</reading>p (<ja>し</ja>)!
data.reading_hint: You had your eyes closed because the sun is so bright. When you open them you realize the delicious sun you were eating is really just a giant, really bright, cooked sheep. You should probably point this out to NASA or something.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You've been ordered to <radical>spear</radical> this <radical>tree</radical> but you decide to be really <kanji>gentle</kanji> instead.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine gently poking the tree with your spear. You glance around nervously, hoping no one notices how easy on it you're being.
data.reading_mnemonic: You're being really <kanji>gentle</kanji> to the tree when a <reading>jewel</reading> (<ja>じゅう</ja>) falls out of its branches and hits you on the head.
data.reading_hint: The jewel has a little note on it, "Thank you for being gentle." Did... did the tree just reward you for being gentle?!

data.meaning_mnemonic: If a <radical>tsunami</radical> hits a <radical>pirate</radical> they are going to <kanji>sink</kanji> no matter how good of a pirate captain they are.
data.meaning_hint: Tsunamis are big. Pirates are small. Simple as that.
data.reading_mnemonic: As the tsunami comes to <kanji>sink</kanji> the pirate, the pirate holds his <reading>chin</reading> (<ja>ちん</ja>) up high. He will die with dignity.
data.reading_hint: Imagine this dignified chin-holding-up-high pirate. Nod your head, because you know he got what he deserves.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> can't resist the <radical>call</radical> of a <kanji>bog</kanji>. Whenever a tsunami is headed toward land, a bog will always call out to it, "Hey tsunami, don't you want to hit me with your water? Come this way~"
data.meaning_hint: Close your eyes and hear the bog's temping call.
data.reading_mnemonic: As you listen to the <kanji>bog</kanji>'s call you realize it looks just like the <reading>Numa</reading> (<ja>ぬま</ja>) Numa guy in your mind. You open your eyes and it's just a bog. You close your eyes, and there he is. The Numa Numa guy.
data.reading_hint: So that's what happened to him! If you're a youngun, just do a little Google and you'll be pretty pleased, I'm sure.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The sound of <radical>spring</radical> <radical>water</radical> always puts you at <kanji>peace</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Everything from winter is melting and trickling and thawing. All the dripping sounds fill you with a peace you can barely describe.
data.reading_mnemonic: You want to feel this <kanji>peace</kanji> all the time, not just in spring, so you dip your <reading>tie</reading> (<ja>たい</ja>) in the spring water. Now your tie is making the peaceful dripping sounds you love.
data.reading_hint: Imagine carefully dipping all of your ties in the peaceful spring waters and hearing that sweet sound you love at all times.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Hit by a <radical>tsunami</radical> the <radical>drunkard</radical> is propelled down a <radical>slide</radical> where he hits the <radical>ground</radical> which is covered in <radical>fire</radical>. He is immediately <kanji>destroy</kanji>ed.
data.meaning_hint: Even if he wasn't saved by the slide (to avoid the tsunami) he would be in trouble. Seems like the world just wanted to <kanji>destroy</kanji> this drunkard.
data.reading_mnemonic: One could say this drunkard <reading>met</reading> (<ja>めつ</ja>) his fate.
data.reading_hint: Strangely, he just came from a <reading>Mets</reading> (<ja>めつ</ja>) game, so maybe that's why he had such bad luck.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A (fresh water) <radical>tsunami</radical>. Some <radical>horns</radical>. The <radical>ground</radical>. A bunch of <radical>poop</radical>. Combine these together and let them decompose a while. You'll have yourself some very <kanji>nourishing</kanji> soil.
data.meaning_hint: The stuff in horns is great for fertilizer. So is poop. So is water (as long as it's fresh water). So nourishing!
data.reading_mnemonic: This is the kind of <kanji>nourishing</kanji> soil that <reading>Je</reading>sus (<ja>じ</ja>) would make if he was into making soil, probably.
data.reading_hint: Imagine him making soil made out of those things. Jesus approves of this nourishing soil.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>fire</radical> <radical>door</radical> is a door that leads to something full of fire. That thing is a <kanji>furnace</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Open the fire door and feel the heat of the <kanji>furnace</kanji>. Hot!
data.reading_mnemonic: You're using the <kanji>furnace</kanji> to melt tar to put on the <reading>ro</reading>ad (<ja>ろ</ja>).
data.reading_hint: Smell the tar baking from the furnace. Feel the heat from the furnace. Fix the road, while you're at it.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Two <radical>king</radical>s are here right <radical>now</radical>! We need to entertain them otherwise who knows what they'll do. Get out the <kanji>harp</kanji>, or something.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine yourself playing a harp even though you probably don't know how to. Entertain these kings to the best of your ability, right now. That's why you're doing it and not someone who knows what they're doing. They want it now.
data.reading_mnemonic: You don't even know how to do the <ja><reading>事</reading></ja> (<ja>こと</ja>, action) of playing the harp, yet you're doing it.
data.reading_hint: Just say to yourself: "This <ja>事</ja> I don't understand. I don't understand this <ja>事</ja> at all omg what am I going to do?"

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>measurement</radical> radical and the <kanji>measurement</kanji> kanji are exactly the same.
data.meaning_hint: If you make sure to know the radicals, you'll also make sure to know the kanji too, automagically.
data.reading_mnemonic: You want to <kanji>measure</kanji> something... something that will make you famous. You decide you'll measure the biggest mass in our solar system. We're talking about the <reading>sun</reading> (<ja>すん</ja>).
data.reading_hint: Imagine yourself deciding to do this. First step is to get a ridiculously long measuring tape. Then, you go up to the <reading>sun</reading> and start measuring. You immediately start getting burned. Feel the pain of the heat from the <reading>sun</reading>. Think about how this really probably wasn't a good idea. You still go forward, though, doing your best to <kanji>measure</kanji> the sun. Ouch, ouch, ouch.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>dragon</radical> radical is the same as this kanji, which is <kanji>dragon</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Not to <kanji>dragon</kanji> with it, but make sure you know your radicals so you know your kanji!
data.reading_mnemonic: Imagine a <kanji>dragon</kanji>. You are talking to it, which is already pretty strange, but as you're talking, he turns into the Street Fighter character <reading>Ryuu</reading> (<ja>りゅう</ja>).
data.reading_hint: Then imagine after his transformation he attacks you using his Street Fighter moves. "Hadouken!"

data.meaning_mnemonic: There's a <radical>thread</radical> tying <radical>wolverine</radical> to a <radical>pig</radical>, balancing them over the <kanji>edge</kanji> of a cliff together.
data.meaning_hint: Picture wolverine and a pig hanging precariously over the edge. One move the wrong way and they'll both go toppling over.
data.reading_mnemonic: Suddenly, the pig squeals, pulls the thread, and sends them both over the <kanji>edge</kanji>. Straight to their <reading>en</reading>d (<ja>えん</ja>).
data.reading_hint: If you fall off the edge it'll be your end too. Always be safe and never get too close to any edges!

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>feather</radical> is on a <radical>rice paddy</radical>, and they are attached <radical>together</radical>. You put a feather on a rice paddy to create a giant airplane. Flawed, sure. But, this rice paddy + feather is going to be one <kanji>wing</kanji> of your amazing aircraft.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine a <kanji>wing</kanji> that is made of a rice paddy and a feather put together. Doesn't make sense, looks ugly, and probably will not fly. Imagine it anyways. It is your wing.
data.reading_mnemonic: To make the feather and rice paddy stick together you need some kind of sticking agent. This time we find the original bird that the feather came from and grab its eggs. We break the eggs open and use the <reading>yolk</reading> (<ja>よく</ja>). It's pretty sticky, but still probably not aircraft safe.
data.reading_hint: Imagine using the yolks to stick everything together. It's all over your hands, and things are pretty nasty.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>good luck</radical> radical and the <kanji>good luck</kanji> kanji are the same!
data.meaning_hint: Know your radicals, yo!
data.reading_mnemonic: For <kanji>good luck</kanji>, you keep special <reading>kits</reading> (<ja>きつ</ja>) in your <reading>kitch</reading>en (<ja>きち</ja>). These kitchen kits contain good luck charms.
data.reading_hint: Your good luck kitchen kits have charms that say things like, "good food," "good company," and "good luck not cutting off your fingers with kitchen knives."

data.meaning_mnemonic: The radical <radical>blade</radical> and the kanji <kanji>blade</kanji> are exactly the same.
data.meaning_hint: Please, just know your radicals. Please!
data.reading_mnemonic: When you stab your <kanji>blade</kanji> into an enemy you shout "<reading>Ha</reading> (<ja>は</ja>)!" It's just the normal "thrusting with blade" sound.
data.reading_hint: Ha, HA, HaaAA! Those are the blade sounds we all know and love.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If someone puts a <radical>blade</radical> to your <radical>heart</radical>, you're going to have a rough time. They leave it there, for a long long time. They aren't going to cut you, but you can't move. You have to <kanji>endure</kanji> the pain and uncomfortableness of the situation.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine your chest and ribs are open. There's a blade on your heart. Now try not to move, or your heart will be cut!
data.reading_mnemonic: This is all a part of your <reading>nin</reading>ja (<ja>にん</ja>) training. You must learn to stay totally still, without breathing. This is how they train you. If you can <kanji>endure</kanji> this you can endure anything, plus you can stay really still, which is good for ninjas.
data.reading_hint: Just think about how much you want to become a ninja. You'll do anything, even endure this.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>tree</radical> has an <radical>omen</radical> growing from it, one single <kanji>peach</kanji> that is the size of a house. Inside is a child who will save the village from demons.
data.meaning_hint: Of course, this tree omen of a <kanji>peach</kanji> refers to momotaro, the little boy who was born from a peach (you should look it up if you don't know this children's story).
data.reading_mnemonic: If <reading>momo</reading>taro (<ja>もも</ja>) wasn't enough, think about the <kanji>peach</kanji> growing larger and larger. You want it to grow bigger, so you yell at it: "<reading>MO</reading>RE! <reading>MO</reading>RE!" (<ja>もも</ja>).
data.reading_hint: It grows bigger everytime you say "MORE MORE" twice. If you say it just once, it stays the same.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>spicy</radical> radical and <kanji>spicy</kanji> kanji are exactly the same! Hot!
data.reading_mnemonic: Imagine eating this <kanji>spicy</kanji> food, becoming blinded by the spicy heat, and knocking your <reading>shin</reading> (<ja>しん</ja>) on something while you bumble around.
data.reading_hint: It's bleeding profusely and really hurts a lot. Plus your mouth is still burning from that spicy food you ate. It's pure agony.

data.meaning_mnemonic: I <radical>say</radical>, which weighs more: a kilogram of <radical>scooter</radical>s or a kilogram of <radical>rice</radical>? This is a <kanji>riddle</kanji>!
data.meaning_hint: Think carefully and see if you can come up with the answer to my riddle before you read on.
data.reading_mnemonic: Did you figure out the answer to this <kanji>riddle</kanji>? Say your answer aloud to the screen right now.... <reading>not so</reading> (<ja>なぞ</ja>)! You're wrong.
data.reading_hint: Did you say the answer to the riddle is that they're both a kilogram? Not so! A scooter is heavier than some rice! And don't you email me saying that's not so! It's my riddle, I can make the answer whatever I want. That's the law of riddles!

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> of the <radical>temple</radical> isn't a monk like you'd expect. It's a <kanji>samurai</kanji>, who protects the monks in return for prayers that keep him safe.
data.meaning_hint: You walk up to a temple and you're surprised to find that there's a samurai guarding it. Talk to him for a while so he can tell you why he has been doing this job. He's quite a nice guy, actually.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is <reading>samurai</reading>, which should be easy enough to remember.
data.reading_hint: If you know the meaning you know the reading as well! That doesn't happen too often with kanji, so consider yourself lucky!

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> of a <radical>big</radical> <radical>rice paddy</radical> is standing in the middle of said rice paddy with an <radical>umbrella</radical>. Who is this wacky leader? Why, it is <kanji>I</kanji>. It is <kanji>me</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine that this leader is you. Be rough about it, because <ja>俺</ja> is the "rougher" version of "I." You should only use it in casual situations or if you're a badass.
data.reading_mnemonic: Why am <kanji>I</kanji> standing in the middle of this rice paddy with an umbrella? I'm digging for <reading>ore</reading> (<ja>おれ</ja>).
data.reading_hint: More accurately, I'm standing here with an umbrella so I don't get wet. My minions are doing the ore digging, but I am watching to make sure they don't slack off.

data.meaning_mnemonic: From my <radical>mouth</radical> I have told you <radical>seven</radical> times not to do that. Now I have to <kanji>scold</kanji> you.
data.meaning_hint: SEVEN TIMES! You'd think you'd learn.
data.reading_mnemonic: What were you doing wrong that caused me to <kanji>scold</kanji> you? You were feeding the <ja><reading>鹿</reading></ja> (<ja>しか</ja>). If you feed them they'll never be able to feed themselves!
data.reading_hint: Imagine yourself feeding the deer, then getting scolded (or you doing the scolding to someone else feeding the deer, whichever works best).

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>woman</radical> loves her <radical>catapult</radical> for some good ol' fashioned <kanji>recreation</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: You ask the woman what she does for fun... for recreation. She says, she goes out and shoots her catapult.
data.reading_mnemonic: Her favorite thing to shoot at with her catapult for <kanji>recreation</kanji> is <reading>Go</reading>dzilla (<ja>ご</ja>).
data.reading_hint: Get out of here, Godzilla! I'm gonna shoot you.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>ladle</radical> radical and the <kanji>ladle</kanji> kanji are the same!
data.meaning_hint: Know your radicals, yo!
data.reading_mnemonic: You use a <kanji>ladle</kanji> to distribute soup. But as you're ladling you find something odd floating in the soup. It's... a <reading>toe</reading> (<ja>と</ja>)! You scream, dropping the ladle and the toe on the ground.
data.reading_hint: Your mom comes rushing in and smacks you on the head. "Fool!" she says, "This is toe soup, what did you think you'd ladle up?!" Oops.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>slide</radical> to get off this <radical>jet</radical> is a beautiful, brilliant <kanji>vermillion</kanji> color.
data.meaning_hint: Vermillion is like an orange red, which is perfect for visibility purposes.
data.reading_mnemonic: As you jump onto the <kanji>vermillion</kanji> slide, it more of a steep <reading>chu</reading>te (<ja>しゅ</ja>). And... oh... urp... it's making you sick.
data.reading_hint: The vermillion chute spits you out and you spit out your lunch. And it looks vermillion. Uh oh. Hospital. Please.

data.meaning_mnemonic: An <radical>axe</radical> is stuck into the <radical>ground</radical> on a <kanji>hill</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine climbing up the hill. The sun is coming up behind the axe,  silhouetting the whole thing very nicely.
data.reading_mnemonic: You reach the top of the <kanji>hill</kanji> and realize the entire hill is covered in <reading>cu</reading>cumbers (<ja>きゅう</ja>). The axe has a little note on it that says "Cucumber Hill Axe - Please Use."
data.reading_hint: You take the axe out of the hill and cut off some cucumber to eat. Mm mm!

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>grain</radical> you cut off a <radical>tree</radical> with a <radical>knife</radical> is a <kanji>pear</kanji>. I don't know if you've ever seen Asian pears, but they're pretty big and sturdy. You can't just pick them off of the tree, you need the help of a knife. That's why this is a pear, and not an apple or peach or something else.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine standing below a tree full of pears. You take your knife and carefully cut them all down, one by one.
data.reading_mnemonic: As you cut the <kanji>pear</kanji>s down, you can't help but <reading>gnash</reading> (<ja>なし</ja>) your teeth. You want to eat these pears right now. You gnash and grind and wait though, because you want to have them all down before you start the feast.
data.reading_hint: Imagine a beautiful, ripe pear in your mind. Now gnash your teeth. Mmm. You want to eat a pear right now, don't you?

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>leader</radical> of <radical>business</radical>? Ha! That's <kanji>me</kanji>! That's <kanji>I</kanji>!
data.meaning_hint: This version of <kanji>I</kanji> is more boyish. It's a sort of young man/boy way of saying "I," though you'll hear women use it too sometimes (it's a teensy bit tomboyish though).
data.reading_mnemonic: You use the word <kanji>I</kanji> a lot. You say it so much, you just start referring to yourself with the french <reading>beaucoup</reading> (<ja>ぼく</ja>) for a lot. Because you love yourself a lot.
data.reading_hint: I am beaucoup I am. (Is that a pun? Did I do it right?) I dunno. Just say <ja>ぼく</ja> a lot and try to connect all of your approximate knowledges of languages together. Merci <ja>ぼく</ja> from <ja>ぼく</ja>.

data.meaning_mnemonic: In the <radical>cage</radical> there are some <radical>legs</radical>. They are the legs attached to a <kanji>small animal</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: You can only see the legs, though, because a cloth is covering the cage. What kind of small animal is it? Try to look.
data.reading_mnemonic: You look up through the cloth, and see a hairless cat. This <kanji>small animal</kanji> is hairless, but most surprisingly is covered in <reading>hickie</reading>s (<ja>ひき</ja>).
data.reading_hint: Who is giving this cat all those hickies? Pretty gross, if you ask me.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You have <radical>mouth</radical> <radical>vines</radical>, so you <kanji>shout</kanji>! It's hard for you to talk normally, and even harder for people to understand you unless you shout.
data.meaning_hint: You were born with mouth vines (a rare condition where your mouth is always full of vines), so you've been shouting all your life. And yet people still can't hear you. It's very frustrating.
data.reading_mnemonic: You need to <kanji>shout</kanji> so that people can understand you through the mouth vines. You shout, "<ja><reading>きょう</reading>と</ja>!" because you hear there is a temple there for people with your condition.
data.reading_hint: Imagine the word <ja>きょうと</ja> not coming out clearly because of your mouth vines. People can only hear the <ja>きょう</ja> part, so they don't know where you want to go. SHOUT LOUDER! <ja>きょうと！</ja>

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>gold</radical> <radical>pool</radical> is where you're going to go <kanji>fishing</kanji>. Because, if the pool is gold, hopefully the fish are too.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine yourself fishing in a gold pool, catching golden fish. What a great <kanji>fishing</kanji> spot this is.
data.reading_mnemonic: You caught a couple of gold fish. <reading>Two</reading> (<ja>つ</ja>) gold fish, actually!
data.reading_hint: Count your golden fish. They're so nice! They're also worth their weight in gold, because, well, they are gold.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>long</radical> <radical>hair</radical> is your <radical>friend</radical>. It's your <kanji>hair</kanji> and you're so proud of it.
data.meaning_hint: Just feel your hair, it's such a good friend, and you wish it was longer.
data.reading_mnemonic: Who gave you this hair? Probably the great <ja><reading>神</reading></ja> (<ja>かみ</ja>) of hair. You deserve this great hair.
data.reading_hint: Pretend to pray to the great hair <ja>神</ja>. What is his reply? Does he give you more hair?

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>mountain</radical> <radical>wind</radical> coming down from the mountains is very fierce. It is so fierce it's a lot like a <kanji>storm</kanji>. Well, it is a storm, really.
data.meaning_hint: If you think about it makes sense. Those mountain winds that come down from the mountain are cold and windy and nasty. When they mix with warmer air down below, it creates a nasty <kanji>storm</kanji>.
data.reading_mnemonic: A <kanji>storm</kanji> is nothing to scoff at. If you get hit by the storm and get all wet and nasty and electrocuted, you're bound to get <reading>a rash</reading> (<ja>あらし</ja>).
data.reading_hint: The rash comes from being wet and not drying off when you get home. Your skin gets irritated by this moisture.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>bamboo</radical> thing you put on your head to <radical>stand</radical> taller would probably be a hat. A bamboo hat is probably one of those hats you think of when you think of rice farmers, a <kanji>conical hat</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: You know the ones I'm talking about? They're cone-shaped, sort of, and they go on your head, keeping the sun off your face.
data.reading_mnemonic: A <kanji>conical hat</kanji> is kind of like an umbrella on your head. What's the reading for "umbrella" in Japanese? Why, it's <reading>kasa</reading> (<ja>かさ</ja>)!
data.reading_hint: Think about a bamboo umbrella on your head. They're pretty similar in shape, after all.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> goes through a little <radical>door</radical>, and plops down a <radical>big</radical> drop on your face. This tsunami is your tears inside your eye area. The door is your tear duct. The big drop is the <kanji>teardrop</kanji> coming down your eye.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine a teardrop going through this process to get out of your eye, though in a more miniature teardrop size.
data.reading_mnemonic: Your <kanji>teardrop</kanji>s always come at the worst times, <reading>rui</reading>ning (<ja>るい</ja>) serious and/or happy moments. You can't stop crying. it is ruining your life!
data.reading_hint: Think of several inappropriate situations to cry in. Put yourself in them. Think about how all this crying is ruining things, for real!

data.meaning_mnemonic: The radical <radical>can</radical> is the same as the kanji <kanji>can</kanji>. Usually when we talk about a can with this kanji we mean a <kanji>tin can</kanji>, though.
data.meaning_hint: Picture a tin can in your mind as clearly as you can.
data.reading_mnemonic:
The reading for a <kanji>can</kanji> is <ja>かん</ja>, which seems impossibly easy. If that isn't close enough for you, picture this:

Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (<ja>かん</ja>) is drinking out of a tin can. He glug glug glugs, gasps, and wipes his face. He holds out the can, "Khan made cans," and winks.
data.reading_hint: <ja>かん</ja> is can, it's really easy, come on. Just take this one.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>woman</radical> <radical>servant</radical> is the lower ranking <kanji>princess</kanji>. The queen is no servant. Hecks no. Just the princess, because she's a servant to what her parents tell her to do.
data.meaning_hint: Just imagine a princess saying "UGH, I'm just like a servant, I have to do all the crap you tell me." Then, all the servants roll their eyes, because, really, she's a princess, lucky duck.
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>princess</kanji> goes on to do whatever she wants. She tells the real servants, "Don't tell my daddy, the king, I did this. <reading>He may</reading> (<ja>ひめ</ja>) not like it."
data.reading_hint: The servants all know they should tell the king, because the princess is a servant to the king, just as they are, plus they don't want to lose their heads.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tree</radical> with two <radical>moon</radical>s on either side, holding the tree up in a horizontal angle, is a <kanji>shelf</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: So, your shelf is made up of a tree and two moons. Imagine this shelf and put things on it. The moons are kind of rolling around, making it hard to build your shelf.
data.reading_mnemonic: Your moon shelf is great. It's also huge, because moons are really big. That means you can store a <reading>ton-a</reading>-stuff (<ja>たな</ja>) on it.
data.reading_hint: Think about the ton-a-stuff you're going to put on there. Like, literally, measure out a ton of things and put them on there. It can hold it!

data.meaning_mnemonic: The part of <radical>rice</radical> that <radical>stand</radical>s up tall in the air (at the end of the stalks) is the <kanji>grains</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: If you think about this one it'll make good sense. Just imagine rice stalks standing up into the air.
data.reading_mnemonic: You have a box of <kanji>grains</kanji>. <reading>Ryuu</reading> (<ja>りゅう</ja>) from Street Fighter is doing training by punching the grains to strengthen his fingers.
data.reading_hint: He has his hands flat, and stabs his hands into the grains. Yah! Yah! Yah!

data.meaning_mnemonic: You put a <radical>stone</radical> into a <radical>wrap</radical> of some kind. This wrap happens to be a <kanji>cannon</kanji>, and you're shooting off the stone, just like I used to do to boats with the cannon we had growing up for some reason.
data.meaning_hint: This makes a lot of sense when you think about it, right? The muzzle of the cannon wraps around the rock, then you shoot the rock. Boom!
data.reading_mnemonic: You aim the <kanji>cannon</kanji> at your own <reading>ho</reading>me (<ja>ほう</ja>). You don't want to have a home anymore, you want to become a pirate, live on a boat, and (of course) shoot cannons all day long.
data.reading_hint: Watch as the cannon goes off, the rock hurtles into your home. And just like that, there is a huge, rock-shaped hole in it. You'll have to shoot a few more rocks at your home with this cannon before it's completely gone.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Rain</radical> on a <radical>rice paddy</radical> means only one thing... <kanji>thunder</kanji>! Get off the rice paddy! There's nothing but you to attract the thunder!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine hearing the thunder as you run. It is getting closer.
data.reading_mnemonic: You can't run fast enough to escape the <kanji>thunder</kanji> so you hitch a <reading>ri</reading>de (<ja>らい</ja>) from someone driving by.
data.reading_hint: Thank goodness, that was a close one. The guy who picks you up is named Ryan, though he likes it if you call him <reading>Ry</reading> (<ja>らい</ja>).

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>flowers</radical> <radical>fang</radical> is the bud that comes out of the ground. It's like a little fang, coming from the earth, and it will become a flower someday. This is a little <kanji>sprout</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine a bunch of these. They look like big fangs poking out of the ground (that is, until they bloom and get into the air).
data.reading_mnemonic: When the <kanji>sprout</kanji> gets out of the ground and opens up, instead of a flower there is a human-looking <ja><reading>目</reading></ja> (<ja>め</ja>), looking right at you.
data.reading_hint: You look at all the sprouts. They have all turned into <ja>目</ja>s, looking straight at you. You're terrified.

data.meaning_mnemonic: When <radical>dirt</radical> and <radical>flowers</radical> <radical>suit</radical> one another, the flowers grow so tall that they make a <kanji>tower</kanji>! A flower tower made of flower power!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine walking in the woods and coming across a huge tower made of flowers. It goes so high you can hardly see the top.
data.reading_mnemonic: The only place flowers grow into <kanji>tower</kanji>s like this is in <ja><reading>とう</reading>きょう</ja>. <ja>とうきょう</ja> dirt is the best. <ja>とうきょう</ja> flowers are the best. Thus, you end up with a lot of <ja>とうきょう</ja> towers.
data.reading_hint: How do you think the <ja>とうきょう</ja> tower came to be, anyway? It was once a big flower tower. They just replaced it with metal later. BOOM! History bomb, you're welcome.

data.meaning_mnemonic: When the <radical>tsunami</radical> struck, it hit your <radical>tent</radical> full of <radical>beans</radical>. When you lost your tent of beans, you had a moment of <kanji>lucidity</kanji>. You don't need so much stuff, you can live without it!
data.meaning_hint: Then you went back to being crazy. That moment of lucidity was only temporary, and you go back to stockpiling beans.
data.reading_mnemonic: Your <kanji>lucidity</kanji> was caused by none other than Mrs. <reading>Chou</reading> (<ja>ちょう</ja>), though. After the tsunami wiped away your beans tent, you went crazy. Then, she came and slapped you in the face for being loud, making you lucid (for a bit).
data.reading_hint: It's strange that Mrs. Chou would be the source of lucidity, but that's what she did just there. Of course, it was probably for selfish reasons, knowing her.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>spear</radical> radical and the <kanji>spear</kanji> kanji are the same!
data.meaning_hint: Spears are spears. It makes sense!
data.reading_mnemonic: You take this <kanji>spear</kanji> and stab it into a cow. "<reading>MOO</reading> (<ja>む</ja>)!" it cries. The cow bites the spear out of your hands and stabs you back. "MOO!" you scream.
data.reading_hint: How do you like it? Don't stab cows with spears, you monster.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>moon</radical> <radical>table</radical> is a table that's made entirely of <kanji>skin</kanji>. You thought the table was made of moon, with all those pores and such, but when you look more closely, you realize it's skin. Disgusting, porey, skin.
data.meaning_hint: Touch it and feel the "moon table." You know it's not made of moon. How ridiculous.
data.reading_mnemonic: But, when you go to touch this "moon table" made of <kanji>skin</kanji>, you realize that it's <reading>harder</reading> (<ja>はだ</ja>) than you expected.
data.reading_hint: You'd think skin would be softer, but it's pretty hard. Much harder than you expected.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>boat</radical> radical and the <kanji>boat</kanji> kanji are the same!
data.meaning_hint: Boats are boats, you know?
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the kanji <ja>船</ja>, though there's an extra reading there as well, <ja>ふな</ja>. They're close, so you should be able to remember it based off of <ja>ふね</ja>.
data.reading_hint: Try to answer <ja>ふな</ja> a couple times when doing your reviews. It'll help when we get to the vocab part.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Something made of <radical>gold</radical> <radical>stand</radical>s in a <radical>village</radical>. It's a <kanji>bell</kanji>!  The village bell.
data.meaning_hint: Every village has a bell of its own, standing tall and proud and shiny in the middle for everyone to see and hear.
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>bell</kanji> rings whenever the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (<ja>しょう</ja>) arrives in the village. Its ringing echoes throughout the entire village so everyone knows they have to come out and pay their respects.
data.reading_hint: The Shougun bell even sounds like it's warning you that the Shougun has arrived. It makes a loud, low shooooouu shooou sound.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If there's a <radical>treasure chest</radical>, there's always a <kanji>villain</kanji> too. The villian is trying to get to the treasure chest before the hero of the story.
data.meaning_hint: And the villain always gets to the treasure chest first, often via nefarious means. That villain is SO important when it comes to treasure chests.
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>villain</kanji> beat you all the way to <ja><reading>きょう</reading>と</ja> to get this particular treasure chest.
data.reading_hint: Arrrg! If only you had been closer to <ja>きょうと</ja>! Then you might have beaten this dastardly villain.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>dirt</radical> <radical>demon</radical> is just a <kanji>lump</kanji>. Just like a dust bunny is just a clump of dust.
data.meaning_hint: Picture a lump of dirt. Is there a demon hiding under there? No. It's just a saying, ya nerd.
data.reading_mnemonic: Have you ever heard of the game "Katamari Damacy?" That game is about a little guy who rolls a ball around, turning it into a bigger and bigger <kanji>lump</kanji>. What do you think the <reading>Katamari</reading> (<ja>かたまり</ja>) part means? It means lump, of course.
data.reading_hint: If you don't know the game and have never heard the music (especially), it's great stuff! If you have, this word will be really easy for you. If you haven't, look it up!

data.meaning_mnemonic: I <radical>protect</radical> my own <radical>animal</radical>s by going to <kanji>hunt</kanji> other animals... like wolves and cougars and such.
data.meaning_hint: My animals can't protect themselves, that's why I hunt other animals instead.
data.reading_mnemonic: I also do all my <kanji>hunt</kanji>s using a <reading>ca</reading>r (<ja>か</ja>). I just run those animals down with my car. Kind of cheating, but vroom vroom anyways.
data.reading_hint: Imagine hunting down animals in a car.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>spoon</radical> to measure a <radical>geoduck</radical> is a very <kanji>approximate</kanji> measurement. Geoducks are big, spoons are small. Still, we'll get the approximation going, right?
data.meaning_hint: Do the comparison. A spoonful of geoduck aka a whole geoduck on a spoon. This is a spoonful, right? This is what the recipe wanted, I think...
data.reading_mnemonic: Maybe this is too much geoduck, even if we're going for an <kanji>approximate</kanji>. So, you take the <reading>core</reading> (<ja>ころ</ja>) of the geoduck and measure that instead.
data.reading_hint: That's a little better. Not too much geoduck. Still a lot, but more like an approximate.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>cloud</radical> floating above a <radical>demon</radical> has its <kanji>soul</kanji> in it. If you can manage to get through to the demon, to make it see that it doesn't have to be evil, it might remember who it is and return to the <kanji>spirit</kanji> it once was.
data.meaning_hint: Right now, however, the demon is looming over you, and you can't see anything in the cloud above its head. It just looks mad, like it's gonna pummel you or eat you.
data.reading_mnemonic: You shout out and beg its <kanji>soul</kanji> for help until, finally, you see the cloud take the shape of a <reading>con</reading>dor (<ja>こん</ja>). Aha! "You were a condor before you became a demon! Remember who you are and turn back!"
data.reading_hint: POOF! Now there's a condor spirit floating in front of you, crying. "Thank you, human. You've saved my soul!" it says, and float/flies off and disappears.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you've been to the <radical>moon</radical> in the <radical>past</radical>, you had to get the special <radical>stamp</radical> on your <kanji>leg</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: This leg stamp not only proved you went, but lets everyone around you know you've been to the moon before!
data.reading_mnemonic: You've only met one other person with the same mark on their <kanji>leg</kanji> and it was <reading>Kyaku</reading> (<ja>きゃく</ja>) the customer. Kyaku visits many places all over the world, so it only makes sense that they've also been off-world too.
data.reading_hint: Picture Kyaku lifting up their pant leg and showing you all the stamps from all the different places they've been. There are even some planets on there!

data.meaning_mnemonic: An <radical>alligator</radical> is <kanji>considerably</kanji> dangerous. Considerably terrifying too. Considerably [put your scary adjective here].
data.meaning_hint: The radical meaning and the kanji meaning aren't the same, but we'll get through this together. Just put a considerable amount of effort into this and you'll learn considerably more quickly.
data.reading_mnemonic: Speaking of <kanji>considerably</kanji> terrifying, that place known as <reading>Nar</reading>nia (<ja>なり</ja>) is pretty terrifying. Not sure why children want to go there.
data.reading_hint: Also, things that are "considerably" anything start somewhere. They <reading>become</reading> (<ja>なり</ja>) whatever "considerable" thing they are now from something smaller before.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>well</radical> radical and the <kanji>well</kanji> kanji are the same.
data.meaning_hint: Make sure you remember that this is a well of water not a "well, actually."
data.reading_mnemonic: There is a single <kanji>well</kanji> in each and every town thanks to the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (<ja>しょう</ja>). One of the first things he decreed when he came to power was that all people have the right to easy and central access to water.
data.reading_hint: The Shougun also really likes watching people do physical labor, so forcing his citizens to haul water up from the well is a plus too. But hey, they aren't thirsty!

data.meaning_mnemonic: From the <radical>mouth</radical> of your <radical>older brother</radical> comes... a <kanji>curse</kanji>!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine him cursing you. He's not a fan of you, since you are siblings, but to think he'd go so far as to put a curse on you? You can't believe it. What kind of curse did he put upon you?
data.reading_mnemonic: Turns out, he put the <reading>no ro</reading>ad (<ja>のろ</ja>) curse on you, meaning you can never walk on roads.
data.reading_hint: In your mind, walk around the area where you live. Think about the places you can go that aren't roads. If you try to walk on a road, you can't. This is the <reading>no ro</reading>ad curse, after all.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>woman</radical> who is a <radical>nurse</radical> should be called <kanji>miss</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Compare this to a man who is a nurse. You should probably call him mister. That's why you know a woman who is a nurse is "miss."
data.reading_mnemonic: "Call me <kanji>Miss</kanji> <reading>Jou</reading>rm (<ja>じょう</ja>)," Jourm says to you.
data.reading_hint: When you think of "miss," remember the time that Jourm asked you to call him "Miss Jourm." You thought he was a big, ten foot tall guy, but now he suddenly wants you to call him Miss Jourm. Okay, that's up to Jourm so you should respect that.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Looking up to the <radical>cliff</radical>, you see the <radical>tree</radical>s, and the <radical>sun</radical> shining down on them. Using the sun and the trees (up there on the cliff), you've devised a method to tell what time of the year it is, based on where the shadow from the trees fall. After a while, you develop a bigger system. This system is a whole <kanji>calendar</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Look at the different shadow patterns. Know what they all mean. This is your very own calendar system.
data.reading_mnemonic: Remember the word <ja>歴史</ja>, which means "history"? Using a <kanji>calendar</kanji>, you too can remember history (otherwise, who knows when these things happened). So, the reading for this kanji is the same as the reading for <ja>歴史</ja>'s beginning, because they're related.
data.reading_hint: Make sure you make the connection between the word <ja>歴史</ja> and this kanji. If you do, it'll be much easier to remember the reading of this kanji.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>sun</radical> is being blocked by a <radical>rain</radical> <radical>cloud</radical>, making it <kanji>cloudy</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: You look up at the sky, trying to find the sun, but it's so cloudy that you can't even find where the sun should be.
data.reading_mnemonic: Remember <ja>雲</ja>? It means "cloud" and has the same reading as "cloudy," making them both <ja><reading>くも</reading></ja>.
data.reading_hint: If it's cloudy there are clouds, so if you can read one, you can read the other!

data.meaning_mnemonic: When your <radical>eye</radical> catches an <radical>omen</radical>, it's only natural that you will <kanji>stare</kanji> at it.
data.meaning_hint: You don't see omens that often, so of course you're going to stare. We'll imagine what the omen is in the reading mnemonic.
data.reading_mnemonic: As you <kanji>stare</kanji> at the omen, you see Mrs. <reading>Chou</reading> (<ja>ちょう</ja>) knocking down buildings, putting nails on the street, and making herself way longer than you ever thought possible. Oh, and there she is, destroying the world.
data.reading_hint: Whenever you see an omen (radical), remember that the omen will probably have Mrs. Chou in it!

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you're showing me your "<radical>spirit</radical> <radical>fruit</radical>" then you are just <kanji>naked</kanji>. You're <kanji>nude</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: You know what I mean by "spirit fruit" –– yep, it's out there and you're naked.
data.reading_mnemonic: Known for being <kanji>naked</kanji> (and showing you his spirit fruit) is the ancient Egyptian god <reading>Ra</reading> (<ja>ら</ja>).
data.reading_hint: Don't look up "Ra Egyptian god naked" in Google. Nothing good will come of it. Instead, just imagine your own Egyptian god Ra being naked in front of you.

data.meaning_mnemonic: I'm putting all my <radical>shellfish</radical> on <radical>someone</radical>, hoping they'll win the race! This is a <kanji>gamble</kanji> and you're gambling.
data.meaning_hint: Remember, shellfish used to be used as money. So if you're betting shellfish on someone, you're just gambling. And you probably won't get any of those shellfish back.
data.reading_mnemonic: If you win this <kanji>gamble</kanji> you'll have enough shellfish to buy a brand new <reading>ca</reading>r (<ja>か</ja>)!
data.reading_hint: If you go to any of those fancy (and not so fancy) gamble-places, they always have a car sitting in the middle of the room. Usually rotating, really slowly, to make you want it more, making you gamble more.

data.meaning_mnemonic: I have <radical>sick</radical> in my <radical>skin</radical>. Just look at it, it doesn't look too good. Whenever I have sickness in my skin, I know that I'm probably <kanji>exhausted</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine yourself being really, really exhausted. Then look at your skin. It's all sickly looking.
data.reading_mnemonic: When you're <kanji>exhausted</kanji>, your muscles are all probably worn out. Being this worn out, you can probably imagine that your body is all <reading>hea</reading>ted (<ja>ひ</ja>) up, from all the exercising.
data.reading_hint: Imagine exercising so much that your body gets all <kanji>exhausted</kanji> and <reading>hea</reading>ted (<ja>ひ</ja>) up.

data.meaning_mnemonic: There's a <radical>sock</radical> <radical>circle</radical> in the <radical>dirt</radical> on your way to <kanji>cram school</kanji>. Every day after school you walk straight until you get to the sock circle, you run around it, and then head off in any direction. Somehow it always leads to cram school.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the sock circle in the dirt in your mind. Now look up and see cram school through the trees.
data.reading_mnemonic: The sock circle seems to have a bit of a gravitational pull, so to make sure you get to <kanji>cram school</kanji> on time you have to <reading>juke</reading> (<ja>じゅく</ja>) around it every day, to make sure you can get past it.
data.reading_hint: Normal kids would probably try to juke cram school, since it's hard and it's more school than they think they need. But you're a good kid who want to cram, so you juke the circle instead.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>toe</radical> is <radical>early</radical>. I hate it when the toes show up early. Well, if the toes are going to show up this early, I guess it's best to put them on the <kanji>table</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: See all the toes lined up on the <kanji>table</kanji>. They are the ones who showed up early.
data.reading_mnemonic: What do all the early toes on the <kanji>table</kanji> do while they're waiting until it's the right time? They just sit around on their table, <reading>talk</reading>ing (<ja>たく</ja>).
data.reading_hint: Imagine the toes talking to each other. "Hello Mr. Toe!" "Oh hello other Mr. Toe!"

data.meaning_mnemonic: Below this <radical>canopy</radical> of <radical>tree</radical>s is a <radical>stone</radical>. Since it's the only stone here, you make sure to <kanji>polish</kanji> it.
data.meaning_hint: It's a single, perfectly round stone under this canopy of trees. It didn't start this way, but thanks to all the polishing you did, it has become nice and smooth.
data.reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>polish</kanji> the stone due to your <reading>meager</reading> (<ja>みが</ja>) lifestyle.
data.reading_hint: There's only this one stone under these trees, and polishing the stone is the only job here. Still, you don't get much from it, thus the meager life of polishing your stone.

data.meaning_mnemonic: When you leave <radical>grain</radical>s in your <radical>mouth</radical> for long enough, they'll turn into <radical>flowers</radical> of <kanji>bacteria</kanji>. These aren't the nice, pretty flowers you'd give your mom on Mother's Day. These are little bacteria flowers that are taking over your mouth. Maybe brush your teeth next time.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine how much bacteria would flower in your mouth if you just left grains in there for like, I dunno, a month. That's a lot of nasty bacteria!
data.reading_mnemonic: There is a lot of this <kanji>bacteria</kanji> in the <reading>Kin</reading>g (<ja>きん</ja>) of England's mouth. He eats a lot of grains, and he won't let anyone touch his mouth to clean it, but he refuses to do things himself... so it's absolutely chock full of bacteria.
data.reading_hint: Picture the King's mouth up close. Look at all the bacteria squiggling around and through his teeth and gums. Bleh! Barf!

data.meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>building</radical> <radical>now</radical> has a <radical>cloud</radical> over it, creating <kanji>shade</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: This shade is really convenient right now, because it's been such a hot day. Ahh, shade is so nice and cool.
data.reading_mnemonic: The building that's getting this nice <kanji>shade</kanji> is the <reading>inn</reading> (<ja>いん</ja>) you're staying at.
data.reading_hint: Picture an inn with a cloud right above it right now. Look at the cloud-shaped shade keeping everyone visiting the inn cool and sunburn-free.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Coming down with the <radical>rain</radical> is <radical>two</radical> <radical>spikes</radical>. They go right through two <kanji>ghost</kanji>s.
data.meaning_hint: The ghosts are pinned to the ground by the spikes, unable to move.
data.reading_mnemonic: You come across the <kanji>ghost</kanji>s, who are stabbed into the ground. "Please," they beg. "Please use that <reading>ray</reading> (<ja>れい</ja>) gun that's in that <reading>row</reading> (<ja>りょう</ja>) boat and end our suffering."
data.reading_hint: A ray gun, coincidentally, is the only thing that can kill a ghost, and there it lays, just out of reach. You'll have to be the one to pull the trigger of the ray gun. Do you pick up the ray gun out of the row boat to destroy the ghosts?

data.meaning_mnemonic: After the <radical>tsunami</radical> the <radical>sun</radical> comes out again and shines on these <radical>spikes</radical>. They were super wet before, but you figure the sun probably dried them off. You lean down to touch them and nope, they's still <kanji>damp</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: The sun did a little bit of work, so they aren't wet, but they aren't dry either. They're damp.
data.reading_mnemonic: As you're looking at the <kanji>damp</kanji> spikes, a <reading>shih tzu</reading> (<ja>しつ</ja>) prances over, slips on the damp ground, and falls right on the spike! Oh nooo!
data.reading_hint: Luckily the shih tzu is kinda pinned between the spikes, so it isn't dead or anything, but it's definitely stuck. You try to help it out, but you slip because it's so damp and you fall in too! Imagine the sound of your cries mixing in with the shih tzu's as you both struggling to get out but can't because of how damp everything is.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You feel like a <radical>stone</radical> (<radical>again</radical>!). When you feel like a stone, your body is feeling very <kanji>stiff</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Touch your stiff body. It feels like a stone.
data.reading_mnemonic: You remember how you used to cure these <kanji>stiff</kanji> body times: your old friend <ja><reading>こう</reading>いち</ja> would just massage them out for you.
data.reading_hint: If only you could ask <ja>こういち</ja> to give you massages again, but he's too busy for you, now (being emperor and all).

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>grain</radical>s you have stored in your <radical>house</radical> reflect on your <kanji>earnings</kanji>. If you earn a lot of money, you have more grains.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine looking at the grains in the houses of people who make vastly different earnings. The poor artist has only a few sacks of grain. The rich samurai has an extra house just for holding his grain. That's how you know he has much higher earnings than the artist.
data.reading_mnemonic: Another way to check someone's <kanji>earnings</kanji> is to see if they have a <reading>ca</reading>r (<ja>か</ja>). Would someone who doesn't make a lot of money have a car? No!
data.reading_hint: Picture your own earnings. Can you afford a lot of grains and a car?

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>woman</radical> who makes your <radical>house</radical> a home is your <kanji>bride</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: She's in your house because you married her. Thus, she's your bride. Your house is now a home.
data.reading_mnemonic: Now that you have a <kanji>bride</kanji> in your house, you can get rid of <reading>yo</reading>ur <reading>mai</reading>d (<ja>よめ</ja>), since your bride will do all the cleaning.
