data.reading_hint: Imagine a fool trying to pull skin out of a tiger's stomach. You can imagine them getting their skin added to the pile too if you want.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
Your <radical>car</radical> is <radical>dry</radical> because you kept it under the <kanji>eaves</kanji> of your house. 

This kanji has a second meaning too: <kanji>house counter</kanji>. Imagine counting all the houses on your block by the number of eaves you see keeping cars dry.
data.meaning_hint: One eave, one house. Two eaves, two houses.
data.reading_mnemonic: On top of the <kanji>eaves</kanji> of your house <reading>Ken</reading> (<ja>けん</ja>) the samurai is counting houses too.
data.reading_hint: Ken hops down and explains that he's been hired to count all the houses in his lord's domain just because his name is the same as the counter for houses. It isn't really fair, he complains to you, as you try to sneak by and lock him out of your house.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>car</radical> that's <radical>lack</radical>ing is really <kanji>soft</kanji>. Cars need to be hard so that things like bugs and other cars wont hurt the people inside when you hit them. But if your car is lacking the hardness it needs, you'll have a really soft, useless car.
data.meaning_hint: Picture a soft car lacking what it needs to drive down the road. It's so soft it just flops down and won't move.
data.reading_mnemonic: This car is probably so <kanji>soft</kanji> because it's made entirely of <reading>naan</reading> (<ja>なん</ja>). Naan may be delicious, but it makes a really crappy car. No wonder it was so soft (and yummy).
data.reading_hint: Picture trying to drive this soft naan car. It probably just sinks into the ground and then gets eaten by wild animals (and me).

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you <radical>mix</radical> a bunch of <radical>building</radical>s together, you have yourself a <kanji>suburb</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Isn't that all a suburb is? Just a mix of a variety of buildings in one area?
data.reading_mnemonic: "<kanji>Suburb</kanji>s are what we need!" says Emperor <ja><reading>こう</reading>いち</ja>.
data.reading_hint: "That suburb life will encourage more people to study kanji," Emperor <ja>こういち</ja> continues.

data.meaning_mnemonic: So my <radical>building</radical> has a big <radical>splinter</radical>, right in the <kanji>corner</kanji>. So what?
data.meaning_hint: Imagine a huge splinter coming out of the corner of the building. It's in a really dangerous spot, but the owner doesn't seem so worried about it.
data.reading_mnemonic: That <kanji>corner</kanji> is dangerous, but what are you going to do, <reading>sue me</reading> (<ja>すみ</ja>)?
data.reading_hint: Actually, please don't sue me. I'll fix the splinter coming out of the corner of my building.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>turkey</radical> sitting on a <radical>stool</radical> is something every ship has in its crow's nest. That's why the universal <kanji>ship counter</kanji> is a turkey on a stool. Not a crow.
data.meaning_hint: Picture yourself counting ships by pointing your finger from one turkey propped up on a stool to the next. You'll be the best ship counter in the world at this rate!
data.reading_mnemonic: Once you become the best <kanji>ship counter</kanji> in the world everyone will think you are super <reading>sexy</reading> (<ja>せき</ja>)! Nothing is sexier than being able to count, and counting ships is the sexiest thing you can count.
data.reading_hint: Imagine yourself, a sexy ship counter. Sexily counting ships. You go guy/girl/non binary person! So sexy!

data.meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>clan</radical> is breaking <radical>ground</radical> and <radical>building</radical> your new <kanji>residence</kanji>. You're all working together to make you a new home!
data.meaning_hint: Picture your clan, working together, to build a new residence for you on their land.
data.reading_mnemonic: Your new <kanji>residence</kanji> is complete! You step closer and the smell of <reading>ta</reading>ter (<ja>てい</ja>) tots hits your nose. Someone is making you tater tots in your new residence. Wait, no they aren't. Your residence is MADE of tater tots! Thank you, clan!
data.reading_hint: Imagine living in a tater tot residence. Whenever you're hungry, you just lean over to the wall and munch.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>buddy</radical> <radical>building</radical> is in the next <kanji>county</kanji>. If it was in your county then it wouldn't be a buddy, it would be a neighbor. You're aware of this building, but they aren't that close, so they're just a buddy.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine looking at a map of your county and the surrounding ones. All of the buildings in the counties next to yours are buddy buildings!
data.reading_mnemonic: Your <kanji>county</kanji> is everything you can reach when shooting a <reading>gun</reading> (<ja>ぐん</ja>). If the bullet can't reach a building you know, it's a buddy building in another county.
data.reading_hint: Imagine taking out a gun and shooting in a random direction. When you find where the bullet landed, you know that's the county line. Though if it gets stuck in a building or a person it doesn't count. You'll have to try again.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Kill a <radical>shrimp</radical> with a <radical>sickle</radical> and you'll need a really good <kanji>explanation</kanji> for yourself. What did that shrimp do to you? Why use a sickle? Well? What's your explanation?
data.meaning_hint: Try to come with an explanation for picking up a sickle and cutting the head off a shrimp with it.
data.reading_mnemonic: In your <kanji>explanation</kanji> you blame everything on <reading>Shaq</reading> (<ja>しゃく</ja>). He told you to do it! It's all Shaq's fault, you explain.
data.reading_hint: Picture Shaq popping into your head as you struggle to come up with an explanation for me. Picture Shaq's face. This is payback for Shaq Fu, you think, as you finalize the rest of the explanation in your mind.

data.meaning_mnemonic: When the <radical>moon</radical> faces the right <radical>direction</radical>, everyone on earth becomes <kanji>obese</kanji>. The pull of the moon moves all the water on earth as well as inside us, so when it faces the right way, we all get super <kanji>fat</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the moon turning to face a different direction. Feel your body start to become really obese. You get huge and round just like the moon.
data.reading_mnemonic: You look around and everyone is <kanji>obese</kanji> like you. You try to reach out to them, but you roll over like a big <reading>bow</reading>ling (<ja>ぼう</ja>) ball. The person next to you does too. Soon you're all rolling around like helpless, obese bowling balls.
data.reading_hint: Picture yourself, as obese and round as a bowling ball, rolling faster and faster down hills. Other people are rolling around you too. You're all screaming. You want the moon to face the other direction so it will stop. You don't like being a human bowling ball!

data.meaning_mnemonic: You wake up in <radical>prison</radical> and there is a <radical>big</radical> <radical>mouth</radical> full of <radical>legs</radical> coming really, really close to your own <radical>mouth</radical> so you <kanji>scream</kanji>! Scream because this is terrifying. Scream because it's all you can think to do.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine a prison where horrible mouth leg creatures are trying to get in your mouth. You don't want to scream because they might get in there, but you can't help it.
data.reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>scream</kanji> and scream and scream until a door bursts open. It's Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (<ja>かん</ja>) and he looks mad. Apparently your screaming is bothering him and now he's gonna give you a real reason to scream.
data.reading_hint: Imagine Genghis Khan doing something to make you scream. What is it? What could Genghis Khan do that's worse than what's already happening to you?

data.meaning_mnemonic: Everyone knows that when a <radical>woman</radical> plays <radical>football</radical> she becomes a <kanji>princess</kanji>. Thats how princesses are made.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the awesome princess, kicking butt and taking names, out on the football field.
data.reading_mnemonic: Remember the word <ja>姫</ja>? It means <kanji>princess</kanji> too. If you remember the <ja>ひめ</ja> from <ja>姫</ja>, you'll be able to remember this one too.
data.reading_hint: Make sure you know both princess words and you'll know their readings too.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You try to put your <radical>toe</radical> inside a <radical>shellfish</radical>, but it just won't open. That's because this shellfish has sworn an oath of <kanji>chastity</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: "No, I won't open up until I meet the toe I will marry," it says to you.
data.reading_mnemonic: "<kanji>Chastity</kanji> is really important to me," the shellfish says. "But, maybe if you give me a <reading>ta</reading>ter (<ja>てい</ja>) tot, I'll change my mind."
data.reading_hint: You give the shellfish a tater tot, and it breaks its vow of chastity, opening up for your toe. You look the other way, but you can hear the sounds of passion below.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>mysterious</radical> radical and the <kanji>mysterious</kanji> kanji are the same!
data.meaning_hint: Know your radicals, yo!
data.reading_mnemonic: There is no one more <kanji>mysterious</kanji> than <reading>Gen</reading>ji (<ja>げん</ja>). He's tall, dark, handsome, and most of all... <ja>〜</ja>mysterious<ja>〜</ja>!
data.reading_hint:
Who's the mysterious man who's always reciting poetry? Genji!
Who's the mysterious man who gets all the ladies? Genji!
Who's the mysterious man crying over there because someone turned him down? G... Genji...

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Flowers</radical> that grow in a <radical>rice paddy</radical> only live to be <kanji>seedling</kanji>s. Once they sprout, they're plucked away to make room for more rice. Poor little seedlings.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the seedlings growing among the rice plants. Once they bloom they'll be picked, so let's hope they stay small as long as they can.
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>seedling</kanji>s try their best to blend in by referring to themselves as <reading>myou</reading> (<ja>みょう</ja>), you know, me and you combined. That's myou.
data.reading_hint: Listen to the little seedlings say myou over and over. Too bad the farmers can tell they aren't rice plants.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you put two <radical>mustache</radical>s on either side of a <radical>tsunami</radical> it won't know which way to go and spin back and forth until it becomes as <kanji>whirlpool</kanji>. Mustaches are pretty gross, so I don't blame the tsunami for avoiding them.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the tsunami spinning in a circle, trying not to hit the mustaches until it spins itself into a giant whirlpool.
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>whirlpool</kanji> is huge, and it starts pulling things into itself. Oh no, is that my <reading>ca</reading>r (<ja>か</ja>)? Hey, wait! Whirlpool give my car back!
data.reading_hint: Picture my car getting sucked into the whirlpool. Picture me crying as my car disappears into it forever.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A person with <radical>horns</radical> has you on the <radical>ground</radical> and lets loose two <radical>poops</radical> over your <radical>heart</radical>. "<kanji>Mercy</kanji>! Mercy!" You cry, but the horned dude doesn't stop until there are two gross poops sitting on your heart. "M-mercy..." is the only thing you can think to say.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine yourself saying "mercy" over an over as this horned guy has you on the ground and keeps pooping over your heart.
data.reading_mnemonic: As you shout "<kanji>Mercy</kanji>!" one more time, suddenly <reading>Je</reading>sus (<ja>じ</ja>) appears out of no where and punches the horned guy into the stratosphere. Jesus snaps his fingers and the poop is gone and you're off the ground. Your heart is safe.
data.reading_hint: Imagine yourself saying mercy and seeing Jesus appearing just in time to save the day. The word "mercy" must be his bat signal. Jesus signal? Sure.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>spirit</radical>s of the two <radical>tree</radical>s you destroyed with your <radical>jackhammer</radical> live on in the <kanji>collar</kanji> you made out of them.
data.meaning_hint: You took the shredding tree bits and carefully molded them into a nice collar to go with all of your shirts. But now it's haunted.
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>collar</kanji> keeps whispering, "<reading>Eri</reading>c (<ja>えり</ja>)!" into your ear. Your name isn't Eric (I mean it could be, in that case wow, weird, right?), so you assume one of the trees you killed was named Eric. But that's the only name you hear, so maybe they were both named Eric? It's weird.
data.reading_hint: Whenever you put on your collar you hear a constant stream of, "Eric, pssst, hey Eric, hey!" and you just have to pretend it isn't happening.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You put <radical>flowers</radical> on your <radical>scooter</radical> and your <radical>car</radical>. The flowers you put on them are <kanji>lotus</kanji> flowers.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine placing lotuses on top of your scooter and car. They are the right kind of flowers for these vehicles.
data.reading_mnemonic: You're putting a <kanji>lotus</kanji> on both your scooter and car because they are <reading>ren</reading>tals (<ja>れん</ja>).
data.reading_hint: You always put a lotus on top of your rental cars and scooters. Come up with a personal reason why you do this.

data.meaning_mnemonic: There is a special type of meditation where you put a <radical>lid</radical> on your <radical>mouth</radical> and touch your <radical>forehead</radical> down to your <radical>legs</radical>. If you can do this pose, everything in life will become completely <kanji>clear</kanji>. Everything will clear out of your head too. You should try it.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine this pose, imagine everything becoming clear. Clear your mind. Clear your head.
data.reading_mnemonic: Your mind is as <kanji>clear</kanji> as a sparkling clear pond. On this pond you see yourself in a <reading>row</reading> (<ja>りょう</ja>) boat. A single row boat on the clear pond that is now your mind.
data.reading_hint: Picture the row boat on the clear pond in your mind. Watch the clear water flow over the row boat's oars.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you have an <radical>ear</radical> for the <radical>public</radical>'s <radical>heart</radical>, you must be very <kanji>wise</kanji>. You can understand everything the people want, and you know how to give it to them because you listen to their hearts so well.
data.meaning_hint: Close your eyes and open your ears. Feel all of the wise things fill you.
data.reading_mnemonic: All of these <kanji>wise</kanji> things are stored in your <reading>sou</reading>l (<ja>そう</ja>), not your brain. That's where all of these kinds of intuitive feelings live.
data.reading_hint: Picture your wise soul, living inside your body. Somehow it just seems to know what the public really wants. It's like your soul is connected to their souls, granting you this wisdom.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you want to have a <radical>tsunami</radical> at your <radical>wedding</radical>, you need to make sure you have it at the <kanji>bay</kanji>. Anywhere more inland, and the tsunami won't reach it in time.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the tsunami coming towards your beautiful wedding as you stand by the bay. It's not safe, but it's memorable!
data.reading_mnemonic: How did you get a tsunami to show up in the <kanji>bay</kanji> in the first place? By throwing a bunch of <reading>ura</reading>nium (<ja>うら</ja>) in there, of course! Its highly unstable nature can make any body of water, especially a calm bay, turn violent.
data.reading_hint: Imagine throwing buckets of uranium into the bay. It only burns your hands a little. And now they glow green, just like the bay does!

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>dirt</radical> on the <radical>forehead</radical> of a <radical>pig</radical> makes a small <kanji>mound</kanji>. Picture it, if you will. A pig is rooting through the dirt. It lifts its head and there is a mound of dirt right on its forehead.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine that you're the pig. How big can you make your forehead dirt mound?
data.reading_mnemonic: The pig's forehead dirt <kanji>mound</kanji> keeps getting bigger until it's the size of <reading>two cars</reading> (<ja>つか</ja>)! Pigs are big, but you didn't think one could balance a mound the size of two cars on its forehead and not fall over.
data.reading_hint: Picture a pig with a mound of dirt the size of two cars leisurely stomping around on a farm.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>building</radical> was a <radical>former</radical> <radical>prison</radical> until the <kanji>cave in</kanji>. You see, prisons aren't built very carefully, they just try to get them done fast enough to stuff people in there. So while you can tell this was once a building, it definitely isn't a prison anymore, since the whole thing caved in.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the cave in in your mind. Can you see all the little prisoners and guards being squished as the building tumbles down around them? Oh no!
data.reading_mnemonic: You keep picturing the <kanji>cave in</kanji> and you see Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (<ja>かん</ja>) climbing over the rubble. He's the one who took down this prison! And he's coming for your town next!
data.reading_hint: Genghis Khan is all about being smart and using better tactics. In this case, why fight a bunch of guards and prisoners when you can just cause a cave in and win immediately? The ol' Khan cave in, a classic war maneuver.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
Under the <radical>window</radical>, you place a <radical>shellfish</radical>, then slam the window shut to <kanji>pierce</kanji> its tough shell. This is the best way to pierce a member of the shellfish family, I promise.

This kanji also has a second meaning. That shellfish you pierced with the window is in two halves now. You can use those halves as plates for sushi. If you count the broken shells you'll know how much sushi you have. That makes them <kanji>sushi counter</kanji>s!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine the window piercing into the shellfish's shell. Then imagine lining up the pieces, putting sushi on them, and counting them all.
data.reading_mnemonic: Now that your shellfish is properly <kanji>pierce</kanji>d and turned into <kanji>sushi counter</kanji>s, you can serve them to Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (<ja>かん</ja>) and his men. I really hope you counted them correctly too, because there are a lot of them.
data.reading_hint: Carefully count out all the sushi on their pierced shell plates and place them in front of Genghis Khan and his army. As you reach Genghis Khan himself, you realize it's just his ghost, but he's still staring at you as you serve his troops. Ghost or not, you don't want him to pierce you if you mess up.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Take a <radical>leather</radical> <radical>helicopter</radical> to the <radical>moon</radical> to prove your excellent <kanji>leadership</kanji>. Some people called you crazy, but you'll show them, as you lead an entire crew of leather helicopter pilots on their first mission to space!
data.meaning_hint: Not many people have the leadership it takes to lead such a mission. Imagine what it takes to do it!
data.reading_mnemonic: Under your superior <kanji>leadership</kanji> you and your leather helicopter crew are able to make it to the moon. The moon! Your crew is so impressed by your leadership, and their lack of being very dead, and they all start laughing, "<reading>Ha</reading> (<ja>は</ja>) ha ha ha!" They thought they were going to die but you lead them to the moon safely!
data.reading_hint: Imagine laughing along with the crew, in awe at your own leadership skills. Ha ha ha! We didn't die!

data.meaning_mnemonic: I hope all you're doing in the <radical>bathtub</radical> is taking a <kanji>bath</kanji>. I mean, you can do other things if you want I guess. But bathtubs were made just for baths!
data.meaning_hint: Picture yourself taking a bath in your bathtub. Relaxing!
data.reading_mnemonic: When do you miss taking a <kanji>bath</kanji> the most? When you're on the <reading>ro</reading>ad (<ja>ろ</ja>). Traveling is fun and all, but when you're stuck in a car, traveling down a dirt road for days, all you want to do is take a nice long bath.
data.reading_hint: Imagine being stuck on the road all day for a week. Imagine how good a bath will feel when you finally get home. Nice and hot and relaxing. Mmmm...

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you look at <radical>flowers</radical> the first thing you notice are the leaves and petals themselves, then the <radical>next</radical> thing you notice are the <kanji>briar</kanji>s. You never see <kanji>thorn</kanji>s first, only after you've looked at the flowers.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine what you see next after looking at the pretty flowers. The briars are what you see next. Spiky and sharp. It would have been nice if you had seen them first.
data.reading_mnemonic: When you see the <kanji>briar</kanji>s you can't help but yell, <reading>Eee! Ba riars</reading>! (<ja>いばら</ja>)! You pause funny because you prick your finger on one while you're yelling. Ouch!
data.reading_hint: Imagine seeing the briars and yelling out "Ba RI ars!" as you prick your finger on one.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>fingers</radical> grasp this <radical>lid</radical> and when you raise it you see a <radical>poop</radical> <radical>turkey</radical> (a turkey covered in poop). You can't help yourself, you <kanji>embrace</kanji> the turkey.
data.meaning_hint: Someone was obviously going to cook this poop turkey in a pot, and if you hadn't looked under this lid it surely would have died. Now as you embrace it you can hear the turkey weeping softly.
data.reading_mnemonic: As you <kanji>embrace</kanji> the sad turkey it makes a funny sound and suddenly starts pooping <reading>yo</reading>gurt (<ja>よう</ja>) all over you. But you don't want to stop embracing it! It's probably just scared still. But the more you squeeze, the faster the yogurt comes out of it!
data.reading_hint: Imagine embracing the turkey as it covers you in yogurt poo. You hope it's yogurt at least. You aren't gonna taste it to find out. Maybe. Okay you might taste it a little.

data.meaning_mnemonic: There was once a <radical>melon</radical> <radical>child</radical>, that is, a child with the body of a melon. When he was born, his parents didn't want him, so he became an <kanji>orphan</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: The "melon boy orphan," is what they called him. Imagine a melon (your favorite kind) with a face and arms and legs sticking out. He walks up to you and says "hello kind person, could you help an orphan?"
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>orphan</kanji> melon boy is but a <ja><reading>子</reading></ja> (<ja>こ</ja>).
data.reading_hint: That's the sad thing about the melon orphan boy... he's just a child. "Hello gov, I'm just a child," he says to you.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You give a bunch of <radical>shellfish</radical> to a <radical>clown</radical> as <kanji>compensation</kanji>. The clown did you some favors, and everyone knows clowns only accept shellfish as a form of currency. So your compensation is a pile of random shellfish.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the shellfish in your hands. Imagine handing them over to the clown as compensation for the unspeakable acts you had him do for you.
data.reading_mnemonic: Once the clown has been properly <kanji>compensate</kanji>d, he looks you in the eyes, one hand full of shellfish, the other in the air, and waves, "<reading>Bye</reading> (<ja>ばい</ja>)" he says. "Bye, bye."
data.reading_hint: All you have to do is give him the right amount of compensation and you'll hear his sweet "bye, bye." Then you never have to see him again.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The famous <radical>gold</radical> <radical>triceratops</radical> <radical>shellfish</radical> is good for only one thing, and that's being made into <kanji>chain</kanji>s. They link their triceratops horns together and form an unbreakable gold chain. You can't eat them, because they're gold. So they're only really good for their chaining together ability.
data.meaning_hint: Picture these little gold triceratops shellfish linked together by their horns in a chain around your neck. Feel them hanging there. Sparkly and cold.
data.reading_mnemonic: However, the only way to break the <kanji>chain</kanji> is to <reading>saw</reading> (<ja>さ</ja>) it open. Once the triceratops shellfish start holding on, they never let go. So when you want to take the chain off you have to really hack at it with your saw.
data.reading_hint: Picture the saw in your hands, sawing back and forth on the gold chain around your neck. Maybe this isn't the best fashion accessory if you have to use a saw to get it off.

data.meaning_mnemonic: From your <radical>mouth</radical> comes a <radical>cross</radical>, some <radical>flowers</radical>, and <radical>shellfish</radical>. It all <kanji>erupt</kanji>s from your mouth!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine these three things coming out of your mouth not one at a time, but all together like an eruption. Perhaps you're laying on your back, and they burst out of your mouth.
data.reading_mnemonic: When do inanimate objects <kanji>erupt</kanji> from your mouth? Mostly when you're having <reading>fun</reading> (<ja>ふん</ja>).
data.reading_hint: It's really inconvenient that things erupt from your mouth whenever you're having fun. Makes it hard to have fun.

data.meaning_mnemonic: When a <radical>spirit</radical> lives in a <radical>sheep</radical> it becomes the most <kanji>auspicious</kanji> creature on the planet. Lights shine out of it and the whole world weeps at its beauty. Look at the sheep's fluffy glowing head. Nothing could be more auspicious and glorious than this.
data.meaning_hint: Picture this auspicious spirit sheep. Blessing the children with its fluffy hooves.
data.reading_mnemonic: The spirit sheep is so <kanji>auspicious</kanji> that the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (<ja>しょう</ja>) declares this day to be the most auspicious of all days. The day when the spirit sheep appeared.
data.reading_hint: Picture the Shougun telling the world that they must fly spirit sheep flags on this day forever, because of how auspicious it is.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you take a <radical>cow</radical>'s <radical>life</radical> you're turning it into an <kanji>offering</kanji>. In the old days, cows' lives were given to the gods as offerings pretty often.
data.meaning_hint: Picture yourself offering the cow's life up to the god(s). It's a good thing we don't actually have to do this anymore, you think.
data.reading_mnemonic: You prepare the <kanji>offering</kanji> with your holy blue <reading>sa</reading>ber (<ja>せい</ja>). Normally this would be gruesome, but your saber glows and the cow's life shoots up into the sky without you laying a hand on it.
data.reading_hint: Thanks to the mercy of your saber, the offering is quick and painless. A normal saber, however, would have cut that cow to bits. Like, really just wrecked it. Good thing we didn't make you think about that, huh?

data.meaning_mnemonic: If a <radical>grain</radical> has a <radical>fault</radical>, it needs to be put back in <kanji>order</kanji>. Grains must be perfectly identical at all times, otherwise they'll be thrown out. That's why special people will go out and check them to confirm their <kanji>regularity</kanji>. Keeping order is a tough job!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine being one of these people who maintain order by going out in the fields and inspecting every single grain, keeping the good ones and plucking off the ones with faults.
data.reading_mnemonic: You can always tell if a company keeps <kanji>order</kanji> or if it <reading>cheats</reading> (<ja>ちつ</ja>) just by looking at the grains.
data.reading_hint: If there are faulty grains in there, they cheated and order was not maintained. Now you have to go through all the grains and throw out the weird ones yourself.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you have <radical>spider</radical>s in your <radical>mouth</radical>, then you're going to <kanji>instigate</kanji> fights between people. Mostly because the spider in your mouth makes you grumpy, but also because the spider keeps telling you to be an instigator with its little mouth inside your own mouth.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine having a spider in your mouth. Imagine being angry about it and instigating fights between people because of it.
data.reading_mnemonic: The spider in your mouth tells you to <kanji>instigate</kanji> a fight by <reading>saw</reading>ing (<ja>さ</ja>) the other person's leg off. It even whispers where you can find a nice big saw.
data.reading_hint: Picture the fight you and the spider instigated. The guy pointing at the saw, then pointing at his sawed off leg. Listen as the spider tells you to shake your head.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Play your <radical>drum</radical> under the <radical>moon</radical> and your <radical>hair</radical> will <kanji>swell</kanji>! The more you play and the longer it's under the moon, the larger your hair will swell.
data.meaning_hint: Have you been suffering from flat, boring hair? Well do I have the swelling treatment you've been looking for!
data.reading_mnemonic: Using this method, your hair <kanji>swell</kanji>s so much it looks like a giant <reading>bow</reading>ling (<ja>ぼう</ja>) ball is sitting on top of your head. It's all round, and well... swollen is probably the only word that fits.
data.reading_hint: Imagine watching your hair swell to the size of a large bowling ball. Imagine never being able to go bowling again because the comparison is too easy for people to make.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you point <radical>flowers</radical> in the same <radical>direction</radical> you'll be able to smell their wonderful <kanji>perfume</kanji>. The best way to get perfume out of flowers is to make them face the same way. Then the smell will go the same direction, making you smell great.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine aiming a bunch of flowers in the same direction towards you. The perfume coats your body. You smell great now!
data.reading_mnemonic: You decide to <kanji>perfume</kanji> your entire <reading>ho</reading>me (<ja>ほう</ja>) by planting flowers all the way around it, all facing in toward it.
data.reading_hint: Now when you're in your home the overwhelming smell of perfume assaults your nostrils. It's actually... really strong. Oh... oh no it's too strong, you can't breathe. And you live alone. Help! Someone!

data.meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>soul</radical> is like the <radical>ground</radical> or the <radical>dawn</radical>. It is <kanji>constant</kanji>, never changing.
data.meaning_hint: Think of some other things your soul is like, but always make sure you come back to one word: constant.
data.reading_mnemonic: Also <kanji>constant</kanji> is the Emperor <ja><reading>こう</reading>いち</ja>, who will surely rule for a thousand more years!
data.reading_hint: A constant rule from Emperor <ja>こういち</ja> means constant kanji learning and constant WaniKani reviews. They will always be constant!

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>leader</radical> puts their <radical>hat</radical> on the <radical>ground</radical> next to a <radical>bookshelf</radical>. This is a test in <kanji>ethics</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: People hang around the bookshelf, and the leader wants to see if anyone will steal the hat or not. That's why its a test of ethics.
data.reading_mnemonic: To test your <kanji>ethics</kanji> even more, the leader puts down a <reading>rin</reading>g (<ja>りん</ja>) as well.
data.reading_hint: Now we'll really see how everyone's ethics are. Will they turn in the ring to lost in found? will they ignore it? Will they steal it?

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>building</radical> to the <radical>east</radical> is an <kanji>exhibit</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: It's a pretty large building and you can see inside to all of the different exhibits within the main exhibit.
data.reading_mnemonic: Right now the <kanji>exhibit</kanji> has a bunch of <reading>chin</reading>s (<ja>ちん</ja>) on display. Animal chins, human chins, every chin you can think of is in the exhibit.
data.reading_hint: Go up to the first exhibit and look very closely at some turtle chins, then some crab chins, then some alligator chins. This is weirdly familiar.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Shaving the <radical>hair</radical> off a <radical>geoduck</radical> before you try to eat it is absolutely <kanji>necessary</kanji>. If you don't, the hair will get caught in your throat and you'll choke. It is necessary that you remove the hair.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the page in your cookbook where it says "Shaving the hair off your geoduck = Necessary!!" It's absolutely necessary that you follow that instruction!
data.reading_mnemonic: It is also <kanji>necessary</kanji> that you wear a <reading>su</reading>it (<ja>す</ja>) when eating shaved geoduck. It's a super fancy meal so a suit is necessary for you to enjoy it correctly.
data.reading_hint: What's necessary? To shave the hair off your geoduck and to wear a suit. That's not too hard. You should do it.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> of the <radical>library</radical> thinks that all the books in their library are better than everyone else's books. He's a very <kanji>biased</kanji> person. If he wasn't the leader of that specific library he'd probably feel differently.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine showing the leader your favorite book. "That's not a book in MY library," he says, and throws it in the trash. That's so biased! He didn't even give it a shot!
data.reading_mnemonic: You decide to give in to his <kanji>biased</kanji> recommendations and look at what he has in his library. It doesn't take long until you realize that these books are all about <reading>hen</reading>s (<ja>へん</ja>) and hen care. This guy is so biased about his favorite books that he only filled his library with what HE wants to read. And apparently that thing is taking care of hens... weird.
data.reading_hint: "This is such biased crap," you say, as you finish reading the title of a book called "Hens are better than all other birds." Screw this leader guy and his books.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>scooter</radical> gave you a <radical>splinter</radical>, so you had to go in for <kanji>treatment</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine how bad a scooter splinter would be! You would need special treatment for that.
data.reading_mnemonic: After you get <kanji>treatment</kanji>, you feel really <reading>goo</reading>d (<ja>ぐう</ja>).
data.reading_hint: Not just "good," but "goooooood." Emphasize the long vowel for the long vowel in <ja>ぐう</ja>. You feel this way because when you went in for treatment, they gave you the good, good drugs. You know the ones.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>rice</radical> that's prepared at <radical>dawn</radical> by the <radical>village</radical> are <kanji>provisions</kanji> for the army. The army is scheduled to arrive right after dawn, so all of the villages provisions for them have to be ready by then.
data.meaning_hint: Picture everyone in the village getting all of their rice together as provisions for the army. Even the kids and old people are helping out.
data.reading_mnemonic: Once all of the <kanji>provisions</kanji> are ready, the soldiers show up in their <reading>row</reading> (<ja>りょう</ja>) boats and load it all up. But they aren't done there. "Rice isn't enough, we need <reading>roe</reading> (<ja>ろう</ja>) so we will have the strength to row our row boats back." And so the village brings them all of their roe too.
data.reading_hint: Picture the soldiers gobbling down their provisions of rice and roe in their row boats as they row away.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If the <radical>yakuza</radical> <radical>slide</radical> you into a <radical>jet</radical>, things are <kanji>especially</kanji> bad for you. Not just normal bad, like, especially bad.
data.meaning_hint: First of all, the yakuza have you, that's bad already. But they're sliding you into their jet? That means you aren't upright, you might even be knocked out or dead. That's especially worrying, don't you think?
data.reading_mnemonic: You're <kanji>especially</kanji> worried now, because they're putting you in some kind of <reading>chu</reading>te (<ja>しゅ</ja>). You already took a slide in here, and now you're teetering over the edge of a dark, steep chute into who knows where!
data.reading_hint: As you slide down the chute, it's especially dark. And especially scary. And especially bad! How did this happen to you?!

data.meaning_mnemonic: If your <radical>soul</radical> is acting like the <radical>sun</radical> trapped in a <radical>net</radical> sitting on a <radical>stool</radical>, then people will <kanji>ridicule</kanji> you for your <kanji>laziness</kanji>. You're just sitting there, trapped and not moving.
data.meaning_hint: Your soul just doesn't want to move or do anything though... and that may look like laziness, but you can't help it. You wish your friends and family wouldn't ridicule you. You're going through enough, internally.
data.reading_mnemonic: When people <kanji>ridicule</kanji> you, when you can't stop the <kanji>laziness</kanji>, you read <reading>man</reading>ga (<ja>まん</ja>). Manga helps you feel better about the mean things people say. Manga helps you feel like you're doing something, and that you aren't just a lazy person.
data.reading_hint: Picture yourself reading manga and watch as the people who ridicule you and call you lazy fade away into the background. You're going to be okay.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you figure out how to use a <radical>tsunami</radical> as a <radical>weapon</radical>, everyone is going to <kanji>die</kanji>. You can't control a tsunami, you fool. Now you've doomed us all.
data.meaning_hint: Picture everyone in the world being swept away in a tsunami to die. This is what happens when you try to use nature as a weapon.
data.reading_mnemonic: The only way to maybe not <kanji>die</kanji> is to find <reading>boats</reading> (<ja>ぼつ</ja>). As long as the boats don't get smashed by the tsunami, you might be able to cheat death by holding onto the boats and not drowning.
data.reading_hint: You don't want to die, do you? Get to the boats!

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you give a <radical>machine</radical> a <radical>heart</radical> it will get <kanji>lazy</kanji>. Hearts give us emotions and with emotions we become weak. Why would a machine with a heart want to work anymore? Nah. It's lazy time now.
data.meaning_hint: Picture a machine with a heart, laying on the couch, eating oil snacks, and snoozing. What a lazy machine!
data.reading_mnemonic: The machine is so <kanji>lazy</kanji> it won't even wear its <reading>tie</reading> (<ja>たい</ja>) anymore. That was the only official thing left about it, but now it's as lazy as a human. Would a lazy human put on a tie? I don't think so.
data.reading_hint: Picture the lazy machine sitting on the couch again. There are untied ties all over the floor.

data.meaning_mnemonic: When you ride your <radical>scooter</radical> on the <radical>ground</radical> listening to <radical>music</radical> under the <radical>sun</radical>, you're bound to <kanji>encounter</kanji> a bunch of new people! They hear your music playing as you scoot by and they come out to <kanji>meet</kanji> you.
data.meaning_hint: Picture all of the people you encounter as you ride your scooter, spreading your music around town.
data.reading_mnemonic: Everyone you <kanji>encounter</kanji> wants to bare their <reading>sou</reading>l (<ja>そう</ja>) to you, literally. They're all coming out to meet you, pulling back their skin and showing you the soul ghosts inside of them.
data.reading_hint: "We love your music, look at our souls!" Uh oh, this is turning into some kind of horror movie. You better scoot a bit faster or you might meet an unfortunate fate.

data.meaning_mnemonic: In its <radical>soul</radical>, a <radical>narwhal</radical> that's supposed to do <radical>construction</radical> under the <radical>moon</radical>, will be too <kanji>lazy</kanji> to do it. And when your soul is lazy, there's no way you'll be able to get something done.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the lazy narwhal laying on a block of ice in the moonlight. There are tools and other blocks of ice around, but he just can't seem to get up and do any construction work.
data.reading_mnemonic: You can't tell the <kanji>lazy</kanji> narwhal he's being lazy because he's your <reading>da</reading>d (<ja>だ</ja>). If he was anyone else you'd tell him off for being lazy, but you can't tell off your dad. That's just not right.
data.reading_hint: Picture your lazy dad. Your big, lazy narwhal dad.

data.meaning_mnemonic: There is an <radical>animal</radical> in the <radical>grass</radical> and your horrible <radical>task</radical> is to go <kanji>hunting</kanji> for it.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the shape of the animal in the grass, off in the distance. You can't see what kind of animal it is yet, but you know you're hunting it.
data.reading_mnemonic: You're currently <kanji>hunting</kanji> in a <reading>row</reading> (<reading>りょう</reading>) boat and you have to row as quietly and carefully as you can or the animal will run away.
data.reading_hint: You wouldn't be able to go hunting in any other kind of boat—the motor would be too loud. Picture yourself in a row boat with all of your hunting gear. You need to be extra careful not to make any loud splashing sounds with the oars!

data.meaning_mnemonic: What do <radical>stairs</radical> do? They take you <kanji>from</kanji> where you were, to somewhere else. They're a way to get <kanji>from</kanji> place to place.
data.meaning_hint: Picture yourself climbing stairs, picture going from room to room. From place to place. From wherever you were to wherever you want to be.
data.reading_mnemonic: If you're going <kanji>from</kanji> place to place, you should really make sure you have a <reading>kni</reading>fe (<ja>ない</ja>) on you for protection. If you want to make it far enough from home you should seriously consider it. Knives keep everyone safe when they're going far from home.
data.reading_hint: Imagine yourself taking those first few steps from home, knife heavy in your pocket. You can go as far from home as you want now. The knife will keep you safe.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You're sewing something with <radical>thread</radical> but you and your creation get <radical>frostbite</radical> while you're still working. Luckily the snowflakes freeze themselves into the cloth and turn into a pretty <kanji>design</kanji>. They swirl around and press a unique snowy design into the fabric. This is nice for you because you can't sew anymore with your frostbitten hands.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine holding your creation in your frostbitten hands as the snowflake design starts to appear. The design gets more and more complicated the longer you watch, twisting this way and that, like it's dancing in front of your eyes.
data.reading_mnemonic: As you watch the snowflake <kanji>design</kanji> form you realize they're moving in a <reading>rin</reading>g (<ja>りん</ja>) pattern. Rings inside bigger rings, linked with smaller rings.
data.reading_hint: Try to picture this ring design in your head. It's something no human hands could have made, frostbitten or otherwise.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you <radical>stand</radical> in the <radical>wind</radical> it will be really <kanji>quick</kanji> to knock you over. So quick that you probably won't even know the wind did it. You'll end up standing up again just to be knocked over again, just as quick.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine how quick the wind knocks you over when you stand up. So quick, you don't even remember being up. Try again and try to count how many seconds it takes for it to knock you down. Less than one. Now that's quick.
data.reading_mnemonic: The wind was so <kanji>quick</kanji> to knock you down that you <reading>sat</reading> (<ja>さつ</ja>) down instead. The wind may be quick, but it can't knock you down if you've already sat yourself.
data.reading_hint: Picture how quick you sat down. Even faster than the quick wind. Nice job!

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you tie a <radical>cross</radical> to a <radical>turkey</radical> you can trick everyone into thinking it's a <kanji>falcon</kanji>. The cross will stretch its wings out just enough for it to stop looking so fat and turkey like, into a super cool bird of prey.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine tying a cross to this turkey and see it transform into an elegant falcon. Majestic.
data.reading_mnemonic: You decide to name this new falcon after your favorite falcon-like ninja. Ryu Hayabusa (はやぶさ) from Ninja Gaiden! Picture your fat turkey falcon and Ryu Hayabusa teaming up Banjo and Kazooey style. Yeah, that's the dream right there.
data.reading_hint: Picture your falcon Hayabusa and the real... ok fake.. Hayabusa running around together and kicking butt.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you want to have your <radical>wedding</radical> in a <radical>car</radical> you're going to need a lot of <kanji>help</kanji>. Cars are pretty small compared to weddings, so if you don't get help from everyone you know you won't be able to pull it off.
data.meaning_hint: Picture all of your close friends coming to help you squeeze everything for the wedding into your car.
data.reading_mnemonic: You can't just ask for <kanji>help</kanji> on the day of the wedding, either. You have to <reading>sche</reading>dule (<ja>すけ</ja>) getting your friends' help ahead of time. They might have pretty tight schedules too, so makes sure you plan early!
data.reading_hint: Imagine calling all your friends and scheduling when you will get their help. Make sure you have your day planner ready!

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>roof</radical> <radical>flowers</radical> <radical>see</radical> everything. But, they only see. That is because they learned the art of <kanji>tolerance</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: These roof flowers only see because they do not judge. They accept everything. We humans can learn a thing or two about tolerance from these roof flowers.
data.reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Tolerance</kanji> is one thing that Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (<ja>かん</ja>) had a surprising amount of.
data.reading_hint: You wouldn't expect it, but he actually allowed many types of cultures, religions, and peoples to exist under his reign. The Mongols had an exceptional amount of tolerance for the time.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Take the <radical>moon</radical> and <radical>wrap</radical> it in a bag and it will look just like a <kanji>cell</kanji>. It's a circle in a bigger circle. The moon is the nucleus. Yes! Science is happening!
data.meaning_hint: Picture the moon with a big bag circling it. Now look down at your biology homework on cells. They're identical!
data.reading_mnemonic: As you learn about <kanji>cell</kanji>s you realize they're all over your <reading>ho</reading>me (<ja>ほう</ja>). Without ever noticing it, your home has been slowly filling with dead skin cells. And now that you know what they look like (the moon with a plastic wrap bag around it) you can see them everywhere.
data.reading_hint: AHHH CLEAN ALL OF THESE CELLS OUT OF YOUR HOME!

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Tsunami</radical> of <radical>conflict</radical> will <kanji>cleanse</kanji> and <kanji>purify</kanji> the lands of people, homes, and culture.
data.meaning_hint: Anything less than a tsunami of conflict would leave something behind. But this much conflict will cleanse the area of everything.
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>cleanse</kanji> of your lands was caused by <reading>Jou</reading>rm (<ja>じょう</ja>). Why did the slow farmhand bring an army to the village, and why is he yelling about, "The cleanse," while destroying everything? Jourm?! Weren't we friends?
data.reading_hint: You thought Jourm was an ordinary, clumsy, ten foot tall farmhand. But he brought down a tsunami upon your village. And, he brought armed conflict too. This thing he calls "The cleanse" was actually something he had been planning for years. His use of a totally ordinary Viking mouth towel... his table made of foreheads... That tatami mat altar with the forehead wearing a top hat... Was he really a Viking pretending to be a simple farmhand just so he could bring his men inland to cleanse and purify your village? It's too late now. Jourm stands over your body. You are about to receive "The cleanse" too.

data.meaning_mnemonic: How many <radical>building</radical>s <radical>have</radical> <radical>scooter</radical>s? <kanji>All</kanji> of them!
data.meaning_hint: All buildings have at least one scooter. It could be out front, on the roof, in the basement. But all of them have scooters and someone who likes to ride them instead of using a car or a bike.
data.reading_mnemonic: <kanji>All</kanji> of these scooters have a specific sound they make as they burst out of the buildings: <reading>zuwee</reading> (<ja>ずい</ja>).
data.reading_hint: Imagine the sound of the scooter's tiny engine: zuwee zuwee zu zu zuwee. All of them do this, which is why you hate them.

data.meaning_mnemonic: When what you're writing is as <radical>tall</radical> as the <radical>grain</radical>s growing outside, you know you're done with your first <kanji>draft</kanji>. Some teachers want papers to be a certain number of words or pages, but that's silly. You should measure your draft in grains!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine holding your draft up outside in a field of grains. You're a couple leaves short. Time to get back to the drawing board.
data.reading_mnemonic: Who asked you to write such a tall <kanji>draft</kanji> in the first place? Emperor <ja><reading>こう</reading>いち</ja>, who wants you to draft up the world's largest book about how great of an emperor he is.
data.reading_hint: Now <ja>こういち</ja> is out there measuring your draft against the tall grain plants. You better hope it's long enough, because if it isn't, Emperor <ja>こういち</ja>'s probably going to execute you.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This is a <radical>boat</radical>, but it's missing some pieces. That's because it's really rusty, so parts are falling off of it and it looks <kanji>rust colored</kanji>. It's getting more and more rusty as time goes on.
data.meaning_hint: Picture this broken, rust colored boat. It's a reddish-brown color and it's definitely missing some important pieces.
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>rust colored</kanji> boat has inspired you, so you sit down next to it in the sun and <reading>tan</reading> (<ja>たん</ja>). You want to be the exact same rust color as the boat, and in a few hours you're sure you'll match.
data.reading_hint: Watch your skin slowly change as you tan to match the rust colored boat. Feel your skin in the sun. This may not be good for your health, but it's great for fashion!

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>dirt</radical> <radical>nurse</radical> is someone who nurses dirt. When nursed, dirt becomes <kanji>soil</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Soil generally has more nutrients in it. It makes sense for dirt that's been nursed to become soil.
data.reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Soil</kanji> is a thing <reading>Jou</reading>rm (<ja>じょう</ja>) the huge farmhand works on improving. If he makes the soil better, the farm will yield more crops.
data.reading_hint: Imagine Jourm working with soil (not dirt!). Improving it by mixing in various ingredients. The soil this year is particularly lush, for some reason...

data.meaning_mnemonic: You want to have a quaint <radical>cottage</radical> <radical>wedding</radical>, so you have to go to the cottage wedding <kanji>shop</kanji> to get everything you need. This shop is the only place you can buy everything you need. It's not like you can make a cottage from scratch!
data.meaning_hint: Picture yourself walking into the cottage wedding shop. Look at all the different cottages you get to choose from. And there's wedding cake too?! This shop has everything!
data.reading_mnemonic: You're browsing everything in the <kanji>shop</kanji> when a garden <reading>hoe</reading> (<ja>ほ</ja>) catches your eye. Yes. This will make your cottage wedding the absolute best one. The hoe will give you away at your wedding.
data.reading_hint: Imagine walking around the shop and then falling in love with a hoe with pretty tassels and flowers attached to it. Yes, it's only for decoration, but you're going to buy and use it during your cottage wedding.

data.meaning_mnemonic: While the <radical>moon</radical> is out, a <radical>gladiator</radical> is riding a <radical>horse</radical>, yelling about <kanji>inflation</kanji>. No one would listen to him during the day, so he waited for the moon to rise so he could complain about prices doing the same.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the gladiator riding his horse in the light of the moon yelling, "Do you have any idea how important it is to increase the average pay rate to account for inflation? All of us gladiators are going to be unable to pay the bills soon because inflation isn't being taken into account! You'll suffer too! Listen to me!"
data.reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Inflation</kanji> rises the most in <ja><reading>とう</reading>きょう</ja>, and the gladiator knows that because that's where most of them live and fight (and die).
data.reading_hint: Imagine if you were in this gladiator's place. In five years, you wouldn't be able to afford to eat thanks to the bosses in <ja>とうきょう</ja> refusing to adjust for inflation. Back in my day, onigiri only cost FIFteen yen!

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>thread</radical> that goes through <radical>Korea</radical> is the <kanji>latitude</kanji> line splitting up North and South Korea.
data.meaning_hint:
Why thread? Back in the old days globes were sewn together with cloth and thread, so there was a literal thread dividing the Koreas!

Or you can just picture an actual, super long piece of thread going around the entire globe. That works too.
data.reading_mnemonic: The only way you can see this <kanji>latitude</kanji> line is to ride an <reading>ea</reading>gle (<ja>い</ja>) over it. The line isn't visible from a car, you're too close, and a plane is too high. You have to see it from an eagle's point of view.
data.reading_hint: Imagine being an eagle yourself, flying around the entire globe, following the latitude line that splits Korea down the middle.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>boat</radical> owned by a <radical>Yoga</radical> <radical>King</radical> needs to be able to let him keep doing his exercises while he's on it. That's why his boat is a <kanji>rowboat</kanji>, so he can work on his yoga arms as he gets around.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the Yoga King rowing a rowboat. Maybe he's using his legs. Maybe he's using his butt? You don't know. Yoga people are super flexible, he could be using anything to move this rowboat.
data.reading_mnemonic: As he rows the <kanji>rowboat</kanji> with his butt, you see the Yoga King eating something with his toes. They're <reading>ta</reading>ter tots (<ja>てい</ja>). Tater tots are the perfect snack for a rowboat. They're small, delicious, and they float if you drop them in the water.
data.reading_hint: Go rent a rowboat and try eating tater tots in it. For fun, throw a bunch of them in the water and watch them float. Maybe you'll catch a fish!

data.meaning_mnemonic: Press your <radical>fingers</radical> in someone's <radical>skin</radical> to <kanji>expose</kanji> what's underneath. This is pretty gross, but sometimes it's more important that you expose the cause of the problem, than avoiding something uncomfortable.
data.meaning_hint: Close your eyes. Picture someone's arm. Now touch their skin with your fingers and peel it back to expose the muscles and bones underneath.
data.reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>expose</kanji> a small hole under their skin and <reading>he</reading>at (<ja>ひ</ja>) comes pouring out. Aha! You knew there was something wrong under here. Apparently there's something under this person's skin that's exuding way too much heat.
data.reading_hint: Imagine the heat steaming out, like it's coming out of a teapot, not out of somebody's arm skin.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You weave <radical>gold</radical> and <radical>white</radical> patterns into this <radical>towel</radical>, turning it into <kanji>brocade</kanji>. It's beautiful, elegant, and worth way more than when it was just a plain towel.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine weaving this beautiful brocade fabric out of one of your old towels. Try to actually picture the gold and white patterns you want on there. If you're a crafter, actually do it!
data.reading_mnemonic: You want to keep your <kanji>brocade</kanji> fabrics safe, so you lock them away and seal them in with a <reading>niche key</reading> (<ja>にしき</ja>). It's niche because brocade is a very niche kind of thing.
data.reading_hint: Imagine using your niche key to open this hidden brocade storage room. The key is gold and white and looks like brocade too!

data.meaning_mnemonic: Put a <radical>turkey</radical> on <radical>ice</radical> and it will only get <kanji>semi</kanji> frozen. You add more ice, and it stays the same. Only some of it will freeze. What the heck!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine covering a turkey in ice and every time you check it, it's only semi frozen. It doesn't matter what you do, it just refuses to freeze all the way through.
data.reading_mnemonic: Finally you realize it will only <kanji>semi</kanji> freeze because it's <reading>June</reading> (<ja>じゅん</ja>)! It's too hot out for your turkey to freeze all the way. The ice keeps melting off the top and semi thawing it!
data.reading_hint: The lesson is to never try to freeze something in June. If you do it will only semi freeze.

data.meaning_mnemonic: There's so much <radical>grain</radical> in your <radical>mouth</radical> you need to use a <radical>knife</radical> to remove it. Only when there is a <kanji>surplus</kanji> can you put that much grain in your mouth.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine seeing so much grain that you can stuff your mouth so full you can't swallow or spit it out. You have to use a knife to remove it. After you get all the grain out, comment on the surplus of grain.
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>surplus</kanji> is thanks to the hard work of folks like <reading>Jou</reading>rm (<ja>じょう</ja>) the big farmhand. He worked hard to make sure there was a surplus of grain this year.
data.reading_hint: Remember how Jourm made the soil better? Perhaps this is some of that work paying off. Thanks to that and everything else, there is a great surplus.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>drunkard</radical> <radical>cross</radical>es <radical>thread</radical> across special <radical>spikes</radical> to separate the <kanji>fiber</kanji>s. The best way to separate the fibers of thread is to get a drunkard to do it. If you're too precise it will just snap. You gotta be loose with it! Just flop them onto the spikes and the fibers will come apart by themselves!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine a drunkard crossing threads onto spikes and pulling the tiny fibers free. You don't think you could do that. Maybe if you got drunk too...
data.reading_mnemonic: You stare at the <kanji>fiber</kanji>s easily coming apart when you realize that this drunkard seems to have a few extra legs... and hair and a tail? This isn't just a drunk guy, it's a <reading>cen</reading>taur (<ja>せん</ja>). Maybe separating fibers is really a centaur trick, and that's why normal people can't do it...
data.reading_hint: Watch the centaur cross the fibers and separate them with his spikes. How strange.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you try to <radical>say</radical> something to the <radical>Death Star</radical>, it would only <kanji>admonish</kanji> you. It was made to destroy planets, after all, so I don't know why you'd expect it to have anything nice to say. It just admonishes you about everything you've ever done wrong until you can't stop crying.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine being admonished by the Death Star. It's hovering above you, giant and round, just yelling at you about everything you've ever messed up. It's really awful being yelled at. But the Death Star doing it is particularly scary and embarrassing.
data.reading_mnemonic: Right now you're being <kanji>admonish</kanji>ed about living in a <reading>yu</reading>rt (<ja>ゆ</ja>). The Death Star bellows, "What, am I too big and safe for you? I'm easy to move too, you know. You're a disgrace! You should be ashamed!"
data.reading_hint: Imagine sitting in your yurt, the home you love, but you can still hear the admonishments from the Death Star in your ears. You feel... bad.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you get a <radical>big</radical> <radical>hair</radical> stuck in your <radical>private</radical> <radical>soul</radical> it will be a <kanji>disaster</kanji>! Have you ever gotten a hair in your eye or your mouth that you just couldn't get out? You cough, your eyes water, it's awful! You can't focus on anything until it's gone. Now imagine if a big 'ol hair got stuck in your own private soul!!! Disaster!!!
data.meaning_hint: This disaster is ruining your life. You can't eat, sleep, all you can do is panic trying to get the hair out.
data.reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>disaster</kanji> is so huge that even <reading>San</reading>ta-san (<ja>さん</ja>) left his vacation in <reading>Zan</reading>zibar (<ja>ざん</ja>) to come tell you you're on the naughty list for being such a disaster person. WHAT?! Even you Santa-san?
data.reading_hint: Santa-san has forsaken you. Your life is a wreck. This is a total disaster just because of one big hair.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Tiger</radical>s and <radical>wolverine</radical>s have one big thing in common and it's that the government likes to <kanji>oppress</kanji> them. It doesn't matter if you're the animal or a mutant X-Men hybrid. The government will go out of its way to oppress you if you are one.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine being a tiger or a wolverine or a tiger-wolverine and being oppressed by the government just because you're different. Imagine being stuck in a cage. Not being allowed to vote. It's awful!
data.reading_mnemonic: Tiger and wolverine people are so <kanji>oppress</kanji>ed that the only thing they're allowed to amuse themselves with is <reading>Gak</reading> (<ja>ぎゃく</ja>). You know, that weird goo they made us play with when we were kids? Well that's not so fun when it's all you have.
data.reading_hint: Imagine being a tiger/wolverine girl and being so oppressed that you can only sit in a cage, playing with goopy Gak all day. This blows...

data.meaning_mnemonic: You use your <radical>fingers</radical> to take down the <radical>old</radical> <radical>flag</radical> and <kanji>install</kanji> a new one. Flags get old, just like computers and furniture and people. So when one gets too old, you have to get on up there and install a new on in its place.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine reaching out and grabbing onto the old flag with your fingers. Feel the dirty grime and little holes it's gotten. Now install something new!
data.reading_mnemonic: You've decided to <kanji>install</kanji> a <reading>su</reading>it (<ja>す</ja>) where the old flag used to be. I mean, a suit is probably more durable than a flag, am I right? This way you won't have to install flags as often.
data.reading_hint: Picture a newly installed suit flying in the air on a pole.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you <radical>loiter</radical> around a <radical>surplus</radical> of anything, you need to be <kanji>gentle</kanji> and touch everything <kanji>gently</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Unfortunately it's not specific as to what kind of surplus you're loitering around, so you'll need to imagine a surplus of something memorable to you. Then, just imagine loitering around there, being really gentle with everything.
data.reading_mnemonic: You have to be <kanji>gentle</kanji> and handle these things <kanji>gently</kanji> because they belong to <reading>Jo</reading>-Anne (<ja>じょ</ja>). You're loitering around her surplus of (whatever you decided to imagine).
data.reading_hint: Imagine Jo-Anne coming back to her surplus, then asking you if you were gentle with the goods. You were, you treated everything very gently.

data.meaning_mnemonic: In your <radical>fingers</radical> are <radical>flowers</radical> which really <radical>suit</radical> you. But you throw them to the people waving to you from below, as you <kanji>board</kanji> your ship. The flowers fall, unneeded. You're <kanji>embark</kanji>ing on a new life, a new journey. There will be more flowers where you're going.
data.meaning_hint: Picture yourself boarding the ship and letting the flowers slip from your fingers, into the crowd of people waving goodbye.
data.reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>board</kanji> a ship to <ja><reading>とう</reading>きょう</ja>, bound for your new life, of course!
data.reading_hint: Where else would you go at this point? I mean, come on. You've made it 53 levels since you embarked on your kanji journey with us. We know you by now. You want to be in <ja>とうきょう</ja>.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Flowers</radical> are growing out of the <radical>ground</radical> and over your pet <radical>pig</radical>'s <radical>forehead</radical> and it's causing the poor thing to live in total <kanji>darkness</kanji>. The flowers are hanging down over its eyes and won't let any light in at all. And some of the flowers seem to be growing directly out of the pig's forehead too. The pig has just been wandering and bumping into things all day because of it.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine being a pig with flowers hanging down off your forehead and into your eyes so that darkness was all you knew. It's very sad, actually.
data.reading_mnemonic: To end the <kanji>darkness</kanji> you <reading>mow</reading> (<ja>もう</ja>) the flowers. You have to drive your lawnmower over its head too, because they're growing out of its forehead too. They'll grow back soon though and cover your pig's world in darkness once again and you'll have to do it all over again.
data.reading_hint: Imagine mowing the darkness away. Be careful! If you mow the pig's eyes, the darkness will last forever!

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you're in Japan (which is the end goal here, let's be honest) then the <radical>fish</radical> in your <radical>village</radical> are <kanji>carp</kanji>. You may know them as <kanji>koi</kanji>, too.
data.meaning_hint: Picture your village in Japan. There's a big, still pond full of bright and beautiful giant carp. You hear the village kids giggle as they feed them and their big round mouths pop out of the water.
data.reading_mnemonic: A <kanji>carp</kanji> is called a <reading>koi</reading> (<ja>こい</ja>) in Japanese. We've used that word before so I hope you know it by now. A koi is a koi, you know?
data.reading_hint: Carp are koi and koi are carp. Blub blub.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>cross</radical> carrying <radical>drunkard</radical> wants you to go to a <radical>rice paddy</radical> <radical>together</radical> so you can <kanji>receive</kanji> something from them.
data.meaning_hint: You really don't want to receive whatever it is this drunkard wants to give you, and it's even sketchier that they want you to go to a rice paddy together to do it.
data.reading_mnemonic: Against your better judgement, you decided to go and <kanji>receive</kanji> the thing. You close your eyes, hold out your hands, and feel a silky, light <reading>tie</reading> (<ja>たい</ja>) being placed in them.
data.reading_hint: The tie looks harmless enough, but you still receive it skeptically. The drunkard is just holding up his cross and smiling at you. Hmm.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>thread</radical>s a <radical>criminal</radical> wears will always be <kanji>scarlet</kanji>. Scarlet is the color of freshly spilt blood, which is why bad guys wear it so much.
data.meaning_hint: Picture a person wearing all scarlet all the time. Don't they give you a criminal-y vibe?
data.reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>scarlet</kanji> color holds a lot of <reading>he</reading>at (<ja>ひ</ja>). Scarlet is the color of fire, and it has the heat of fire too.
data.reading_hint: Picture a criminal, covered in this scarlet thread, heat radiating off of him.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>sun</radical> is rising and there is a <radical>net</radical> covering <radical>someone</radical>, who's being forced to watch as <kanji>dawn</kanji> appears. They've never seen dawn before, and they didn't want to, but you're making them.
data.meaning_hint: Picture someone tied down in a net as dawn breaks.
data.reading_mnemonic: The someone who saw <kanji>dawn</kanji> for the first time goes on to become sumo wrestling champ <reading>Akebono</reading> Taro (<ja>あけぼの</ja>). He always gazes at the sunrise at dawn before he wrestles and it fills him with strength.
data.reading_hint: Look at Akebono looking at you as you look as dawn is breaking.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>old</radical> <radical>moon</radical> (the moon we had before the current moon) was actually just a huge <kanji>barbarian</kanji> floating in the sky.
data.meaning_hint: Just imagine a huge barbarian (whatever that means to you) floating in the sky, looking down. Some ancient people look up and wave at the old moon barbarian.
data.reading_mnemonic: At least, this is the kind of story you told your <ja><reading>子</reading></ja> (<ja>こ</ja>) when they asked you where the moon came from.
data.reading_hint: "You see, my child, the old moon was not like the current moon. It was a giant barbarian in the sky, who would eat children that asked too many questions."

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>melon</radical> radical and the <kanji>melon</kanji> kanji are exactly the same! Wahoo!
data.meaning_hint: Make sure you remember this radical means melon and you'll remember the kanji meaning too!
data.reading_mnemonic: What's the best use for a <kanji>melon</kanji>? Not eating it, but running over it in your <reading>ca</reading>r (<ja>か</ja>)! Melons make a nice big splat sound when you drive over them, and that's what you plan to do to every melon you see.
data.reading_hint: Imagine hitting the gas pedal in your car as you head for a big melon. Watch it burst into a million pieces as your car makes contact, hurling melon bits all over your windshield. It's a melon firework!

data.meaning_mnemonic: There's a <radical>drop</radical> of <radical>bear</radical> on this <radical>towel</radical>. A true <kanji>commander</kanji> can notice little things like this.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine a commander carefully looking over everything. They not only notice a drop of something on a towel, but they're able to identify that the drop is a small piece of liquid bear.
data.reading_mnemonic: You watch the <kanji>commander</kanji> in all his glory... going back and forth on a <reading>swi</reading>ng (<ja>すい</ja>).
data.reading_hint: "Weeee!" says the commander.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you can find the <radical>door</radical> in <radical>winter</radical> shaped like a <radical>mouth</radical> it will <kanji>enlighten</kanji> you.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine searching for this special door in the cold wind and snow of winter. The search for enlightenment always has something to do with suffering and searching on your own like this.
data.reading_mnemonic: The door <kanji>enlight</kanji>ened you by opening up and revealing the <reading>ca</reading>ke (<ja>けい</ja>) in its door-mouth. "Cake is the key to enlightenment, my child. Now eat it from my mouth."
data.reading_hint: All you need to do to attain enlightenment is to eat this cake... out of this mouth. Eh. Maybe enlightenment isn't worth it.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Flowers</radical> that are thought to be little <radical>tent</radical>s sent from <radical>heaven</radical> are <kanji>hollyhock</kanji>s. They're shaped almost like little teepees and would make the perfect tent for a faerie or a little yokai!
data.meaning_hint: Picture a tiny yokai using a hollyhock as a tent. Aww cute!
data.reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Hollyhock</kanji>s are mostly <ja><reading>あおい</reading></ja> (blue) because they copy the color of the heavens, where they came from.
data.reading_hint: Imagine yourself in a field of hollyhocks and the <ja>あおい</ja> of them match the <ja>あおい</ja> of the heavens! It's like you're standing on a giant flower filled mirror of the sky.

data.meaning_mnemonic: When a <radical>horse</radical> sees a <radical>spider</radical> it will start running at a <kanji>speed</kanji> no one ever thought a horse could go! Horses are super afraid of spiders, you see, so if they see one, they'll bolt and reach top speed! That's actually the only way to get a horse to run that fast.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine the eyes of a horse seeing a spider and then running at top speed to get the heck away from it.
data.reading_mnemonic: Once people realize that they can increase the <kanji>speed</kanji> of their horses, <reading>soon</reading> (<ja>しゅん</ja>) everyone will be taking spiders with them to scare their horses into running faster. I say soon because it hasn't quite caught on yet. But if you help to spread the word it can happen even sooner.
data.reading_hint: Soon the world will be filled with horses running at full speed all thanks to the spider increase of the 2000s! Soon we will be in the future of top speeds!

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you <radical>say</radical> something the same way they say it in the <radical>capital</radical>, everyone in the whole country will be able to <kanji>comprehend</kanji> what you're trying to say. If you try to speak in your hometown's dialect no one will. But everyone can comprehend what you want if you use the capital's dialect to say it.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine the confused faces of the people in the countryside as you try to talk to them. Decide to say it the way it's said in the capital and see their faces light up as they comprehend what you're trying to say.
data.reading_mnemonic: Now that the townspeople finally <kanji>comprehend</kanji> what you were trying to say, they sell you the <reading>row</reading> (<ja>りょう</ja>) boat you were trying to buy. You were using the wrong word, but <ja>りょう</ja> is what they needed to hear to understand you, and now you can row your way back home.
data.reading_hint: Picture yourself rowing away in your new row boat as the townspeople wave goodbye. They were much nicer once they comprehended what you were asking for. Maybe you'll row your way back here someday.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You cut the <radical>flowers</radical> off the <radical>grain</radical> with your <radical>knife</radical>. The flowers that fall off are <kanji>jasmine</kanji> flowers.
data.meaning_hint: It's weird that jasmine flowers are growing out of your grain, but that's why you're cutting them off.
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>jasmine</kanji> is growing out of everything, not just grain! It's also growing out of the <reading>ree</reading>ds (<ja>り</ja>)!
data.reading_hint: You have a farm that grows grain and reeds. Jasmine flowers are growing out of both of those things, ruining your crops! Perhaps you should become a jasmine tea farmer instead...

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you travel to the <radical>fish</radical> <radical>capital</radical>, you'll find the leader of all fish, the mighty <kanji>whale</kanji>! Okay, so a whale isn't technically a fish, but that's why it makes such a good leader. You can usually only find whales hanging around near the capital because they really enjoy ruling over all the other fish. They are the biggest, after all.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the underwater fish capital. Statues of whales line the fishy streets, and all of the fish bow down to the whale ruler's giant body.
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>whale</kanji> who resides over the capital just happens to be <reading>gay</reading> (<ja>げい</ja>). You only know this because his husband is a man whale too. Actually, now that you think about it, all the whales you've ever met have been gay.
data.reading_hint: Picture the gay whale ruler holding whale hands... fins? with his whale husband. They're so cute.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Clearing his <radical>flowers</radical> of <radical>icicle</radical>s, the <radical>samurai</radical> returns home to his <kanji>villa</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the samurai's villa. It's in the countryside and covered in flowers and icicles. Even though it's spring, it's still cold, so all the new flowers are very cold.
data.reading_mnemonic: Once the samurai enters the <kanji>villa</kanji>, he lets his <reading>soul</reading> (<ja>そう</ja>) go. He's been fighting for long enough and this villa was always where he wanted to go.
data.reading_hint: Picture the samurai sitting in a chair in his beautiful villa and breathing his last breath. His soul slowly floats up and out of his still body and dances around the villa, free.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>drunkard</radical> gets his hands on a <radical>plow</radical> and starts <kanji>planting</kanji> right away. Drunk people are surprisingly good at planting, especially when they have machines to help them do it.
data.meaning_hint: Picture a drunk guy laughing and plowing a field and planting seeds. He wouldn't do this if he was sober, but drunk people can't help themselves.
data.reading_mnemonic: He keeps <kanji>planting</kanji> and planting... a little too much. You walk over and realize this drunkard isn't just any guy... he's YOUR <reading>CY</reading>BORG (<ja>さい</ja>)!
data.reading_hint: Oh my sweet cyborg child! Is this what they've done with you? You're just a drunkard who's only good for planting? Nooooooo!!

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>mouth</radical> with a <radical>sword</radical> is threatening to cut off your <radical>fingers</radical> because they've <kanji>kidnap</kanji>ped you! You can't see anything about them, since they're all covered up. All you see is their angry mouth and the sword they keep putting near your fingers.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine you've been kidnapped. And the person who kidnapped you is going to cut off some of your fingers and mail them to your parents if they don't pay the ransom soon enough. You don't want your fingers to be cut off with a sword! Help!
data.reading_mnemonic: You've been <kanji>kidnap</kanji>ped and your kidnapper has asked for one thing in exchange for your safe return: a <reading>ka</reading>yak (<ja>かい</ja>). Kayaks are expensive. And it's way easier for this dude to kidnap you and demand your family buy one and give it to them than for them to work for one.
data.reading_hint: If your parents don't send in the kayak to your kidnapper soon, you're gonna lose some fingers. Come on guys, just get the kayak already!!!

data.meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>forehead</radical> is the <radical>origin</radical> for the <radical>measurement</radical> for your <kanji>crown</kanji>! If you measure somewhere else on your head for a crown it won't fit.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine someone putting a tape measure around your forehead and taking careful measurements for your crown. They better not mess up, or you'll have them put to death!
