data.reading_mnemonic: Now you're curious about what's under there but when you try to touch the <kanji>tombstone</kanji> it's radiating with intense <reading>he</reading>at (<ja>ひ</ja>)! It must have come from outer space and this heat is from when it entered our atmosphere!
data.reading_hint: Can you feel the heat radiating off this space tombstone? Maybe there's a space skeleton sizzling under there too...

data.meaning_mnemonic: Who loves their <radical>flag</radical>, using <radical>jackhammer</radical>s, and precise <radical>measurement</radical>s? Your <kanji>military officer</kanji>! He's always saluting the flag, jackhammering near all the new recruits to test them, and checking the measurement between the floor and their pants. Who else could it be?
data.meaning_hint: Picture a military officer doing all those things.
data.reading_mnemonic: That <kanji>military officer</kanji>'s favorite bird is an <reading>ea</reading>gle (<ja>い</ja>)! That should be obvious because the eagle is the bird of America! And that's the country he fights for!
data.reading_hint: Picture the military officer saluting as an eagle flies overhead. Majestic.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You're trying to open the <radical>lid</radical> of a manhole that's covered in <radical>ice</radical> by <radical>jackhammer</radical>ing it a bunch of <radical>times</radical> but it's not working because it's just too <kanji>cold</kanji>. It's so cold that your jackhammer is starting to ice up too. But you need to get this lid open so you try time after time after time!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine if it was sooo cold that no matter how many times you tried to jackhammer the ice of the lid for this manhole, it wouldn't crack open.
data.reading_mnemonic: Each time the jackhammer hits the freezing <kanji>cold</kanji> ice it makes a high pitched <reading>rin</reading>ging (<ja>りん</ja>) sound. It's actually really annoying to listen to but you really need to crack this ice open so you have to keep listening to it.
data.reading_hint: If it wasn't so darn cold you wouldn't have to hear this horrible high pitched ringing sound because there wouldn't even be any ice to jackhammer through!

data.meaning_mnemonic: There is a <radical>cage</radical> with an <radical>axe</radical> in it above your house to show that you are an <kanji>artisan</kanji>. All of the artisans have to have this special sign somewhere near where they live to show they make things.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine looking down your street and seeing caged axes above all of the artisans homes and shops. You want a new chair? You want some pants mended? Go to one of those signs and you'll find the right artisan.
data.reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Artisan</kanji>s have to be marked this way because the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (<ja>しょう</ja>) says so. The Shougun doesn't want to have to put any effort into finding people to make things for him, so he created this new system.
data.reading_hint: Picture the Shougun marching angrily down the street. His shoe suddenly snaps in half. With just one glance he'll be able to find the shoe artisan and make them fix his shoe for free.

data.meaning_mnemonic: There is a <radical>scooter</radical> that is a <radical>satellite</radical>, but it is <kanji>far off</kanji> and <kanji>far away</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Look up into the sky. That little moving light is the scooter satellite. It's just scooting along, far away from here.
data.reading_mnemonic: The scooter satellite is <kanji>far off</kanji>, but you can still hear it's horn go "<reading>har</reading> (<ja>はる</ja>) har har."
data.reading_hint: The scooter satellite's only purpose is to make a "har har har" sound that is audible from far away. It's quite obnoxious.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You shoot an <radical>arrow</radical> at the <radical>mouth</radical> of the <radical>sun</radical> so that it will grant you a gift of <kanji>wisdom</kanji>. You heard about a Greek hero doing this and the god in the sun gave him the wisdom to see everything. You're hoping it will work for you too.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine shooting an arrow at the mouth of the sun and then waiting for the wisdom of the world to hit you. Did it work? Will you know when it works? Probably...
data.reading_mnemonic: You're standing around waiting for the <kanji>wisdom</kanji> to hit you when something else does. In the head. Ouch! You look down and it's a wheel of <reading>chee</reading>se (<ja>ち</ja>)! At first you're angry, until you realize that this must be a sign. Cheese IS wisdom. And they key to wisdom is eating a lot of cheese!
data.reading_hint: Picture yourself thanking the sun for teaching you that all wisdom comes from cheese. Now take a big bite!

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you could <radical>stop</radical> <radical>spoon</radical>ing water onto that <radical>tree</radical> we could use it for <kanji>brushwood</kanji>. But if you don't stop, then it will be too wet to burn at all! Stop already!
data.meaning_hint: We need to use that brushwood to make a fire! So stop spooning water on it!
data.reading_mnemonic: You finally set the <kanji>brushwood</kanji> on fire and suddenly a <reading>Shiba</reading> (<ja>しば</ja>) Inu jumps out of the flames. So that's why they named this wood after them or... or vice versa?
data.reading_hint: Shiba inu's come from setting brushwood on fire! That must have been how they got their name!

data.meaning_mnemonic: When a <radical>shellfish</radical> becomes a <radical>drunkard</radical> and sees a <radical>cross</radical>, they'll become a <kanji>robber</kanji>. Because they'll steal the cross!
data.meaning_hint: Some people make really bad choices when they're drunk, and in this case, when a shellfish gets drunk and sees something it wants it'll just rob people for it.
data.reading_mnemonic: Once the shellfish has a taste for being a <kanji>robber</kanji>, he'll join a Boso<reading>zoku</reading> (<ja>ぞく</ja>) bike gang so he can keep stealing more and more crosses. He'll drink more, steal more, and get to ride cool motorcycles.
data.reading_hint: Picture a robber shellfish in a Bosozoku bike gang. Look at him the wrong way and he and his gang will steal all your stuff next time!

data.meaning_mnemonic: You take a <radical>drum</radical> and a <radical>branch</radical> and... well, what else would you do? You would <kanji>drum</kanji> or <kanji>beat</kanji> them together.
data.meaning_hint: A branch is just like a drumstick, so of course you're going to drum them together.
data.reading_mnemonic: Who loves to <kanji>drum</kanji> things together and make a huge racket? <ja><reading>子</reading></ja>s (<ja>こ</ja>), of course.
data.reading_hint: Kids can't get enough of it. Anything that makes a loud drumming noise or anything they can beat together is fun for them.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Move your <radical>coat rack</radical> in one <radical>direction</radical> by shooting it with a <radical>gun</radical>. Then you can keep shooting it to get a good <kanji>rotation</kanji> going. If you think there is a better way to make your coat rack make <kanji>revolution</kanji>s, you're probably wrong.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine getting your coat rack to make rotations in a circle just by shooting it with a gun!
data.reading_mnemonic: As you watch your coat rack's <kanji>rotation</kanji>s a <reading>cen</reading>taur (<ja>せん</ja>) barges in and takes the gun from you, stops the rotating coat rack and leaves. How rude! I guess centaurs don't like when things rotate.
data.reading_hint: Picture that centaurs angry face. Convince yourself it was the rotation it didn't like.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>moon</radical> is <radical>easy</radical> tonight, so you decide to cut it open. But, the moon wasn't the moon, it was your big, pale, round tummy. You just cut it open, and now you can see your <kanji>intestines</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine the moon, then imagine it cross-fading into your big, round tummy. Then, cut it open because you think the moon is easy to cut. And finally, see your intestines as clearly as you can.
data.reading_mnemonic: All over the world, people are cutting their bellies open, because they think its an easy moon (versus a normal moon, or hard moon, presumably). This is because they have fallen victim to a spell by Mrs. <reading>Chou</reading> (<ja>ちょう</ja>).
data.reading_hint: This scene was in all the omen radicals you've been seeing about her. If only you could have stopped her, then none of this would have happened, right? Perhaps it was all destiny, you think, as your intestines fall from your stomach and Mrs. Chou cackles over your weakening body.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tree</radical> melts into the <radical>ground</radical> after listening to loud <radical>music</radical> in the hot <radical>sun</radical>, so you have to find a nice big <kanji>tank</kanji> to scoop the melted tree into. The music made the tree vibrate at juuust the right frequency that it, combined with the hot sun, made the tree turn into a puddle. You can't just leave it being all blobby on the ground, so you find a tank for it.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine scooping a melted tree into a tank. It's a very strange sensation.
data.reading_mnemonic: You're staring at the big <kanji>tank</kanji> when an eerie sound comes out, "Oooh I am the <reading>sou</reading>l (<ja>そう</ja>) of the tree! You've trapped me in this tank and now I'm going to haunt it!" You don't want to be haunted by a tank with a soul stuck in it.
data.reading_hint:
"Um, okay?" you reply to the soul, and walk away from the tank. "W-wait! Tanks can't move? Come back, let me haunt you with my tree soul!"

It's a good thing there weren't wheels on that tank!

data.meaning_mnemonic: If the <radical>leader</radical> of your gang is a <radical>drunkard</radical> he'll try to have you <kanji>fell</kanji> trees thinking they're rival gang members. You all know they aren't but you can't argue with your leader, especially if he's drunk. Go ahead and <kanji>attack</kanji> the trees anyway.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine felling trees with a bunch of other guys, yelling things like, "This is what you get for stepping on my turf!" It's a little silly.
data.reading_mnemonic: As you <kanji>attack</kanji> the innocent trees with your chains and sticks, a bunch of <reading>bats</reading> (<ja>ばつ</ja>) come flying out and attack YOU! You have your own kind of bats so now you're all trying to fell the bats with YOUR bats!
data.reading_hint: Bats attacking bats. Who will win on this season of Survivor?

data.meaning_mnemonic: Take some <radical>tsunami</radical> water and sacrifice the <radical>life</radical> of a <radical>shellfish</radical> to make a liquid you can <kanji>pickle</kanji> in. All pickling liquids are made from 1 part tsunami and 1 part murdered shellfish.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine stabbing a shellfish and dropping it in some water you collected from a tsunami so that you can make your own pickles.
data.reading_mnemonic: You can only <kanji>pickle</kanji> <reading>two</reading> (<ja>つ</ja>) things with the life of one shellfish. Thats a lot of dead critters for not a lot of delicious pickles. Make sure you get a lot of shellfish if you want a full jar.
data.reading_hint: Picture the two pickles that shellfish life got you. They're gonna be the best pickles ever!

data.meaning_mnemonic: The amount of <radical>dirt</radical> you need to get some <radical>peace</radical> is a <kanji>two mat area</kanji>. Two tatami mats, that is. This is a pretty common measurement in Japan, so you should get really familiar with the amount of space that two tatami mats take up together.
data.meaning_hint: Picture how big a two mat area is. Lay down and feel the peace this much space brings to you.
data.reading_mnemonic: A <kanji>two mat area</kanji> also happens to be big enough to hold <reading>two bo</reading>dies (<ja>つぼ</ja>). That's enough space to bring peace to two living, or dead, bodies!
data.reading_hint: Try to picture a two mat area with two bodies laying in it. Whether they're alive or dead is up to you.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you want to turn your <radical>thread</radical> into a <radical>sweet</radical> color you just HAVE to go with <kanji>navy</kanji> or <kanji>dark blue</kanji>. That's the sweetest color in existence, everyone knows that. After all, blue raspberry flavor is dark blue and it's super sweet.
data.meaning_hint: Turn your thread a sweet navy color and people will be reminded of yummy blue raspberry. MmMmm.
data.reading_mnemonic: Now that your threads are <kanji>navy</kanji> colored you need to be careful that <reading>con</reading>dors (<ja>こん</ja>) don't try to steal it for their nests. Condors love <kanji>dark blue</kanji> things and thread is perfect for a condor nest.
data.reading_hint: Imagine a condor stealing your sweet navy thread right after you dyed it, flying off. Lame!

data.meaning_mnemonic: You have a <radical>net</radical> of <radical>thread</radical> for catching a <radical>turkey</radical>. But, it must be <kanji>spread out</kanji> and you must <kanji>arrange</kanji> it first.
data.meaning_hint: The reason you'd use a net made of thread is because it's hard to see. But, it's only that way when you spread out the net. It's important to spread out and arrange your net otherwise the turkey will see it.
data.reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>spread out</kanji> your net and <kanji>arrange</kanji> it just so. You expect it to catch a turkey, but instead you catch the ancient Egyptian god <reading>Ra</reading> (<ja>ら</ja>).
data.reading_hint: "Let me out of this net!" says Ra. "You arranged and spread it out just right so I couldn't see it!"

data.meaning_mnemonic: To the <radical>mountain</radical>s you took your <radical>horned</radical> <radical>husband</radical> for you two to get married. (Society wouldn't accept a horned husband!) To hide even more from the prying eyes of society, you take your horned husband into a <kanji>ravine</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine walking up the mountain in your wedding clothes so you can get married without anyone trying to stop you. Then, because you're still worried, you go into a ravine where you are read your marriage vows.
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>ravine</kanji> is still in <ja><reading>きょう</reading>と</ja> though, because if you went outside the city your marriage wouldn't be legal. So you found a secluded, local ravine.
data.reading_hint: This ravine runs right through the middle of <ja>きょうと</ja>, though most people don't notice it. That makes it the best place for a secret wedding to a horned freak-husband.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> says <radical>spring</radical> is looking <radical>dry</radical>, so you'll need your <kanji>salary</kanji> in advance.
data.meaning_hint: The leader shows you the number, it's all of your salary for spring. "This way, if things dry up worse, you'll be okay for a while," he says. This is awfully nice, but very suspicious at the same time.
data.reading_mnemonic: Your <kanji>salary</kanji> is sent straight to your <reading>ho</reading>me (<ja>ほう</ja>) instead of the bank. Okay, something is definitely fishy here.
data.reading_hint:
You're sitting at home, and there is a knock at the door. A man in a suit, hat, and dark sunglasses hands you a briefcase full of money. "Here's your spring salary. Enjoy the dry weather."

"T-thanks?"

Welp, have fun at home with your stacks of early salary cash.

data.meaning_mnemonic: An <radical>alcohol</radical> <radical>nurse</radical> is someone who nurses alcohol. In other words, they <kanji>brew</kanji> it.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine a nurse brewing alcohol with the same attention they would nurse a human patient. But this brew is much more important than any person's health.
data.reading_mnemonic: A <kanji>brew</kanji> of alcohol is what <reading>Jou</reading>rm (<ja>じょう</ja>) loves most after a long day.
data.reading_hint: As you know, Jourm infiltrated your village and pretended to be a large, simple farmhand, only to bring destruction down upon you. After he was done, he sat down and drank a brew with his Viking buddies.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You give a <radical>bow</radical> and a <radical>stick</radical> to your friend's family. This is because your friend died, and he loved bows and sticks. You give this to his family, to give our <kanji>condolence</kanji>s.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine looking at the bow and stick as you slide them over to your deceased friend's family. This won't do enough, but it is a little condolence at least.
data.reading_mnemonic: More than a <kanji>condolence</kanji>, you want to avenge your friend's death. He was killed by Mrs. <reading>Chou</reading> (<ja>ちょう</ja>), and she broke his stick and bow, which is why you got the family a new set.
data.reading_hint: Imagine her saying, "My condolences," as Mrs. Chou does him in.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>nose</radical> isn't the first thing people see about your face, it's the <kanji>latter</kanji>. They see your eyes THEN your nose, then your mouth, in order going down. Just label them A <kanji>B</kanji> and C and you'll never forget!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine saying A B C as you look down someones face at their eyes, nose and mouth. Their nose is B!
data.reading_mnemonic: If you don't have any cereal you have to eat your <kanji>B</kanji> breakfast option. <reading>Oats</reading> (<ja>おつ</ja>). You don't hate oats, but they're definitely not your first choice.
data.reading_hint: Imagine running out of cereal so you have to eat your latter option of breakfast oats. They aren't awful but they aren't your A breakfast choice, that's for sure.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Riding a <radical>scooter</radical> to the <radical>library</radical> is a <kanji>universal</kanji> experience. People young and old have all, at some point, taken a scooter to the library, picked up a book, used the internet, sat in the comfy chairs, then left via that same scooter.
data.meaning_hint: Scooters and libraries are universally loved by all!
data.reading_mnemonic: Riding a scooter to the library is so <kanji>universal</kanji>, even <reading>hen</reading>s (<ja>へん</ja>) do it.
data.reading_hint: The next time you scoot to the library look around. There are little hen scooters and hens there with their chicks. They're reading them books about grains and how to hatch eggs. It's a universally adorable thing to see.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>go</radical> to a <radical>big</radical> <radical>rice paddy</radical> and establish a <radical>prison</radical> right in the middle of it to restore the <kanji>equilibrium</kanji> of the area.
data.meaning_hint: There was a lot of crime right here in this rice paddy, so you just built a big prison right there to lower the crime rate so this region can experience equilibrium once again.
data.reading_mnemonic: To restore <kanji>equilibrium</kanji> in these parts, you throw all the <ja>耕</ja>ing <ja><reading>こう</reading>いち</ja> clones into the prison.
data.reading_hint: The cloned <ja>こういち</ja>s were causing all the crime in these parts (or so Emperor <ja>こういち</ja> said), so by throwing them in a prison built right there just for them, this area could once again achieve equilibrium.

data.meaning_mnemonic: "For the  <radical>samurai</radical>, it is a <radical>jackhammer</radical> that they will <radical>lack</radical>." That is the latest <kanji>article</kanji> of the law written about samurai, hundreds of years after katana were taken away. This article was written with great <kanji>sincerity</kanji> by the government.
data.meaning_hint: By writing up new articles and laws they keep taking things away from samurai. First the katana, now jackhammers?
data.reading_mnemonic: The one who wrote these <kanji>article</kanji>s with such <kanji>sincerity</kanji> was Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (<ja>かん</ja>).
data.reading_hint: Genghis Khan knew that samurai were a threat to his kingdom, so he took away their secondary weapon, the jackhammer.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Put a <radical>guard</radical> at your <radical>gate</radical> to get a good <kanji>inspection</kanji> of your neighborhood going. The guard will stand there all day inspecting everything and then report it all back to you. You won't have to do any of the inspection yourself!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine the guard doing his inspection in front of the gate all day long. He should have a nice report for you once he's done.
data.reading_mnemonic: His <kanji>inspection</kanji> is complete, but it looks like he's used an <reading>etch</reading> (<ja>えつ</ja>) a sketch to record all the results. That's not really helpful. If you shake it all the inspection results will disappear!
data.reading_hint: If you hire a guard to stand at your gate and conduct an inspection of your neighborhood, make sure you tell him not to use an etch a sketch!

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you put your <radical>spoon</radical> in the <radical>sun</radical> while you're in <radical>prison</radical>, a <radical>mouth</radical> will appear to <kanji>scold</kanji> you. You can never see who the mouth belongs to, but considering you're in prison it's probably a guard. Either way, that person doesn't like what you're doing and they keep scolding you when you put your spoon out into the sun.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine trying to reflect some precious sunlight into your prison room with a spoon. Now imagine a mouth appearing in the way of the sunlight and it scolds you.
data.reading_mnemonic: One day you finally get fed up. You need to know who the mouth of the person who's <kanji>scold</kanji>ing you is. You stick your spoon out into the sun and the mouth appears, scolding you right on time. You reach out and grab them. But in your hand is a pile of <reading>cats</reading> (<ja>かつ</ja>).
data.reading_hint: WHAT KIND OF WORLD IS THIS THAT YOU'RE IN A PRISON WHERE CATS SCOLD YOU?!

data.meaning_mnemonic: An <radical>elf</radical> who ventures outside in <radical>winter</radical> has a lot of <kanji>daring</kanji>. Elf ears are very, very delicate, and the winter cold can really mess them up. So if you see an elf adventuring in winter, know that that particular elf is a really daring dude.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine how much daring it would take to go outside in winter knowing you could be freezing your precious elf ears off.
data.reading_mnemonic: The amount of <kanji>daring</kanji> you'd need is about equal to the amount Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (<ja>かん</ja>) had. And he was really daring!
data.reading_hint: Do you think you have the same amount of daring as an elf going out in winter and Genghis Khan? Tell the truth.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you trap the <radical>moon</radical> in a <radical>greenhouse</radical> it will grow a creepy <kanji>membrane</kanji> around itself. The moon isn't used to the heat it would be exposed to in a greenhouse so that membrane is there to protect it. It's really gross looking though.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine seeing the moon with a membrane sitting stuffed in a greenhouse. It looks like something out of the Alien movies and you're starting to think putting it in there wasn't a good idea.
data.reading_mnemonic: You decide to open the greenhouse to check this moon <kanji>membrane</kanji> out but when you open the door the smell of big <reading>mac</reading>s (<ja>まく</ja>) hits you in the face. Eww. Why does this membrane smell like a big mac... or does that mean big macs smell like a festering moon?
data.reading_hint: Can you imagine if the moon had a membrane and it smelled like a big mac? How does that even happen? You should probably go ask that food chain what they use for their ingredients.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>death</radical> of your <radical>eye</radical>s means that you've gone <kanji>blind</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine what it would be like to have one of your eyes die. You'll be blind in that eye forever!
data.reading_mnemonic: When you're <kanji>blind</kanji> you probably shouldn't drive anymore because if you do you'll <reading>mow</reading> (<ja>もう</ja>) everyone over. Actually, don't mow your lawn either. Blind people probably shouldn't be driving anything.
data.reading_hint: Imagine a blind person mowing over everyone in their car as they drive on the sidewalk. Eeek. At least they don't have to see this mess.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>machine</radical> in your body that is powered by the <radical>moon</radical> is your <kanji>womb</kanji>, also called your <kanji>uterus</kanji>! Haven't you ever wondered why periods happen with the revolutions of the moon? That's because it powers your uterus and tells it what to do!
data.meaning_hint: The next time you're cursing your uterus for making you bleed, curse the moon instead! It's the moon's fault you're in pain.
data.reading_mnemonic: It kind of sucks, but there is no way to sever this <kanji>uterus</kanji> - moon <reading>tie</reading> (<ja>たい</ja>). But if you find a way please tell me, I can't take this anymore.
data.reading_hint: Picture an invisible tie tieing your uterus to the moon. Damn you moon, stop pulling, it hurts!

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Alcohol</radical> is a good <radical>teacher</radical> on the process of <kanji>fermentation</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Because alcohol is so good and addicting, people will work extra hard to ferment it properly. This makes it a good teacher to learn about fermentation. People are motivated to figure it out!
data.reading_mnemonic: Using <kanji>fermentation</kanji>, you are indeed making some alcohol. It will be drunk at a party put on by Emperor <ja><reading>こう</reading>いち</ja>.
data.reading_hint: You are fermenting thousands of bottles of alcohol for Emperor <ja>こういち</ja>'s big party.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Even if you <radical>have</radical> a <radical>building</radical>, it will eventually turn back into <radical>dirt</radical>. Everything will <kanji>degenerate</kanji> eventually. A brick falls off here, a door comes loose there. Nothing can last forever.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine a time lapse video of a building degenerating.
data.reading_mnemonic: As you watch the building <kanji>degenerate</kanji>, you can't help but think of your <reading>da</reading>d (<ja>だ</ja>). You had to watch him waste away the same way of a degenerative disease. Why do people have to die, dad?
data.reading_hint: This may not be a happy thing to think about, but it will help you remember this kanji better. Imagine your dad fighting a degenerative disease. Imagine helping him fight through this. Everything will be okay eventually. I promise.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You're riding your <radical>scooter</radical> toward your <radical>yurt</radical> as fast as you can because someone is trying to get in there to <radical>boil</radical> your water and you want to <kanji>intercept</kanji> them.
data.meaning_hint: If you manage to intercept them before they can go in there to boil things, you'll be able to pick up all the clothes and comic books you left on the floor. You really don't want anyone to see those.
data.reading_mnemonic: You manage to <kanji>intercept</kanji> the <reading>sha</reading>man (<ja>しゃ</ja>) who was just about to open the door to your yurt, and instead you crash right into him.
data.reading_hint: Phew, you intercepted the shaman in time (though she doesn't look very happy about being scooted into) and now you can clean up your yurt before they go in.

data.meaning_mnemonic: An altered <radical>bird</radical> is a <kanji>crow</kanji>! They look like birds but they're bigger and darker and smarter!
data.meaning_hint: See that bird? Wait, that's not just a bird, it's a crow!
data.reading_mnemonic: If you can't tell just from looking at it that it's a <kanji>crow</kanji> and not a bird, walk up to it and <reading>caress</reading> (<ja>からす</ja>) it with your hand! If it caresses you back, it's a crow! If it freaks out and flies away or pecks your face, it's a normal bird. Crows are really smart and like affection. That's what makes them so cool!
data.reading_hint: How many crows have you caressed today?

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>convex</radical> radical and the <kanji>convex</kanji> kanji are the same, so hopefully you now just know them both.
data.meaning_hint: Study your radicals and you'll read good.
data.reading_mnemonic: Is this <kanji>convex</kanji>? It's <reading>totes</reading> (<ja>とつ</ja>) convex!
data.reading_hint: Tote bags are totes not convex though. Don't mix them up.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>concave</radical> radical and the <kanji>concave</kanji> kanji are the same!
data.meaning_hint: Know your radicals, yo!
data.reading_mnemonic: If you call someone <kanji>concave</kanji> the <ja><reading>王</reading></ja> (<ja>おう</ja>) will find out and he'll have his guards turn you concave.
data.reading_hint: Watch your mouth around the <ja>王</ja>. Have you ever seen a concave person? Yeah that's because they didn't live through it. <ja>王</ja>s aren't very nice, you know.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tree</radical> that does well in the <radical>wind</radical> is a <kanji>maple</kanji> tree. Maple trees don't have fruit so the wind can't knock anything off of it. That's why they thrive well in windy places!
data.meaning_hint: Picture a bunch of maple trees being blown by the wind. They don't seem upset, they actually seem really happy.
data.reading_mnemonic: When the wind goes through the <kan>maple</kan> tree you know it's <rd>kite day</rd> (<ja>かえで</ja>)!
data.reading_hint: Imagine your kite in the maple tree.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>drunkard</radical> has <radical>dirt</radical> in his <radical>mouth</radical> as he tries to talk to you. You walk over and he spits a <kanji>question mark</kanji> into your hand. It's covered in dirt and spit. Um... does this mean he's confused? He probably doesn't even know where he is. But how did he make this question mark and why was it in his mouth?
data.meaning_hint: Imagine having a drunkard spit a dirty question mark into your hand. You want to say, "Yes, I'm ??? too."
data.reading_mnemonic: The drunkard takes the <kanji>question mark</kanji> back and presses it to his head. He's wearing a <reading>Ya</reading>nkee's (<ja>や</ja>) cap. Oh come on. "Do you just want to know the Yankee's score in the game?" The drunkard nods.
data.reading_hint: Picture yourself throwing the question mark at the drunkard who only cares about the Yankees. What a waste of time.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Flowers</radical> grown in a <radical>warehouse</radical> will be very <kanji>pale</kanji>. They never see the sun, so they don't grow to have bright colors.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine walking into a warehouse and seeing hundreds of pale flowers growing in it. It's subtle, but beautiful.
data.reading_mnemonic: When you grow <kanji>pale</kanji> flowers like this, they don't grow a <reading>soul</reading> (<ja>そう</ja>). Soul adds color to plants and flowers. That's probably why ghosts and dead bodies are pale too.
data.reading_hint: Picture a bunch of pale, soulless flowers. You pick one up and it falls apart in your hands.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
The <radical>king</radical> will send his men with <radical>sword</radical>s into your <radical>private</radical> <radical>rice paddy</radical> if you come across <kanji>lapis lazuli</kanji>. Even though this is your private land, he wants that lapis lazuli to make some new crowns and thrones for himself. Plus he's the king, so he can do whatever he wants.

If you've never taken an art history class (or played Minecraft) you may never have come across lapis lazuli, but think of it as a pretty, blue precious stone that people really, really liked in the olden days.
data.meaning_hint: Watch the king's swords digging in your private rice paddy and digging up huge chunks of lapis lazuli. This isn't fair, that lapis should belong to you.
data.reading_mnemonic: You run up and ask how this <kanji>lapis lazuli</kanji> thievery isn't illegal and one of the swordsmen just shouts, "<reading>Loo</reading>phole (<ja>る</ja>)!" What? What loophole? What law says that the king gets to steal your stuff?
data.reading_hint: Imagine reading through a giant text called "The Law" and looking for this loophole the king's men claim to have about taking your lapis lazuli. You can't find it... but maybe if you search just a bit longer...

data.meaning_mnemonic: You have to put <radical>flowers</radical> in a <radical>bright</radical> place if you want them to <kanji>sprout</kanji>. If they're left in the shade they'll just rot.
data.meaning_hint: Picture your flowers sprouting out of the ground in the bright spring sun.
data.reading_mnemonic: You want to grow these <kanji>sprout</kanji>s in your <reading>ho</reading>me (<ja>ほう</ja>), not outside. So you need to find the windows in your house that are the brightest.
data.reading_hint: Take a walk around your home right now. Can you find the best place to sprout flowers? Remember, it has to be nice and bright! Not dark and damp. Don't put them in your closet.

data.meaning_mnemonic: There are <radical>stone</radical>s that smell like <radical>trash</radical> in the <radical>river</radical>. You reach in and realize these rocks are made of <kanji>sulfur</kanji>. Even the flow of this water can't hide the stink of these sulfur rocks.
data.meaning_hint: If you haven't smelled sulfur before, it smells a bit like rotten eggs. Something that definitely belongs in the trash.
data.reading_mnemonic: You throw the <kanji>sulfur</kanji> rock as hard as you can, but it hits someone in the back of the head. Oh no, it's <reading>Ryu</reading> (<ja>りゅう</ja>) from Street Fighter. You try to apologize and explain that you just didn't want this stinky trash rock, I mean, sulfur rock near you. You didn't know he was there.
data.reading_hint: Ryu looks down at you, holding the sulfurous rock in one hand. Then he uppercuts you with it! Shoryuken!

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you spill something <radical>red</radical> on yourself in <radical>winter</radical> you should <kanji>pardon</kanji> yourself immediately and try to find something else to wear. It's very dangerous to wear red in winter, and even if it seems rude, make sure you pardon yourself right away and get that taken care of!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine spilling red wine or red paint down your shirt. Quickly pardon yourself and get changed now!
data.reading_mnemonic: If you don't <kanji>pardon</kanji> yourself fast enough the winter <reading>sha</reading>man (<ja>しゃ</ja>) will burst in and cast a spell on you, taking away all the clothes that have red on them! Now you have to pardon yourself for being naked!
data.reading_hint: Imagine not pardoning yourself fast enough and having the winter shaman spirit away whatever you got red on. That's embarrassing.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You see <radical>seven</radical> <radical>sword</radical>s just sitting in a <radical>hole</radical> and so you decide to <kanji>steal</kanji> them. They were just left in that hole after all, it's not like anyone was using them. And even if they were, they'll never know you were the one to steal them, right?
data.meaning_hint: Imagine seeing seven swords just laying abandoned in a hole. Feel the urge to steal them all. Do it, do it!
data.reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>steal</kanji> the swords and realize they aren't just seven random swords, they're from the famous sword <reading>sets</reading> (<ja>せつ</ja>) they sell online. This particular set is from the Seven Samurai movie. Yes! What a great steal!
data.reading_hint: Imagine your delight as you look up the different sword sets online and realize you happened to steal the best one!

data.meaning_mnemonic: Deep in your <radical>soul</radical>, you feel like you want to pull your <radical>fang</radical>s out by the <radical>root</radical>, but instead you let out a loud <kanji>sigh</kanji>. You're one of the only people you know that has fangs, and it weighs heavily on your soul.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine all of the other people staring and pointing, the kids making fun of you, no one seeing you as equal. And just... sigh. Deep down, you want to get rid of your fangs, but you can't do it.
data.reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>sigh</kanji> again and say, "I wish I was just a normal <reading>guy</reading> (<ja>がい</ja>)." I swear the rest of me is a guy like the rest of you. *sigh*
data.reading_hint: Now you're staring in the mirror at yourself. You sigh loudly and take out the pliers. You'll be a guy like everyone else. S-soon. As soon as you can muster up enough strength to stop sighing and rip these fangs out.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Put your <radical>fingers</radical> on your <radical>husband</radical> to <kanji>aid</kanji> him. There's something about a spouse's touch that just makes you feel better. Have you ever had someone rub your back while you were hurt or sick or sad? It's nice, right?
data.meaning_hint: Imagine rubbing your husband's back with your fingers to aid him. You want him to feel better. You want him to get that comforting feeling that this kind of touching gives.
data.reading_mnemonic: Unfortunately, your husband wouldn't need your <kanji>aid</kanji> if he wasn't such a <reading>foo</reading>l (<ja>ふ</ja>). He walks into doors, he falls down the stairs, he touches the plate when the waiter says it's hot. And every single time your fool husband hurts himself, you aid him.
data.reading_hint: That's true love, my friend.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Throw a <radical>drunkard</radical> in a cage with a <radical>tiger</radical> and some <radical>spikes</radical> and the tiger will have the time of its life <kanji>play</kanji>ing with them! Think of all the tiger play time possibilities!
data.meaning_hint: If you were the tiger how would you play with the drunkard?
data.reading_mnemonic: If you aren't the tiger, watching it <kanji>play</kanji> is a little like watching someone's head get cut off with a <reading>gui</reading>llotine (<ja>ぎ</ja>). In fact, you don't want to watch it play at all anymore.
data.reading_hint: What would you rather watch? A guillotine at work or a tiger playing like this?

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you only let <radical>oneself</radical> (yourself) into your <radical>heart</radical>, you'll end up <kanji>mourning</kanji> all of the loves and friendships you could have had but didn't let in.
data.meaning_hint: Picture yourself all alone. You never let anyone into your heart but yourself, and now you're mourning the life and friends you could have had.
data.reading_mnemonic: While you're in <kanji>mourning</kanji>, you feel a sharp pain in your crying eyes. A <reading>key</reading> (<ja>き</ja>) comes sliding out with your tears. You look around wildly, but you're still alone. Is this... the key of mourning?
data.reading_hint: You try to push the key back into your body. Back into your eye, you even try to swallow it, but it comes back out. Finally you look down at your mourning heart and try the key there. It clicks. And opens.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If a <radical>tsunami</radical> gets into a <radical>net</radical> that's im<radical>prison</radical>ing a bunch of <radical>insect</radical>s, the insects are going to get all <kanji>muddy</kanji>. The net gets dragged along with the tsunami water and the insects can't escape, so they just get covered in the yucky stuff.
data.meaning_hint: Picture a net prison full of insects being dragged by a tsunami getting muddier and muddier. Poor buggles!
data.reading_mnemonic: Unfortunately for the insects, these <kanji>muddy</kanji> conditions have created the perfect habitat for <reading>duck</reading>s (<ja>だく</ja>). And muddy insects already imprisoned in a muddy net is a duck's favorite treat!
data.reading_hint: Picture a bunch of muddy ducks munching on some muddy trapped insects, in a some muddy leftover tsunami water.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You're walking down the street when you see <radical>twenty</radical> <radical>big</radical> <radical>cross</radical>es lined up in front of you. Crosses creep you out and this is way too many for you to keep walking so you decide to <kanji>run</kanji> as fast as you can to get past them.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine trying to run down a street with twenty big crosses lining it. It's so scary that you keep running faster and faster as you go.
data.reading_mnemonic: You figure since you're already on the <kanji>run</kanji> that you might as well <reading>hone</reading> (<ja>ほん</ja>) your running skills while you make your way down this scary, cross lined street.
data.reading_hint: Imagine distracting yourself from the scary crosses by honing your running skills while you do it.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You see a <radical>triceratops</radical> standing in front of a full <radical>moon</radical> and you can't help but see a really strong <kanji>resemblance</kanji>. The triceratops has that round frill thing behind its horns and it looks just like the round full moon. Who knew that a triceratops would resemble the moon!
data.meaning_hint: Look at the triceratops. Now look at the moon. See the resemblance? Uncanny, don't you think?
data.reading_mnemonic: The first person to see this <kanji>resemblance</kanji> was the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (<ja>しょう</ja>). That's why he decided to put a triceratops head with the moon behind it on his mon (family crest). Now he's known as the full moon dinosaur shogun, and he's very famous.
data.reading_hint: Imagine being the Shougun and seeing the resemblance between a triceratops and the moon for the first time. You'd put that on all your stuff too, if you were him.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tree</radical> is stuck in a <radical>prison</radical> under the <radical>ground</radical> and it's starting to <kanji>rot</kanji> and <kanji>decay</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Trees can't live without sunlight, and it's too damp underground in a prison. The water gets all moldy and the tree will rot and die.
data.reading_mnemonic: You get close to the <kanji>rot</kanji>ting tree and see some rotten <reading>cu</reading>cumbers (<ja>きゅう</ja>) hanging from its branches. No!
data.reading_hint: This poor cucumber tree, left in this ground prison to rot. There's nothing worse than eating a rotten cucumber.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>samurai</radical> puts his <radical>forehead</radical> on the <radical>table</radical> next to his <radical>weapon</radical>. He is just a <kanji>husk</kanji> of his former self. This <kanji>shell</kanji> of a samurai has nothing left.
data.meaning_hint: He's just sitting there, he can't even pick up his weapon or raise his head anymore.
data.reading_mnemonic: The only way to bring a <kanji>husk</kanji> of a samurai back to life is to have a <reading>cock</reading> (<ja>かく</ja>) crow right in his ear.
data.reading_hint: "Co co co co cooooock!" the cock screams, shocking the samurai back into his lifeless shell. You did it!

data.meaning_mnemonic: If someone gives you a <radical>sock</radical> you should <kanji>receive</kanji> it and thank them. You can't just say no or put the sock on the ground and walk away. You should always receive a sock properly, with both hands, when it's handed to you.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine Dobby reaching out to receive his first sock. Don't you want to be happy like that too?
data.reading_mnemonic: The best place to <kanji>receive</kanji> a sock is in <ja><reading>きょう</reading>と</ja>. They're famous for their sock stores and schoolgirls who have too many socks. If you walk down the street someone is bound to try to hand you a sock in <ja>きょうと</ja>, and you should receive it happily.
data.reading_hint: Imagine standing in <ja>きょうと</ja> and receiving sock after sock. People just keep giving and you keep receiving!

data.meaning_mnemonic: You have to reach a certain <radical>number</radical> of <radical>flowers</radical> and <radical>tsunami</radical>s hits to become a legitimate <kanji>fiefdom</kanji>. At least in the old days. If you don't meet one of these conditions, like if you get hit by tsunamis all the time but you only have two or three flowers that will grow, you can't be your own fiefdom.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine being the person who has to check whether each fiefdom has enough flowers and tsunamis per year to keep their status.
data.reading_mnemonic: The most famous <kanji>fiefdom</kanji> checker is <reading>Han</reading> (<ja>はん</ja>) Solo. He takes his Millennium Falcon and swoops around checking for flowers and signs of past tsunamis and then he'll either say you can or cannot be your own fiefdom. Thanks Han Solo!
data.reading_hint: Picture Han Solo flying around Japan checking to make sure all the fiefdoms are up to code.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>sweet</radical> <radical>woman</radical> sits under a <radical>tree</radical> and works as a <kanji>mediator</kanji>. If you're having a fight with someone, bring them to the sweet woman under the tree and she'll mediate for the two of you. Problem solved! Thanks sweet lady!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine the sweet tree woman being a mediator for you and your arch rival. What she says fixes everything between you two!
data.reading_mnemonic: You go to pay the woman for being your <kanji>mediator</kanji> for you two but she just says, "<reading>Bye</reading> <ja>ばい</ja>)." You try to hand her some money and she stares into your eyes. "Bye." Oh... okay, bye then.
data.reading_hint: Imagine her refusing to let you pay her for her mediator services and just saying "bye" over and over until you leave. Weird.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>husband</radical> was wearing his <radical>cleats</radical> when he accidentally stepped on a <radical>bird</radical>. Luckily this particular bird is a <kanji>chicken</kanji>, and chickens are really durable!
data.meaning_hint: Picture the sad, stepped on chicken. It's angrily clucking and chasing your husband around your yard for what he did.
data.reading_mnemonic: The only way to stop the <kanji>chicken</kanji> from putting on your husband's cleats and stepping on him to death in revenge is to feed it the <reading>ca</reading>ke (<ja>けい</ja>) you were making.
data.reading_hint: This cake was for your husband, but now he gets nothing. The chicken gets to eat all of the cake in front of him instead.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you want to take a <radical>flag</radical> out of the <radical>mouth</radical> of a <radical>mantis</radical> you have to make a formal <kanji>request</kanji> first. Mantises don't like to just give things away, and they're kind of mean so if you try to steal the flag it will probably bite you. So make a formal, polite request if you want it.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine trying to request a flag from a scary mantis that has it sitting in it's mouth. Will it give it to you? Will it bite you? You'll have to wait and see.
data.reading_mnemonic: After you <kanji>request</kanji> the mantis give you its flag it <reading>shock</reading>s (<ja>しょく</ja>) you by actually spitting it out of its mouth at your feet. You didn't think your request would work, or even if the mantis understood human speech, but it shocked you by doing exactly what you asked!
data.reading_hint: Imagine your shock at finding out the mantis not only understood your request, but agreed! This is great but also makes you wonder what other creatures can understand you...

data.meaning_mnemonic: When your <radical>scooter</radical> has a <radical>fault</radical>, you need to get an <kanji>alternate</kanji>. Hopefully your insurance will cover it too.
data.meaning_hint: You have a scooter that you drive every single day, but if you notice a fault, you need to send it in to get it fixed. That's when you break out your alternate scooter.
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>alternate</kanji> scooter is made entirely of <ja><reading>鉄</reading></ja> (<ja>てつ</ja>). It's hard and cold and not very comfortable when you sit on it. That's why you chose to keep it as an alternate and not as your everyday scooter.
data.reading_hint: Imagine riding on your alternate <ja>鉄</ja> scooter. Feel the hard iron under your bum and the loud sounds it makes as you scoot down the street. I hope your normal scooter is fixed soon.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The only <radical>tree</radical> a <radical>turkey</radical> will live in is an <kanji>oak</kanji> tree. They really only do this because oak trees have really yummy acorns and turkeys loooove acorns.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine seeing a turkey sitting in an oak tree munching on acorns. You didn't even know turkeys could fly, but it got up there somehow.
data.reading_mnemonic: If you see a bunch of <kanji>oak</kanji>s but no turkeys just yell, "<reading>SOOEY</reading> (<ja>つい</ja>)!" and they'll all come jumping out! Just because you can't see a turkey in there doesn't mean there isn't one!
data.reading_hint: Imagine standing in a grove of oak trees and yelling SOOEY! SOOOOOEY! Now watch as hundreds of turkeys come flying at your face! They think you have more acorns for them. RUN!

data.meaning_mnemonic: Put <radical>thread</radical> in the <radical>mouth</radical> of a worm while the <radical>moon</radical> is out and it will poop out some <kanji>silk</kanji>. That's why they call them silkworms, didn't you know? But it has to be while the moon is out, otherwise normal thread will come right back out the other end of the worm. The moon is what makes the magic happen.
data.meaning_hint: Picture feeding some thread into the mouth of a worm as the light from the full moon shines in on you. See the silk come out of the worm's butt and into your hands.
data.reading_mnemonic: The biggest fan of <kanji>silk</kanji> is <reading>Ken</reading> (<ja>けん</ja>) the samurai. Everything he wears is silk, even his armor.
data.reading_hint: Picture Ken with a silk helmet, silk fundoshi, and a silk sheath for his sword.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>building</radical> <radical>clown</radical> is the only clown allowed to <kanji>accompany</kanji> you. You hate all clowns, and so does the rest of your town. But this clown is really good at building buildings, and he's allowed to leave his part of town and accompany you while you fix buildings together.
data.meaning_hint: I know it's been a long time, but try not to mix this one up with 	<ja>部</ja>, if you can. Remember, the clown building is in another part of town and the clowns aren't supposed to leave. But the building clown is okay to accompany you through the rest of the city.
data.reading_mnemonic: He can only <kanji>accompany</kanji> you for so long though and soon it's time to say <reading>bye</reading> (<ja>ばい</ja>) again.
data.reading_hint: Wave bye to the clown, he'll accompany you on your building job tomorrow, but right now he has to go home and be with the rest of his clown people. He can't accompany you after dark.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>clown</radical> takes a <radical>knife</radical> and <kanji>divide</kanji>s himself. First he divides himself into two pieces, then he's in four pieces, then... oh why won't he stop?!
data.meaning_hint: Instead of dying, the clown divides into slightly thinner clowns.
data.reading_mnemonic: The clown finally stops trying to <kanji>divide</kanji> himself, and you can't stand to look at all of him. You grab a <reading>bow</reading>ling (<ja>ぼう</ja>) ball and bowl all of his divided parts over!
data.reading_hint: The many clowns crash to the floor as the bowling ball plows through their... his(?) divided bodies. You can't bear to look anymore.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
If you <radical>say</radical> the <radical>lineup</radical> of your family members that have lived on this earth under the <radical>sun</radical>, you're really explaining your <kanji>genealogy</kanji>.

This kanji has a second meaning too. It means score. So if you're <radical>say</radical>ing the <radical>line up</radical> of what happened today under the <radical>sun</radical> you're really just saying the <kanji>score</kanji> of a game. So which is it? Are you talking about the past or something that happened today? That's what makes the difference.
data.meaning_hint: Say the line up of what happened under the sun. It's the genealogy of your family or the score of your game!
data.reading_mnemonic: if you can't tell the difference between your <kanji>genealogy</kanji> and a game's <kanji>score</kanji> you're a <reading>foo</reading>l (<ja>ふ</ja>) and I can't help you. You aren't a fool, are you? You know the difference.
data.reading_hint: Your family genealogy and your game's score aren't even close to being the same thing. Memorize these or everyone will think you're a fool.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You can only manage to avoid a <radical>tsunami</radical> by standing <radical>above</radical> it on a <radical>small</radical> <radical>stool</radical> if you are very <kanji>graceful</kanji>. If you aren't graceful enough the tsunami will knock you and the stool over and you'll be swept away like everyone else.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine being graceful enough to balance on a small stool above a raging tsunami! Sooo cool!
data.reading_mnemonic: No matter how <kanji>graceful</kanji> you are, the still tsunami <reading>shook</reading> (<ja>しゅく</ja>) the small stool. That's where your gracefulness came in. The stool shook, but you didn't. You balanced yourself and refused to go down.
data.reading_hint: It doesn't matter how badly the stool shook, you stayed graceful and didn't fall!

data.meaning_mnemonic: You hoist your <radical>towel</radical> above your <radical>table</radical>, <radical>drop</radical> into the water and <kanji>sail</kanji> away. You turned the towel into an actual sail and you're balancing on top of the table, which is now a boat.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine sailing out into the open sea, drops of water hitting your face, as the towel sail catches the air and carries you away.
data.reading_mnemonic: As you <kanji>sail</kanji> off into the ocean you hear a familiar voice shout out, "Ahoy!" <reading>Han</reading> (<ja>はん</ja>) Solo calls. He's also got a towel sail, but it's on the Millennium Falcon, which is half-submerged in the water.
data.reading_hint: You sail nervously past Han Solo who also seems to be sailing, though in worse shape than you. But he keeps throwing you finger guns so you figure it's best to just sail on and pretend this never happened.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You see a <radical>soul</radical> on a <radical>cross</radical> covered in <radical>flowers</radical> with <radical>shellfish</radical> at its feet and you suddenly <kanji>resent</kanji> them. It's not like you want to be the one up there on the cross, but so many people left flowers and shellfish for them. It should have been you...
data.meaning_hint: Picture the soul on the cross, flowers all around it and shellfish at its feet. Feel your resentment grow.
data.reading_mnemonic: You realize you <kanji>resent</kanji> them because it looks like they're having <reading>fun</reading> (<ja>ふん</ja>). You aren't having fun, and you wanna be! How dare they have fun when you aren't!
data.reading_hint: You wanna have fun hanging out on a cross with flowers and all the shellfish you can eat. Your resentment grows and grows as you watch the soul having everything you suddenly want.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Pour all of your <radical>alcohol</radical> in the <radical>pool</radical> to <kanji>serve</kanji> all your guests at once! They can all help themselves to as much or as little alcohol as they want! What a great idea!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine serving all of your guests their alcohol by dumping it all in the pool! Now jump in and drink all you want!
data.reading_mnemonic: As you <kanji>serve</kanji> your guests (and yourself) you look over and see <reading>Shaq</reading> (<ja>しゃく</ja>) also trying to serve them. And by serving I mean getting served because he's throwing them into the pool.
data.reading_hint: Picture Shaq serving your guests by tossing them into your alcohol filled pool. Thanks, Shaq... I guess.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Gambler</radical>s usually only see the <radical>sun</radical> at <kanji>dawn</kanji>. They gamble all day and through the night, and if they leave it's at the crack of dawn to get home, clean up, and then go back. I haven't known a gambler who's seen the sun ... well ever!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine being a gambler and seeing the bright dawn sun when you come out of the casino or pachinko parlor. It burns your eyes! Evil dawn, get back inside quick!
data.reading_mnemonic: If you're up at <kanji>dawn</kanji> you'll also see the <ja><reading>あか</reading></ja> (red) <ja><reading>つき</reading></ja> (moon). The <ja>あかつき</ja> only happens as the sun comes up at dawn so usually only gamblers see it. But if you get up early, you can see it too!
data.reading_hint: Imagine getting up at dawn and seeing the <ja>あかつき</ja> in the sky near the sun. It's so beautiful!

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> does a <radical>dance</radical> on top of the <radical>tree</radical> to show his <kanji>greatness</kanji> to everyone around. If he dances all the way up there on top of the tree, then no one can deny his <kanji>excellence</kanji>!
data.meaning_hint: "Look upon your leader's greatness!" he shouts, doing a jig around on the branches.
data.reading_mnemonic: If you don't recognize the leader's <kanji>greatness</kanji> he will throw <reading>ketsu</reading>p (<ja>けつ</ja>) all over you (it's a special mix of ketchup and catsup). And it's ketsup because it looks like blood. The blood he'll spill if you don't look up and clap at his great dancing.
data.reading_hint: "Oh leader, your greatness is so... great!" you shout up at him. He's holding the ketsup bottle over your head and staring into your eyes as he dances in the tree. He isn't sure if he wants to dump it on you yet. He isn't sure if you really recognize his excellence.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This is a <radical>gold</radical> <radical>roof</radical>, <radical>correct</radical>? It's important to <kanji>lock</kanji> it up, then.
data.meaning_hint: It's only natural that you'd want to lock a gold roof so nobody can steal it.
data.reading_mnemonic: The person who <kanji>lock</kanji>ed the gold roof was <reading>Jou</reading>rm (<ja>じょう</ja>).
data.reading_hint: He's the big farmhand who turned out to be an undercover Viking in your town, only to pillage and destroy everything. Under the gold roof is where he locked up all your village's valuables, after wiping you all out.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you touch <radical>ice</radical> for too long you'll get <radical>frostbite</radical> and that's a really hard thing to <kanji>endure</kanji>. A lot of people can't, and die. Then again, you managed to endure touching ice long enough to get frostbite in the first place, so maybe this is baby stuff for you.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine having to endure the pain of frostbite because you were a jerk who put his hand on ice for a few hours.
data.reading_mnemonic: The best people in the world at being able to <kanji>endure</kanji> the pain are the <reading>shino</reading>bi (<ja>しの</ja>) ninjas! They train by hanging out in frozen areas all the time and don't complain at all. Maybe if the pain gets to be too much you can go ask them for advice.
data.reading_hint: Imagine if you were one of these cool Shinobi ninjas that could endure the extreme cold and pain of frostbite!

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>king</radical> <radical>rake</radical>d all the <radical>mountain</radical>s down into flat land so he could see everyone in the kingdom from his castle windows. You should share your <kanji>congratulations</kanji> with him. Now, quick tell him this was a great idea.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine saying "Congratulations!" to a king who just ordered his servants to rake down all the pretty mountains in his kingdom.
data.reading_mnemonic: The moment you say "<kanji>Congratulations</kanji>!" you've already started to <reading>miss</reading> (<ja>みず</ja>) those beautiful mountains. But you can't let missing them ruin your congratulations! Don't let the king know!
data.reading_hint: Imagine how hollow your congratulation sounds when you really miss those mountains. This king doesn't deserve your nice words.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>flowers</radical> that grow on your <radical>roof</radical> that look like a sleeping <radical>bear</radical> is <kanji>sedge</kanji>. Sedge grow all over the world!
data.meaning_hint: You've probably seen them before, you just didn't know what they were called! Looks like a green sleeping bear bum, right?
data.reading_mnemonic: The next time you see a <kanji>sedge</kanji> bite into it. It tastes like <reading>suga</reading>r (<ja>すが</ja>)! Luckily, it don't taste like bear.
data.reading_hint: Imagine biting into a sedge flower and tasting the yummy sugary taste. Mmmm.

data.meaning_mnemonic: As the <radical>tsunami</radical> hits your <radical>scooter</radical> and your <radical>car</radical>, it alters the wave, creating <kanji>ripples</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: They're hard to see because a tsunami is pretty big, but your scooter and car do create ripples in the water as it goes past.
data.reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Ripples</kanji> come off of your scooter and car from when they were hit by a tsunami. More importantly, those things were <reading>ren</reading>tals (<ja>れん</ja>), so ripples or not, it doesn't matter if they were hit by a tsunami.
data.reading_hint: As you watch the ripples come off your car / scooter, be sure to imagine the relief you'd feel if you knew they were rentals and not something owned by you.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>king</radical> wants you to make a <radical>rocket</radical> that looks <kanji>glassy</kanji>. It won't be very stable, and it probably won't work, but making it glassy and pretty is the only way to make the king will approve.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine a king who won't accept a rocket that isn't made of glassy material. He's not very smart...
data.reading_mnemonic: You take the <kanji>glassy</kanji> rocket and try to stuff some thin <reading>reed</reading>s (<ja>り</ja>) inside to support it. But because it's clear and glassy the king sees them at the last second.
data.reading_hint: Picture the king admiring himself in the glassy surface and then his face contorts. He smashes his fist through the rocket and rips out the reeds. "REEDS AREN'T GLASSY!" he cries, and starts hitting you with them.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Going from a <radical>scooter</radical> to a <radical>helicopter</radical> that's <radical>big</radical> even for yourself (<radical>oneself</radical>), is huge <kanji>transition</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: It's an upward transition, so that's nice, but it's still going to take you a long time to get used to using a big helicopter instead of a scooter.
data.reading_mnemonic: You decide one <kanji>transition</kanji> isn't enough, so you transition to a <reading>cen</reading>taur (<ja>せん</ja>) too. Now you're a big half horse-half human creature and you'll fit in the big helicopter better.
data.reading_hint: A centaur is just a human halfway between transitioning into a horse, so it isn't even that hard to do!

data.meaning_mnemonic: You have to use your <radical>fingers</radical> to make an <radical>exit</radical> because you're so <kanji>clumsy</kanji>. You can't seem to get the door to open, your hands just slip around on the nob uselessly. Instead, you take your fingers and stick them into the door frame, pulling the whole thing off the hinges so you can leave.
data.meaning_hint: Of course, you're too clumsy to do that right either, you accidentally threw the door backwards and hurt some people...
data.reading_mnemonic: After you make your <kanji>clumsy</kanji> mistake you realize that these doors come in <reading>sets</reading> (<ja>せつ</ja>). And now you have to try to open another door. And another door. So many sets of doors!
data.reading_hint: Imagine trying to use your clumsy fingers all over the sets of doors. You keep falling over and hurting yourself. Why is it so hard to leave?!

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you look at what's <radical>above</radical> and <radical>below</radical> a <radical>mountain</radical> you'll just see a bunch of <kanji>ridge</kanji>s. Mountains are made of ridges going up and down, that's why they're so pointy and so hard to climb.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine looking off the edge of a mountain at all the big ridges going above and below it.
data.reading_mnemonic: It's only on this type of mountain <kanji>ridge</kanji> that you'll be able to find the rare and adorable <reading>To</reading>kyo <reading>ge</reading>cko (<ja>とうげ</ja>). These tiny little critters can only be found on the ridges going above and below the mountains in Tokyo. There are like six mountains in Tokyo, so the next time you're scaling the ridges keep your eyes open for the Tokyo gecko!
data.reading_hint: Picture yourself sitting on a mountain ridge in Tokyo and watching a little Tokyo gecko run up and down on them. It's adorable and totally worth the climb.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If someone makes a <radical>bamboo</radical> <radical>horse</radical>, you know it's <kanji>deliberate</kanji>. You can't accidentally make an entire horse out of bamboo.
data.meaning_hint: Someone sat down and deliberately planned the entire horse out, collected the materials, and made it by hand.
data.reading_mnemonic: As you admire all the <kanji>deliberate</kanji> details in this bamboo horse, the ghost of <reading>Toku</reading>gawa (<ja>とく</ja>) Ieyasu appears before you! "I deliberately made this horse to show you how important being deliberate is. You should be absolutely certain and decisive about your decisions."
data.reading_hint: Tokugawa Ieyasu then poofs out of existence and so does the bamboo horse.

data.meaning_mnemonic: There were lots of things that were <radical>above</radical> you when you were <radical>small</radical> that you would need a <radical>stool</radical> to reach, so you just asked your <kanji>aunt</kanji> or <kanji>uncle</kanji> to get them for you.
data.meaning_hint: Your parents didn't want you having those things, which is why they put them up high, but your aunt and uncle would always spoil you and get them for you.
data.reading_mnemonic: You ask your <kanji>aunt</kanji> and <kanji>uncle</kanji> to help you reach your special <reading>o</reading>bi (<ja>お</ja>) from high up in the closet.
data.reading_hint: You aren't supposed to wear your obi unless it's a special occasion, but your aunt and uncle don't know that. Now you can run around with it on your head and your parents can't stop you by putting it up high!

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you can <radical>stop</radical> a <radical>turkey</radical> by putting a <radical>spoon</radical> in its face you'll know it's a <kanji>female</kanji> turkey. A male turkey will peck the spoon out of your hand and run away. But a female turkey will wonder why you're putting a spoon there, stop, and look up at you wondering if you're okay.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the female turkey stopping when it sees you holding out a spoon. Why are you doing that human? it thinks. Are you sick?
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>female</kanji> turkey then runs around making a <reading>mess</reading> (<ja>めす</ja>) of things trying to figure out what's wrong with you. She kicks around her hay, water bowl, and scratches at your pants, making more mess marks on them. But you don't move and she gets even more worried.
data.reading_hint: Imagine watching a female turkey make a mess of her own cage because she thinks you need help. How sweet.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If there is <radical>dirt</radical> in a <radical>crab trap</radical>, it's a lot for the crabs to <kanji>endure</kanji>. Lots of crabs can't endure this and die before they're hauled out of the sea. The ones that are living are going to die once they're out anyway, so all they can do is try to endure what's about to happen as best they can.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine being a little crab, getting stuck in a crab trap with dirt and other crabs. Endure the horror as long as you can, little friend.
data.reading_mnemonic: The little crab who <kanji>endure</kanji>s being stuck in a dirty crab trap just ends up being turned into a seafood <reading>ta</reading>co (<ja>た</ja>). It held out as long as it could, but then it was chopped up and turned into taco filling.
data.reading_hint: The next time you eat a crab taco, think about what the crab had to endure for you to get your meal. I hope you're happy with yourself!

data.meaning_mnemonic: We want you to say things with your <radical>mouth</radical> right <radical>now</radical> because it's <kanji>recital</kanji> time! Go, perform please. What do you mean you didn't know the recital was right now? Well, tough luck. Recite!
data.meaning_hint: The recital is happening now. So open your mouth and start already!
data.reading_mnemonic: Here, if you are too afraid to start the <kanji>recital</kanji> now drink this <reading>gin</reading> (<ja>ぎん</ja>) to get your courage up. But once you're done drinking it the recital starts!
data.reading_hint: Drink gin before all your recitals! It'll help!

data.meaning_mnemonic: Making a mnemonic for a <radical>crab trap</radical> is <kanji>VERY</kanji> hard. So hard that I couldn't come up with one. But it's very possible that one of you will!
data.meaning_hint: How hard is it to come up with a good mnemonic for a crab trap? Very hard!
data.reading_mnemonic: You know what else is <kanji>very</kanji> something? <reading>Jean</reading>s (<ja>じん</ja>). Jeans are very expensive. Jeans are very tight. Jeans are very popular. Jeans are very a lot of things.
data.reading_hint: How many sentences can you make with very and jeans? More than me I hope.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Under the <radical>mountain</radical>'s <radical>roof</radical> are people using <radical>jackhammer</radical>s to <kanji>worship</kanji> the gods. The noise from their jackhammering echos up through the mountain and up toward the sky where the gods live. As long as each person uses their own jackhammer, the sound will be loud enough to reach them.
data.meaning_hint: Man your own jackhammer! (And worship the gods.)
data.reading_mnemonic: Unfortunately, the people who live around here can also hear you and the others <kanji>worship</kanji> in the mountain and they're going to <reading>sue</reading> (<ja>すう</ja>) you for the noise.
data.reading_hint: You try to argue that you can't sue someone for the way they choose to worship, but they say they're all deaf now, all the animals have gone, and no one sleeps anymore because of the shaking. Yikes, they might have a case!

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> hits a <radical>tree</radical> and your <radical>hat</radical> protects you from the <radical>water</radical>, but the hat itself is now covered in <kanji>lacquer</kanji>. You take it off and see that it's shiny and hard and protected.
data.meaning_hint: Picture your hat and all of the other things the tsunami + tree water touched. It's all been hardened with a thick coating of the lacquer.
data.reading_mnemonic: You decide to scoop up the rest of the <kanji>lacquer</kanji> water and use it on your furniture to protect it from your <reading>shih tzu</reading> (<ja>しつ</ja>). Now it can't bite or scratch or ruin any of your things anymore!
data.reading_hint: Watch as your shih tzu tries to bite your now lacquered chair. It gets its teeth around the leg, but it's hard as a rock. The shih tzu starts sneezing and spitting, letting go. Looks like it tastes bad too. Perfect!

data.meaning_mnemonic: You see a <radical>mountain</radical> in the shape of a <radical>turtle shell</radical> sticking out into the ocean. It's a <kanji>cape</kanji>! No, not the kind you wear, the geographical kind. When you're on land, most capes look like turtle shell mountains sticking out into the sea. Do you know any capes like that near where you live?
data.meaning_hint: Picture the turtle shell shaped cape. Feel the salty wind in your hair!
data.reading_mnemonic: You decide to walk along this <kanji>cape</kanji> because it looks like the perfect place to get rid of your old <reading>me</reading>at <reading>sack</reading> (<ja>みさき</ja>). It's starting to smell, but the ocean breeze from the cape pulls the meat sack out of your hands and off into the sky (then probably into the sea too).
data.reading_hint: The next time you go to the cape, remember to bring your old, used meat sack. You can toss it right into the ocean and it won't bother you ever again! Just make sure no one sees you.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Move <radical>thread</radical> in the right <radical>direction</radical> and you'll end up <kanji>spinning</kanji> it into yarn. Then you can spin that yarn into a sweater or a scarf with your favorite half tofu half fugu mascot on it!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine spinning thread into whatever your imagination wants.
data.reading_mnemonic: While you're <kanji>spinning</kanji> you realize that you've always wanted to make your own <reading>bow</reading>ling (<ja>ぼう</ja>) ball. And bowling ball cover. And bowling ball shoes.
data.reading_hint: Picture all of these thread-made bowling items. You're a really big bowling fan, huh?

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>stone</radical> that looks like a <radical>turkey</radical> <radical>boil</radical>ing underwater is just a <kanji>reef</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: It may seem like there are a bunch of turkeys under there, but it's just the shape the reef takes. Though I guess if you're looking from above the water it really does look like a bunch of turkeys freaking out.
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>reef</kanji> is the <reading>Shou</reading>gun's (<ja>しょう</ja>) favorite place to be nowadays. He sits next to the water, and stares down into it for hours.
data.reading_hint: You don't know if the Shougun likes the reef because he likes the beauty of the ocean, or if he's fantasizing about turkeys boiling. He's a... complex man.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>barracks</radical> radical and the <kanji>barracks</kanji> kanji are the same!
data.meaning_hint: Know your radicals, yo!
data.reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Barracks</kanji> are pretty big, so they weigh a <reading>ton</reading> (<ja>とん</ja>). And they probably take tons of materials to build.
data.reading_hint: Imagine trying to lift some barracks. They weigh a ton! How are you supposed to do this? Why would you even try to lift something that obviously weighs a couple tons?!

data.meaning_mnemonic: You meet a <radical>woman</radical> whose <radical>mouth</radical> is <radical>big</radical> and you instantly know this is the person you want to <kanji>marry</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: When you think about the person you want to marry, picture their mouth wide in a big, beautiful smile, a wide-open laugh. That's the lady for you, alright!
data.reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>marry</kanji> this woman right away and you both go straight to an <reading>inn</reading> (<ja>いん</ja>) together!
data.reading_hint: When you get to the inn all you do is make her laugh and smile so you can bask in her bright, big, mouth smiles.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You try to use your <radical>fingers</radical> to cast <radical>doubt</radical> on people by using them to <kanji>imitate</kanji> each other. Right now you're using your fingers as finger puppets, imitating one of your friends to the others.
data.meaning_hint: Picture your angry friend standing up next to your fingers, shouting, "I'm the real me! That's just an imitation!" The rest of your friends look nervously at each other. They doubt this person is real now.
data.reading_mnemonic: Everyone thinks the friend you were trying to <kanji>imitate</kanji> is the imitation now and they have them in a <reading>gui</reading>llotine (<ja>ぎ</ja>). You even doubt if they're an imitation or if your fingers are the imitation.
data.reading_hint: Okay, so that's a lie, Your fingers are definitely imitating them, but you don't want to end up in the guillotine so you keep your mouth shut.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you see someone <radical>eye</radical>ing your <radical>womb</radical> you're probably going to be weirded out by how <kanji>friendly</kanji> they're acting. You only let people who are really, really close to you look at your womb. So if this guy is acting that friendly he should have introduced himself first.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine having someone you aren't friendly with trying to have a look at your womb. No thank you.
data.reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>friendly</kanji> guy comes up to you and start to introduce himself, "<ja><reading>ぼく</reading></ja>-" but you stop him. He's been getting way too friendly with your womb and you don't want to hear who he is. He can <ja>ぼく</ja> at someone else, you're out.
data.reading_hint: Imagine only letting this guy start to introduce himself with <ja>ぼく</ja> before walking the heck outta there. Just because he was acting friendly doesn't mean he was actually your friend.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You see a <radical>gate</radical> with a <radical>tree</radical> growing through it and it reminds you that you need more <kanji>leisure</kanji> time. You walk up to the gate tree and curl up under its branches. No one will bother you because the tree is blocking the gate from being used.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine spending your leisure time curled up under a tree that's growing through a gate. It's so cozy and secluded!
data.reading_mnemonic: As you <kanji>leisure</kanji>ly nap, you hear a gruff voice, "Ah, you're done too, huh?" It's Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (<ja>かん</ja>)! He's spending his leisure time relaxing under this abandoned gate just like you.
data.reading_hint: But wait. Isn't Genghis Khan dead now? He winks at you, "Leisure time is for the dead." He smiles, and fades away, disappearing into the tree.

data.meaning_mnemonic: When under<radical>ground</radical> <radical>music</radical> makes it out into the light of the <radical>sun</radical> (the public), it finally becomes <kanji>official</kanji>. Music isn't really real unless people hear it outside of those secret underground concerts.
data.meaning_hint: Think of all that music you listened to underground but not in the light of the sun. None of that was official music. None of it!
data.reading_mnemonic: Once the music is <kanji>official</kanji>, you'll feel it in your <reading>sou</reading>l (<ja>そう</ja>). When you listen to it outside, under the bright sun, your soul gets to finally hear it too.
data.reading_hint: The official music penetrates into your soul, instead of just your ears, and it's affecting everyone else's souls too! Oh no... wait that's too many people. This was your song! No, it's too popular now, stop your souls from liking it! Ahhh!

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you want to <radical>say</radical> how <radical>eternity</radical> sounds you have to <kanji>compose</kanji> a poem. Or an essay. Or a song. <kanji>Recite</kanji> those deep thoughts about eternity and impress everyone who hears it.
data.meaning_hint: Try to compose a poem about eternity right now. Just jot it down somewhere.
data.reading_mnemonic: You decide to <kanji>compose</kanji> a poem about an <reading>a</reading>corn (<ja>えい</ja>). The tiny acorn is the perfect vessel for you to say how eternity feels to you.
data.reading_hint:
Let me recite the acorn poem to you now:

Acorns start small
Grow up big and tall
Spread their baby acorns for all
Live on for all eternity
