data.meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>drop</radical> to the ground in a <radical>rice paddy</radical>, and then <radical>drop</radical> down in front of the <radical>cross</radical> you keep on you because you're trying to make yourself as <kanji>lowly</kanji> as you can in front of God. He said to lower yourself and this is the only way you can interpret that.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine dropping down in a rice paddy, then again in front of your cross. Be as lowly as you can make yourself.
data.reading_mnemonic: The only problem about being <kanji>lowly</kanji> is the <reading>he</reading>at (<ja>ひ</ja>). Everyone always told you that heat rises, but not here. The rice paddy is incredibly hot... unless oh no. Is that the heat of hell?
data.reading_hint: You tried to make yourself lowly in front of God but this heat is probably a sign that you didn't do it well enough.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Every</radical> <radical>leader</radical> will come to <kanji>despise</kanji> their followers. In the beginning everything is fine and dandy, but eventually the leader's followers will ask for more and more things, eventually ridiculous things, and the leader will really despise them for it.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine yourself as a leader who's come to despise every single one of their followers. Look down at them in disgust as they ask you to grant them all a pony.
data.reading_mnemonic: The more you <kanji>despise</kanji> them, the more <reading>boo</reading>ze (<ja>ぶ</ja>) you drink. This is not smart or healthy, but it's what this kind of hate does to people.
data.reading_hint: This is not a healthy way to handle things! If you despise someone you should talk to them, don't turn to booze. Don't be like every leader that's come before you.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Take <radical>three</radical> <radical>measurement</radical>s of <radical>gold</radical> and <radical>slide</radical> them into a mold to make a <kanji>cast</kanji>! You'll have cast three gold swords, or goblets, or ducks. Just make sure you follow those directions, or your casting won't come out right.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine yourself carefully measuring out the three portions of gold and sliding them into your mold to make a cast of whatever you want. I wonder what it could be?
data.reading_mnemonic: You open the <kanji>cast</kanji> to reveal your gold statue of <reading>Chew</reading>bacca (<ja>ちゅう)</ja>! It's life-size and now you have three! Your new gold Chewbacca casts are going to guard the entrance to your house.
data.reading_hint: Picture your majestic Chewbacca casts. Carefully set them outside your front door to guard you. This was a great idea!

data.meaning_mnemonic: In a <radical>flowers</radical> <radical>net</radical> a <radical>drunkard</radical> <radical>slide</radical>s down like a <radical>drop</radical>. There they stay, an icon of <kanji>scorn</kanji> and <kanji>neglect</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: It's embarrassing to fall down a flowers net while drunk. Despite that, there you are. Everyone who goes by scorns you or neglects you.
data.reading_mnemonic: Every time you receive <kanji>scorn</kanji> and <kanji>neglect</kanji> from someone walking by, you say in your drunken voice: "I <reading>bets you</reading> (<ja>べつ</ja>) I can get up if I want. I bets you I can."
data.reading_hint: You try to get up, but no matter how much you "bets you" someone that you can get up, you slide back down the flowers net. "I bets you I can do it next time," you say.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you stay up for so long that you get to watch the <radical>moon</radical> go down and the <radical>dawn</radical> come, then people will say you have serious <kanji>guts</kanji>. Staying up that late is really hard, and not everyone can do it. If you don't have the guts to stay up, you'll just fall asleep and never see the moon and the sun switch places in the sky.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine the guts you'd have to have to stay up for so long that you see the moon and the sun switch places! A lot of guts!
data.reading_mnemonic: You were outside for so long, proving you had <kanji>guts</kanji>, that you also got a sweet <reading>tan</reading> (<ja>たん</ja>) out of it! It's a really deep tan though, and you probably need more guts if you ever want to do all that again.
data.reading_hint: Imagine having the guts to stay outside to watch the moon and the sun and then getting a really deep tan from it.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>tsunami</radical> that is <radical>good</radical>. This fabled creature has never been seen, but you <kanji>wander</kanji> the lands in search of it.
data.meaning_hint: You wander everywhere, with no particular direction in mind.
data.reading_mnemonic: As you <kanji>wander</kanji>, you come across a clue. It is fish <reading>roe</reading> (<ja>ろう</ja>).
data.reading_hint: Wherever the good tsunami goes, it leaves delicious fish roe behind. That's what makes it a good tsunami.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <reading>spirit</reading> wearing two <reading>mustache</reading>s must be <kanji>evil</kanji>. Everyone knows a mustache makes you evil, but two? And on a spirit? Yup, definitely evil.
data.meaning_hint: Look at the evil spirit with two mustaches on its spirit face. Imagine its face in detail, especially those mustaches.
data.reading_mnemonic: You're watching the <kanji>evil</kanji> mustache spirit when it starts to float toward your <reading>ca</reading>r (<ja>か</ja>). And it's... hey! It's trashing your car! You knew this guy was evil!
data.reading_hint: Imagine running around, flailing your arms, trying to get the spirit to stop ruining your car. But your hands go right through him and his two mustaches. You can't stop his evil doings.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You can only give a <radical>kiss</radical> of <radical>alcohol</radical> to <kanji>dairy</kanji>. If you add anymore than a kiss the dairy will curdle and you won't be able to drink it anymore. Bleh.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine trying to give more than a kiss of alcohol to dairy and watch it bubble and curdle and get all gross and chunky.
data.reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Dairy</kanji> isn't kept with other drinks, it needs to be placed on a <reading>rack</reading> (<ja>らく</ja>). I hope you've been using your dairy rack to store your dairy. If you haven't you should get one right away!
data.reading_hint: Look at all your dairy products: milk, yogurt, cheese, all of it sitting nicely on your dairy rack.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>soul</radical> <radical>stand</radical>s in the <radical>village</radical> you <kanji>long for</kanji>. It's the village you're from, and no matter how far you go, no matter how old you get, your soul is still there, and you <kanji>yearn</kanji> for it.
data.meaning_hint: Have you ever been away from your village? Maybe you're far away right now, studying Japanese alone. Can't you feel your body longing for your soul back home?
data.reading_mnemonic: No matter how much you <kanji>long for</kanji> it, you can't go back because <reading>a cougar</reading> (<ja>あこが</ja>) is in the way. Whenever you try to return to your village to be reunited with the soul you yearn for, a cougar is back, and won't let you in.
data.reading_hint: You long for a cougar to leave you alone! You yearn for a cougar to bother someone else!

data.meaning_mnemonic: If a pilot manages to land under a <radical>canopy</radical> with a <radical>helicopter</radical> that's pierced with a sideways <radical>barb</radical> in the <radical>heart</radical> of <radical>winter</radical> you should <kanji>congratulate</kanji> them! People should always be congratulated for doing good things, and this is one of the best things you've ever heard of!
data.meaning_hint: Can you imagine how hard landing a helicopter in just one of these horrible conditions? Congratulate them!
data.reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Congratulate</kanji> the pilot with <reading>ca</reading>ke (<ja>けい</ja>)!
data.reading_hint: Cake is always the appropriate celebratory food.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the radical that look like this are exactly the same. They are both <kanji>Asia</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: As long as you know the radical Asia, you know the kanji Asia.
data.reading_mnemonic: What's the first sound in <kanji>Asia</kanji>? It's <reading>A</reading> (<ja>あ</ja>). Nice and easy!
data.reading_hint: A is for Asia!

data.meaning_mnemonic: If the <radical>tsunami</radical> that's heading for your village is <radical>fat</radical> you should try to <kanji>select</kanji> a different one to hit instead. You don't want to select fat tsunamis because they do more damage.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine being at the tsunami store and selecting the least fat one there.
data.reading_mnemonic: If you're having trouble <kanji>select</kanji>ing which one is the least fat just check to see which tsunamis are eating <reading>ta</reading>cos (<ja>た</ja>). Only fat tsunamis will be eating them, so just look for one without a taco.
data.reading_hint: While you select the tsunami that's right for you. Keep an eye out for those fat taco-eating ones. And then stay away from them!

data.meaning_mnemonic: You make a tree spicy by turning it into a wood block print. The spice comes from all the porn you put on there. What? It wasn't me. Porn wood blocks have been around for ages!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine the journey a tree took to become a spicy wood block. MmMmm.
data.reading_mnemonic: You make these <kanji>wood block</kanji>s using <reading>a zoo saw</reading> (<ja>あずさ</ja>) because a regular saw can't handle how spicy these wood blocks are gonna get once they're covered in dirty pictures.
data.reading_hint: Imagine using a zoo saw to cut the blocks out of a tree that you're going to spice up with awesome smut.

data.meaning_mnemonic: People think <radical>tsunami</radical>s are only made of water but they have a <radical>few</radical> pieces of <kanji>sand</kanji> in there too. There's actually more sand in the ocean than most people think. And tsunamis can't just have water and sharks in them. A few grains of sand will always slip in.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine how those few grains of sand feel to get swept up into a tsunami. They didn't ask for this. They just wanted to stay at the bottom of the sea.
data.reading_mnemonic: How do I know there's <kanji>sand</kanji> in there? Because I <reading>saw</reading> (<ja>さ</ja>) them!
data.reading_hint: I saw the sand, stop doubting me!

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you ride a <radical>scooter</radical> with your <radical>fingers</radical> around an <radical>axe</radical> you're going to <kanji>die</kanji>. I mean, probably. There's a 99% chance you'll die.
data.meaning_hint: Picture someone else riding a scooter with an axe in their fingertips. That's so dangerous! One bump, one bad turn, and that axe slips and they'll die.
data.reading_mnemonic:
You slip. The axe collides with your face. You <kanji>die</kanji>. But... wait! There's a bright, blue glow and suddenly you're un-dead. You watch in slow motion as your holy blue <reading>sa</reading>ber (<ja>せい</ja>) brings you back to life and takes the hit from the axe instead.

Wait, no!

It shatters.
data.reading_hint: Your holy blue saber died for you. It saved you from certain death and now it died. After all you've been through together. All 60 levels. This is the end.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>cage</radical> is full of <radical>flowers</radical> on the <radical>right</radical> side to <kanji>hide</kanji> the fact that you're in here too.
data.meaning_hint: You don't really want to be in this cage, but there were some things you didn't want to do today, so you hid. Luckily these flowers block the right side of the cage and hide you completely.
data.reading_mnemonic: As you <kanji>hide</kanji> the ghost of <reading>Toku</reading>gawa (<ja>とく</ja>) Ieyasu appears before you, inside the cage! His arms are crossed and he's shaking his head at you. "Do you think I managed to become the first shougun of Japan by hiding?"
data.reading_hint: "N-no?" you respond. "Wrong! I hid all the time. There's nothing wrong with hiding, you're doing a great job." he says, and disappears.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Under your own <radical>roof</radical>, a <radical>geoduck</radical> jumps out of the <radical>ground</radical> with a <radical>sword</radical> and stabs your husband/wife/marriage partner to death. Now you're a <kanji>widow</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine the geoduck laughing and screaming, "Now you're a widow! Now you're a widow!" flailing the sword around. It's awful.
data.reading_mnemonic: You may be a <kanji>widow</kanji>, but that doesn't make you weak. You run outside, jump into your <reading>ca</reading>r (<ja>か</ja>), and run your entire house and the geoduck over.
data.reading_hint: It's just you and your car now, living the widow life, driving on into the sunset and forgetting your past.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You ate some <radical>grain</radical>s that made you so <radical>sick</radical> it feels like a <radical>knife</radical> is stabbing in your guts and all your poop is falling out. This is called <kanji>diarrhea</kanji>. Everyone's had diarrhea before, so you should know this feeling by now.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine back to the last time you ate something bad and it gave you diarrhea. It felt like someone was sticking you with a knife, didn't it?
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>diarrhea</kanji> is here. It's happening. And it smells so awful you can't breathe. You have to take some hollow <reading>reed</reading>s (<ja>り</ja>) and shove them up your nose and out the bathroom door so you can get some fresh air in you.
data.reading_hint: You learned this reed technique from a group of ninjas who use them to breathe underwater, and you never thought you'd use them like this.

data.meaning_mnemonic: In the <radical>dirt</radical>, you find a <radical>lid</radical> under the <radical>table</radical>. You lift it to reveal a deep <kanji>pit</kanji>. Why is there a <kanji>hole</kanji> under your table?
data.meaning_hint: You pull away the lid and crawl inside. There is a ladder that takes you deep into the pit.
data.reading_mnemonic: When you reach the bottom of the <kanji>pit</kanji>, you hear someone scuffling around and the sounds of chains. You light a match and inch closer to see what it is. In the darkness, you see <ja><reading>こう</reading>いち</ja>, starved and chained in a pit under your table.
data.reading_hint: After you've nursed <ja>こういち</ja> back to health, he explains that he was put here by a clone <ja>こういち</ja>–the very same <ja>こういち</ja> who became emperor. He tells you he can think of around 61-70 different pain levels of revenge, but also that "it probably wouldn't be worth it, so let's just hang out for a while instead. Ooh, are those cookies?"
